bulbasaur.name: Bulbasaur
bulbasaur.blurb: Bulbasaur don’t belong to any one habitat — the energy inside their plant bulbs lets them wander far from their birthplace without a steady food supply. This also means they’re not easy to train with treats.

bulbasaur.name: Ivysaur
bulbasaur.blurb: Bulbasaur becomes territorial as an Ivysaur, coinciding with the bud growing heavier. The unfurled leaves compensate with increased photosynthesis, so Ivysaur clearly mark and are very protective of their favorite sunning spots.

bulbasaur.name: Venusaur
bulbasaur.blurb: Venusaur’s bulk requires lots of energy to move, so it prefers absorbing sunlight and only luring prey for nutrition. A lack of sun makes them aggressive, but regular feeding makes for docile big ol’ lugs.

charmander.name: Charmander
charmander.blurb: Charmander’s tail reflects its diet. Experts can guess area food sources from wild Charmander flames’ behavior, smoke, and color. Other Charmander follow individuals with strong flames, hoping to chow down.

charmander.name: Charmeleon
charmander.blurb: Charmeleon hunt at night in packs by communicating with their tails as beacons. They get famously confused the first time they encounter city nightlife with its streetlamps, headlights, and neon signs.

charmander.name: Charizard
charmander.blurb: Charizard seem to breathe more fire than needed when swooping at targets, using the thermals on their next approach to avoid tiring their wings. They were thought to prefer sparse, rocky terrain, but new evidence suggests Charizard habitats just end up that way.

squirtle.name: Squirtle
squirtle.blurb: Squirtle are born upstream and migrate to the ocean as they grow. Some waterfalls become famous for journeying Squirtle bouncing off the rocks below, who quickly learn to do stunts for tourists’ food.

squirtle.name: Wartortle
squirtle.blurb: Their tails filter out metals dissolved in seawater for their next evolution, but they also swim back up rivers just because they can. Their shells become harder and darker as they store minerals, with the oldest Wartortle proud of their sheen.

squirtle.name: Blastoise
squirtle.blurb: Some say flipping them on their backs only makes them more dangerous. Inexperienced opponents may breathe a sigh of relief as an aggressive Blastoise turns away, but then the Blastoise clobbers them as it launches backward with its cannons.

caterpie.name: Caterpie
caterpie.blurb: Caterpie infestations smell awful, but their silk can be collected afterwards. Many gardeners frustrated with their ruined plants cheer up after learning how much weavers will pay for the remains.

caterpie.name: Metapod
caterpie.blurb: An old dance fad was inspired by Metapod’s clumsy, rocking motion when fleeing. Some adults still perform the dance, but kids don’t seem to find it all that exciting anymore.

caterpie.name: Butterfree
caterpie.blurb: Normally docile, Butterfree have long memories for the hardships they endured as Metapod. They will rebuff previous foes with toxic scales that also scatter light to dazzle them. However, Butterfree reward old friends and protectors even more.

weedle.name: Weedle
weedle.blurb: While Weedle is popular with kids, parents dread learning that their child’s first Pokémon friend is the kind that turns into a 3-foot hornet.

weedle.name: Kakuna
weedle.blurb: Weedle plunge their tail barb into the nearest surface to start their evolution. The cooling down as they approach evolution is important for the shell to be brittle enough to break out of.

weedle.name: Beedrill
weedle.blurb: Many have tried to train Beedrill to produce honey, only to learn that it probably shouldn’t be eaten. Fermentation makes a mead with a familiar impact and an even more familiar unpleasant buzzing.

pidgey.name: Pidgey
pidgey.blurb: A popular pet that is okay with being snuggled by children. Breeders compete for fluffier, showier plumages, but in the Pidgey stage they all kind of look the same.

pidgey.name: Pidgeotto
pidgey.blurb: Pidgey often evolve with their child owners as they grow into scrappy preteens, helping them find trouble. Everybody seems to know a kid whose Pidgeotto got them onto the school roof.

pidgey.name: Pidgeot
pidgey.blurb: Pidgeot’s glossy, colorful feathers are a common motif for vehicles. They seem vaguely insulted by this, and cars with Pidgeot stripes often find themselves mysteriously covered in branches.

rattata.name: Rattata
rattata.blurb: Rattata’s eyecatching coloration shows they have abandoned all pretense of camouflage. They respond to intruders by flashing their fearsome incisors, then with hard bites. A family Rattata is an effective watchrat.

rattata.name: Raticate
rattata.blurb: Pet Raticate are cranky, but loyal. Giving them work to tire them out is important for any household, and they’re especially good at demolition, construction, sculpting, woodcutting, and other such jobs.

rattata.name: Alolan Rattata
rattata.blurb: While normal Rattata gnaw their way into food containers, their Alolan cousins have been known to stage elaborate heists of entire foodstuffs. The current record is a horde hijacking a ramen delivery scooter.

rattata.name: Alolan Raticate
rattata.blurb: No less than 20 different pizzerias in Castelia City claim to be “The Original Faticate’s”. The actual original has long since closed, as city officials once worried about the introduction of even more voracious rats.

spearow.name: Spearow
spearow.blurb: Impossibly grumpy, but if you feed a Spearow regularly enough, it becomes protective of you. Team Grunts learn the hard way not to snatch purses from old women who bring breadcrumbs to the park.

spearow.name: Fearow
spearow.blurb: Fearow swap their youthful tempers for vindictiveness. They nest in tall cliffs other birds can’t reach. While this protects newborn Spearow, the subsequent toppling from such heights explains a lot about Spearow temperament.

ekans.name: Ekans
ekans.blurb: Rowdy bird Pokémon flocks are never a problem for long, as Ekans soon follow. You can repel birds just by painting the distinctive purple-yellow color scheme nearby.

ekans.name: Arbok
ekans.blurb:
Rangers will tell tales around the campfire about the largest thing they’ve seen an Arbok swallow whole. This usually concludes with everyone calling the others liars, and then not sleeping until dawn.
Pokéfeature: if the table agrees, Arbok’s different patterns can offer more choices for its Level 5 Ability: Regenerator, Pure Power, Immunity to Poison Moves, Speed Boost, Antagonize, etc.

pichu.name: Pichu
pichu.blurb: Pikachu love hiding their Pichu nests in modern walls: warmth, ready electricity sources, and electricity-insulating fiberglass! Fluctuating lamps and power surges are a dead giveaway, as the Pichu accidentally discharge all the time.

pichu.name: Pikachu
pichu.blurb: Machines with large magnets need frequent inspection as curious Pikachu investigate by rubbing their cheeks on them — and then get stuck. Relocating Pikachu colonies works similarly, but with a polarity shift at the end of the journey for thorough distribution.

pichu.name: Raichu
pichu.blurb: Their nests are easily distinguished by the smell of ozone. Gathering storms provoke Raichu outbursts as their static charges build. Sometimes they get so riled up that after lightning strikes, they fire back at the clouds.

pichu.name: Alolan Raichu
pichu.blurb: Raichu in Alola are normally peppy, pleasant, and easygoing, but dispense swift and terrible justice to Rattata if there’s pancakes nearby. Feuds between pancake-loving Raichu and Raticate can escalate into gang warfare.

sandshrew.name: Sandshrew
sandshrew.blurb: Sandshrew taking dust baths are famously adorable. They frolic in coarse, abrasive sand, smoothing their armor for faster rolling and slipping out of foes’ grip. Domestic Sandshrew seek out litterboxes or childrens’ sandboxes if not provided with sand to their liking.

sandshrew.name: Sandslash
sandshrew.blurb: Sandslash ambush prey by popping out of the earth or rolling down hills at great speed. Their shed plates are traditionally used to smooth wood, scour kitchenware, and polish stone.

sandshrew.name: Alolan Sandshrew
sandshrew.blurb: The Alolan variant adapted its natural minimal water requirements to survive in freezing temperatures. Grooming its shell not only keeps it clean and smooth, but provides Sandshrew with all the water it needs.

sandshrew.name: Alolan Sandslash
sandshrew.blurb: Buildings at the foot of Mt. Lanakila pay out the nose for insurance, as Sandslash that slip build enough momentum down the mountainside to pulverize cinderblocks.

nidoran♀.name: Nidoran♀
nidoran♀.blurb: Most active at dusk, as their blue coloration hides them in dim light. While grasses and leaves make up most of their diet, Pokéologists suspect that flowers such as foxglove and orchid are responsible for their hue and venom.

nidoran♀.name: Nidorina
nidoran♀.blurb: The natural matriarchs of Nidoran colonies, Nidorina are known to adopt other Pokémon into their warrens. Pictures of them sleeping on top of their adopted, fully-evolved children are very popular on the internet.

nidoran♀.name: Nidoqueen
nidoran♀.blurb: Nidorina exposed to lunar radiation undergo a fearsome metamorphosis. Researchers asked about this phenomenon shrug and suggest X-rays. Efforts to question Nidoqueen prove similarly fruitless.

nidoran♂.name: Nidoran♂
nidoran♂.blurb: The more aggressive males are dyed a deep pink to warn the eye. Every region has a rabbit Pokémon, but only Kanto has one you can’t cuddle.

nidoran♂.name: Nidorino
nidoran♂.blurb: Nidorino are fearsome guards, listening and watching intently, and charging at anything they notice. Pictures of them with their horn stuck inside various objects are very popular on the internet.

nidoran♂.name: Nidoking
nidoran♂.blurb: Nidoking get banished from their original warrens, as their unchecked strength causes constant cave-ins. Frustrated and aimless, they usually rampage through towns and other Pokémon habitats. TODO THIS IS A BARAGON REFERENCE

cleffa.name: Cleffa
cleffa.blurb: Cleffa can’t tell the difference between shooting stars and nighttime aircraft. This leads to airfield infestations as Cleffa follow planes to their landings. They then stowaway on flights to get closer to the sky.

cleffa.name: Clefairy
cleffa.blurb: While their wings are incapable of flight, they help steer and ride wind currents as Clefairy bounce along. Their behavior changes with the phases of the moon: new moons cause docile and pleasant Clefairy, while full moons see them at their most mischevious.

cleffa.name: Clefable
cleffa.blurb: Clefable are normally reclusive, but will chase meteor showers through towns and cities. Researchers are eager to see what happens if Clefable ever catch a meteorite — for now, all that is known is how much they steal on their way back.

vulpix.name: Vulpix
vulpix.blurb: Viewed from behind, their tails ripple and sway much like the tongues of a fire. Vulpix den together in the wild as they love warmth, and in captivity can be found under refrigerators, near heating vents, by furnaces, and other heat sources.

vulpix.name: Ninetales
vulpix.blurb: Ninetales are legendary for elaborate, long-running grudges, but their Trainers say they might just be cranky by nature. Grabbing their tails has been confirmed to at least result in bites.

vulpix.name: Alolan Vulpix
vulpix.blurb: A common mascot for cotton candy-flavored ice cream, especially because they love eating the stuff. Vulpix that wander down from frosty mountain peaks seek out ice dispensers to sneak inside.

vulpix.name: Alolan Ninetales
vulpix.blurb: Alolan Ninetales are in no danger from extended exposure to warm temperatures, but their fur gets soggy and tangled. Good grooming is essential for globetrotting Trainers.

igglybuff.name: Igglybuff
igglybuff.blurb: While their evolved forms know the effect of their voices, Igglybuff show off their singing at inopportune times. Igglybuff appearances are severe workplace hazards.

igglybuff.name: Jigglypuff
igglybuff.blurb: To interrupt a Jigglypuff’s rest is to invite danger. While sleeping, a Jigglypuff inflates to three times its regular size with its snores. Some especially pugnacious individuals weaponize Rest into a homerun blow.

igglybuff.name: Wigglytuff
igglybuff.blurb: Wigglytuff have perfect pitch, both in voice and hearing. Lesser vocalists interrupting their performances disturbs them greatly, but they will also start bands with other musical Pokémon.

zubat.name: Zubat
zubat.blurb: Zubat overwhelm any environment they’re introduced to, as their toxic bloodstream means they have very few predators. This is considered an adaptation from feeding on blood in the Kanto region, where Poison-Types abound.

zubat.name: Golbat
zubat.blurb: Since its club feet and broad wings are very poor at grasping, Golbat’s tongue is primarily used as a prehensile limb. Some Golbat refuse to hold items that taste bad.

zubat.name: Crobat
zubat.blurb: Its four wings and constant hovering make Crobat’s energy requirements extremely high. One theory is that Golbat only evolve when they trust a companion to provide enough food for their new, higher-performance bodies.

oddish.name: Oddish
oddish.blurb: Contact with Oddish’s poisonous leaves gives skin an itchy rash. Children playing in yards often come home with them after an Oddish takes up residence on its wandering journey.

oddish.name: Gloom
oddish.blurb: Research is underway to determine how Gloom’s drool can smell awful and still attract prey. The current theory: other Pokémon seek out the source of the stink after getting fed up with it. They then get stuck in the sticky drool trail, and Gloom finds them by retracing its steps.

oddish.name: Vileplume
oddish.blurb: Vileplume can be mascots or calling cards for those who want a femme fatale image. Many a successful perfume line is produced with the cooperation of a Vileplume’s unique chemical concoction.

oddish.name: Bellossom
oddish.blurb: Bellossom don’t have feet — their “skirt” leaves form its method of locomotion. This explains their swaying, rhythmic movement as the leaves buckle together to propel them. Gloom flip over to evolve into Bellossom, with their former feet becoming the “head” flowers.

paras.name: Paras
paras.blurb: Paras colonies plant their tochukaso on each other as a rite of passage. There have been reports of such colonies adopting other subterranean Pokémon and attempting to bestow upon them the same honor, with varying results.

paras.name: Parasect
paras.blurb: There is much debate around whether Paras can evolve at all without a mushroom parasite. Parasect can become truly ancient if the mushroom is well-fed, growing into unique and impressive fungal towers.

venonat.name: Venonat
venonat.blurb: Venonat make good scouts, as their eyes and antennae detect everything from x-rays to electrical disturbances. However, their senses are easily overwhelmed. Wild Venonat can be found circling bright lights, malfunctioning power equipment, and campfires.

venonat.name: Venomoth
venonat.blurb: Finding where Venomoth sleep during the day is a mixed blessing. Their scales coat every surface and settle on the ground. This triggers ferocious allergy attacks, but they can be collected to use as medicine, pigments, or even spices for the adventurous chef.

diglett.name: Diglett
diglett.blurb: Although Diglett’s body is weak, its grip strength is unparalleled. Trainers that try to pull Diglett out of the ground have dislocated their shoulders without budging it an inch.

diglett.name: Dugtrio
diglett.blurb: Although Diglett is a farmer’s best friend, Dugtrio’s aggressive digging can collapse fields. Farmers with Diglett herds must take care to keep other pests out, as too much battle can lead to crop-ruining evolution.

diglett.name: Alolan Diglett
diglett.blurb: Diglett’s love of tree roots make it a constant annoyance for Alolan Exeggutor. Its golden whiskers sense the heavy footsteps of this tree, and it then chews on Exeggutor’s back seed.

diglett.name: Alolan Dugtrio
diglett.blurb: Dugtrio can dig through volcanic rock, which sometimes backfires and leads it into Salandit lairs. Salandit love to steal Dugtrio’s beautiful golden whiskers. Trainers in volcanic areas sometimes find entire wigs made of the stolen material.

meowth.name: Meowth
meowth.blurb: Meowth shrines are popular in urban areas, allowing people to donate coins for good luck. Many Meowth have set up successful hustles by replacing a Meowth statue and collecting the coins itself.

meowth.name: Persian
meowth.blurb: Medieval texts from Kanto warn that Persians are bad luck if you see their jewel shining in the night. It is unknown whether this is because the jewel holds a curse, or because the Persian is now about to attack you.

meowth.name: Alolan Meowth
meowth.blurb: In Alola, Meowth only like to be gifted coins of at least 100₽ or more. If offered anything less, it will be insulted and bite the Trainer’s hand before leaving. It still takes the coin though.

meowth.name: Alolan Persian
meowth.blurb: Many residents in Alola consider it good luck to have an Persian in your town. Persian Towns always close up before sunset, and residents leave saucers of treats on their doorstep. If either of these are forgotten, tragedy often follows.

meowth.name: Galarian Meowth
meowth.blurb: The seafaring warrior people that bred “Galarian” Meowth don’t live in Galar, making the moniker technically inaccurate. It’s unknown what variant of Meowth lived in Galar before, if any.

meowth.name: Perrserker
meowth.blurb: Perrserker can’t be bribed away if it sees a fight coming. The only thing it loves more than violence is, for some reason, team sports. It gets along spectacularly with Scorbunny.

psyduck.name: Psyduck
psyduck.blurb: Psyduck that live in willow-lined lakes display markedly different behavior due to the natural aspirin leaching into the water. They’re more focused and playful, but lose their psychic powers. Stressful environments produce the opposite effect.

psyduck.name: Golduck
psyduck.blurb: While Golduck are peaceful, their quiet movement can startle rivergoers. The Kappa legend often results in the Golduck receiving a deep, respectful bow. This confuses them, but Golduck near popular watering holes learn to return the gesture.

mankey.name: Mankey
mankey.blurb: They are highly social despite their hair-trigger temper, but a colony of Mankey is a veritable powder keg. Mankey migrations are tied to the appearance of rainbows, drifting balloons, or other phenomena they all decide to chase and beat up.

mankey.name: Primeape
mankey.blurb: Primeape has lost the prehensile digits it had as a Mankey, reserving its limbs only for violence. Their full-body coat of dense hair developed to prevent injury from infighting. Silph Co. cites Primeape as the reason Poké Balls were invented.

growlithe.name: Growlithe
growlithe.blurb: Growlithe’s guard instinct is so strong that they can be found protecting random locations or Pokémon in the wild. Abandoned structures may still retain their Growlithe generations later.

growlithe.name: Arcanine
growlithe.blurb: An Arcanine’s stripes moving through tall grass can be mistaken for a brushfire. This is effective camouflage during actual brushfires, which they may intentionally ignite.

poliwag.name: Poliwag
poliwag.blurb: Chased Poliwag leap into the nearest body of water, then turn to face their pursuers. The rippling surface and their bouyant bobbing amplify their stomach’s hypnotic powers, leading to predator species dozing in shallows.

poliwag.name: Poliwhirl
poliwag.blurb: Recently-evolved Poliwhirl are so fascinated by their new hands that they will grab anything they see. This results in items scattered in strange spots, as they drop what they carry to hold something else.

poliwag.name: Poliwrath
poliwag.blurb: Politoed encourage evolution for their Poliwhirl subjects to Poliwrath as powerful guards, but only the most skilled rule well enough to avoid Poliwrath revolts. The Poliwrath afterwards have problems with authority.

poliwag.name: Politoed
poliwag.blurb: When presented with a Water Stone and a King’s Rock, most Poliwhirl are paralyzed with indecision. After evolution, Politoed hoard Water Stones and other shiny trinkets. Politoed ponds are free of litter, because they either hoard it or throw it elsewhere.

abra.name: Abra
abra.blurb: Silent and reclusive, Abra are usually found only when their presence interferes with television and cell reception. Organizations sometimes use them as natural signal jammers.

abra.name: Kadabra
abra.blurb: Notorious urban pests, Kadabra break into houses and ransack silverware drawers to replace worn-out spoons. These intrusions are virtually undetectable unless there are only clean forks, in which case grumbling ensues.

abra.name: Alakazam
abra.blurb: Despite early studies proclaiming Alakazam’s unlimited intelligence, they’re unable to speak or write human languages, don’t really grasp the concept of lying, and can’t seem to recognize themselves in mirrors.

machop.name: Machop
machop.blurb: Despite their humanoid shape, Machop are close to reptiles. They appear in mountains and caves to regulate their body temperature, with the strongest Machop venturing outside at night to keep cool during their workout.

machop.name: Machoke
machop.blurb: The fins on Machoke’s head and the ridges on its arms dissipate heat, letting their muscles flex even harder. The social rank of a Machoke in an area is revealed by how elaborate its belt is.

machop.name: Machamp
machop.blurb: Machamp travel over treacherous terrain by flipping over and walking on their four hands. Their lips have many blood vessels to regulate heat through breathing, so beware a Machamp that looks like it’s winded — it’s only getting started.

bellsprout.name: Bellsprout
bellsprout.blurb: Bellsprout’s eyespots are only capable of sensing light and dark. To compensate, it senses vibrations with its root feet and air currents with its leaves. A swaying Bellsprout when there is no wind is taking a good look around.

bellsprout.name: Weepinbell
bellsprout.blurb: If unable to attract enough prey, hungry Weepinbell will wait for something to pass by underneath their tree perches, then fall onto their heads. This can result in very confused Weepinbell stuck atop Pokémon with unusual anatomy — sometimes for days.

bellsprout.name: Victreebel
bellsprout.blurb: Victreebel hate changing their ambush position, since their movement makes loud sloshing noises. Fleeing Victreebel will dump all of their acid on the ground to lessen their sound and scent, and to increase their speed.

tentacool.name: Tentacool
tentacool.blurb: Tentacool’s red spots look like rubies, but are soft and jellylike. Shoals of them on the water’s surface during a sunset or sunrise are a brilliant sight. Sailors use their soft red glow to navigate at night, since they don’t move around much.

tentacool.name: Tentacruel
tentacool.blurb: Buoys warning of danger are crafted to look like Tentacruel, so even marine Pokémon know to avoid them. While the underside is bad news, the top of a Tentacruel makes a soft and comfortable perch for watergoing Trainers.

geodude.name: Geodude
geodude.blurb: While sleeping Geodude blend in with their craggy habitats, they are very conspicuous when active. Without legs, they hoist themselves around on rocky arms that thud and clatter with every step.

geodude.name: Graveler
geodude.blurb: Graveler’s diet of earth accumulates nitrates, coal, and sulfur, then its internal pressure compresses them into gunpowder. This explains their explosive reputation. If two Graveler meet on a mountain peak, they have a sumo match. The loser is tossed wherever the victor wants.

geodude.name: Golem
geodude.blurb: Golem’s constant rolling down mountainsides cracks open rock faces near the base, exposing the harder minerals they prefer to eat. Prospectors consider Golem furrows to be giant arrows pointing at dig sites.

geodude.name: Alolan Geodude
geodude.blurb: Mountaineers and spelunkers dread evidence of Alolan Geodude, since they render their compasses useless. The workaround is to find one and wait for it to fall asleep — for some reason, they prefer to sleep facing north.

geodude.name: Alolan Graveler
geodude.blurb: Wild Graveler in Alola have iron filings attached to their faces haphazardly. Trainers sometimes rearrange the filings on their Gravelers’ faces to represent its personality. This risks detonation if the Graveler glimpses its reflection and doesn’t like it.

geodude.name: Alolan Golem
geodude.blurb: If suitable rocks are scarce, Golem will improvise with anything sufficiently magnetic: scrap, unattended machinery, or Steel-Type Pokémon. Alolan locations inhabited by both Golem and the Magnemite family are dangerous indeed.

ponyta.name: Ponyta
ponyta.blurb: Ponyta loves eating starchy, oily plants. Ponyta in areas with abundant food are slower and more docile, but their flames burn much hotter to compensate.

ponyta.name: Rapidash
ponyta.blurb: The horn is strictly for driving away foes. Its appearance is too drab to attract mates, and its sharpness combined with Rapidash’s speed is too lethal to use in dominance fights among them.

ponyta.name: Galarian Ponyta
ponyta.blurb: Residents in Glimwood Tangle say that lost Trainers can always count on Ponyta to show them the way out of the forest. This is both a comfort and a warning, as Trainers with impure hearts often find themselves expeled violently by forces they cannot see.

ponyta.name: Galarian Rapidash
ponyta.blurb: Rapidash don’t herd in Galar. A lone Rapidash will settle where it finds a water source, protecting the pure water from “corruption”. Ponyta run freely from one Rapidash’s territory to another to mingle. It’s rumored that Rapidash will still meet one another where moonlight shines.

slowpoke.name: Slowpoke
slowpoke.blurb: Excellent companions for small children and babies who enjoy sucking on Slowpoke’s tail. Slowpoke doesn’t even mind when the babies start teething.

slowpoke.name: Slowbro
slowpoke.blurb: The Shellder has much more of a preservation instinct than Slowbro does. They rotate around on Slowbro’s tail to monitor the surroundings, and bite down when they want Slowbro to start running.

slowpoke.name: Slowking
slowpoke.blurb: Slowking gain reputation among local Pokémon as oracles in the areas they settle in. When dispensing wisdom, sometimes the Shellder on their head can be seen rolling its eyes. What this means is uncertain.

slowpoke.name: Galarian Slowpoke
slowpoke.blurb: Water that Galar Slowpoke dip their tail into takes on a spicy taste that people love. It’s popular in tea shops, but be warned: it only works fresh. Store-packaged Slowpoke teas use an entirely different recipe to “simulate the experience.”

slowpoke.name: Galarian Slowbro
slowpoke.blurb: Slowbro and Shellder rarely get along in Galar, biting and pinching even in battle. Their lack of teamwork makes Galarian Slowbro unreliable, but neither wants to give up the evolution’s benefits. Pokéologists call it mutual parasitism; counselors call it a toxic relationship.

slowpoke.name: Galarian Slowking
slowpoke.blurb: Galarian occult shops have shelves full of various Slowking potions. Most are fake, but the real deal might be even more dangerous. Only Slowking knows what effects its potions will have, and attempts to analyze them only lead to gibberish.

magnemite.name: Magnemite
magnemite.blurb: Magnemite’s apparent levitation is a source of frustration for many Trainers, as Ground-Type attacks are their bane. Research shows their magnetic levitation functions like legs, repulsing the ground for support instead of hanging in the air.

magnemite.name: Magneton
magnemite.blurb: The rotation of their components is how they build a charge. Magneton recognize humans by their biorhythms and electric field, so they can be momentarily confused when their Trainer shuffles across a carpet on a dry day.

magnemite.name: Magnezone
magnemite.blurb: On certain nights Magnezone suddenly crowd the sky, flooding the ground beneath with spotlights. They scan forests for something only they’re aware of. They scatter just as quickly.

farfetch'd.name: Farfetch'd
farfetch'd.blurb: Farfetch’d normally can’t live in areas where their hallmark leeks don’t grow, but conservation efforts to expand their habitat have taught them to wield other items for self-defense. Farfetch’d colonies have flourished, each centered around a different kind of weapon.

farfetch'd.name: Galarian Farfetch'd
farfetch'd.blurb: If Farfetch’d needs to take off quickly, it will use its leek as a pole vault to launch itself into the sky. This makes Farfetch’d more difficult to track in Galar, a fact Galarian birdwatchers cite proudly.

farfetch'd.name: Sirfetch'd
farfetch'd.blurb: Sirfetch’d gather in flocks with a strict leek-size heirarchy. Sirfetch’d with smaller leeks sometimes find themselves bullied, but are too gallantly loyal to simply leave. These Sirfetch’d dream of another life, and will actively seek out adventurous Trainers to take them away.

doduo.name: Doduo
doduo.blurb: Doduo Trainers take special pains to ensure they don’t give one head more attention than the other, otherwise they can grow jealous. Hand signals work poorly, as both hands must hold a treat for each head during training.

doduo.name: Dodrio
doduo.blurb: Dodrio make excellent taxis, as their three heads remember more streets than a human can. Their unpredictable temperament isn’t even a downside compared to human cabbies.

seel.name: Seel
seel.blurb: Seel’s tongue is coated with salty saliva so it doesn’t stick to icy surfaces. Its vascular system shunts excess heat to its horn, making it easier to break ice. The horn becomes especially warm when Seel is in hotter climates.

seel.name: Dewgong
seel.blurb: Dewgong’s body has gotten bulkier and better at regulating temperature, so its horn has instead adapted to draw heat out of whatever it pierces. Would-be predators escape with frostbitten dents.

grimer.name: Grimer
grimer.blurb: Long-term use of X-Items or other pharmaceuticals can permanently change Grimer’s chemical composition. Trainers have reported differences in color, battle performance, and even personality.

grimer.name: Muk
grimer.blurb: Muk avoid each other in the wild — contact causes unpredictable chemical reactions. This has the unfortunate side-effect of them being extremely expansionist, always on the hunt for unspoiled habitat.

grimer.name: Alolan Grimer
grimer.blurb: Grimer’s Alolan variation is more active and vigorous, but it has lost the ability to sustain itself with its own chemical reactions. A constant diet of toxins is required, as hungry Grimers will not hesitate to eat their Trainer’s possessions.

grimer.name: Alolan Muk
grimer.blurb: The Alolan variety of Muk clean up biohazards, but sometimes drop their concentrated poison crystals. These crystals can pollute entire ecosystems, so they sell for large sums on the black market.

shellder.name: Shellder
shellder.blurb: Shellder uses its tongue for positioning, sensation, fine movements, manipulation, and feeding. New nighttime divers are often surprised to see underwater fields of Shellder tongues waving slowly in the current.

shellder.name: Cloyster
shellder.blurb: Cloyster hold the world record for life found in the deepest parts of the ocean. Their ultrastrong shells let them sink to the bottom of marine trenches and prowl around. Deep-sea expeditions have to be on the lookout for them.

gastly.name: Gastly
gastly.blurb: Gastly are said to lower temperatures with their presence, but it’s the other way around — they are blown around by drafts, and seek out cold air to solidify them and help speed up their evolution into Haunter.

gastly.name: Haunter
gastly.blurb: Wind can dissipate Haunter’s newly-grown hands, so it prefers its long prehensile tongue unless the air is still. HVAC systems should be checked regularly in the summer to catch Haunter infestations early.

gastly.name: Gengar
gastly.blurb: Home intrusions by Gengar are common on cold moonless nights. Recent relieving research suggests they are energized by heat, so offerings of plugged-in electric blankets have become a common sight near cemeteries.

onix.name: Onix
onix.blurb: Its burrowing adaptations leave it disoriented and weak on the surface. Trainers are often surprised by the might of an Onix that has its tunnel for leverage — a rocky fin bearing down on you like a land shark is a terrifying sight in Onix undercountry.

onix.name: Steelix
onix.blurb: Steelix are invaluable in the excavation industry. They dig holes for sewer mains, subway lines, and tunnels with an unerring sense of direction, tuned around magnetic north. They even help find aquifers — if they refuse to dig, there’s one.

drowzee.name: Drowzee
drowzee.blurb: Folk remedies for insomnia and nightmares have long advised sleep near Drowzee habitats. Today, sleep clinics, psychiactric institutes, and psychological trauma care employ highly-trained Drowzee. Less rigorously, some claim Drowzee can use Belch after successful Dream Eater use.

drowzee.name: Hypno
drowzee.blurb: The pendulum is not for Hypno’s targets; it helps concentrate its psychic powers. Those it ambushes tend to be understandably upset, so it uses the soothing rhythm to help its brain weather the negative feelings.

krabby.name: Krabby
krabby.blurb: Shed Krabby claws contract as their ligaments dry out. They’re traditionally used as kitchen tools, knives, clothespins, and natural fasteners.

krabby.name: Kingler
krabby.blurb: The oversized claw is the result of an evolutionary arms race with Cloyster. A recent internet sensation is an ongoing video series where a Kalosian man places various items inside a Kingler’s larger claw, crushing them on camera.

voltorb.name: Voltorb
voltorb.blurb: Sleepy Voltorb hide in out-of-the-way places, then their bodies shrink as their internal energy calms down. Unfortunately, this makes them look like lost Poké Balls. Rude awakenings by curious Trainers explain a lot of their infamous temper.

voltorb.name: Electrode
voltorb.blurb: Many have tried to peacefully harness Electrode’s explosive power. The most effective method is to keep them hungry and low on electricity, but that makes them so cranky that sometimes they explode prematurely.

exeggcute.name: Exeggcute
exeggcute.blurb: Individuals with broken shells are used as rear guards to prevent surprise attacks, keeping them away from the dangers of battle. Exeggcute deter Ekans and other snake Pokémon — in fact, some bird Pokémon tolerate them sharing nest space.

exeggcute.name: Exeggutor
exeggcute.blurb: It is nigh-impossible to train an Exeggutor for consistent behavior. Even if all their heads drop off, three brains from their previous life as Exeggcute squabble within the trunk. Some gardeners throw away Leaf Stones on sight.

exeggcute.name: Alolan Exeggutor
exeggcute.blurb: People have tried to use this towering variant of Exeggutor as a lookout, but its constant yammering makes it hard to tell when it’s trying to sound the alarm. Supposedly, it is so tall that it can borrow the power of heaven.

cubone.name: Cubone
cubone.blurb: Caught Cubone will quickly and fiercely imprint on their Trainer if well cared-for. Some claim to know what its face looks like, but usually that it’s surprisingly plain.

cubone.name: Marowak
cubone.blurb: Marowak make nests out of collected bones, then abandon their eggs to fend for themselves. The newborn Cubone aren’t smart enough to question how their mother had multiple skulls.

cubone.name: Alolan Marowak
cubone.blurb: The Alolan variant of Marowak is remarkably bad at normal ghostly activities such as turning invisible, walking through walls, and stalking people. Its bones and skeleton markings always show when it tries to hide itself, it collides with walls, and it constantly clatters.

tyrogue.name: Tyrogue
tyrogue.blurb: A Tyrogue that can’t train for an extended period of time will lose its fighting spirit and refuse to evolve. Some areas with Tyrogue populations hold public exercise routines to avoid this predicament.

tyrogue.name: Hitmonlee
tyrogue.blurb: Though they tend not to get along with Hitmonchan in the wild, sometimes they team up to defend their homes. Hitmonchan sits on Hitmonlee’s shoulders while Hitmonlee holds their legs, and their combined size and prowess scare off most intruders.

tyrogue.name: Hitmonchan
tyrogue.blurb: A strange symbiosis happens between Hitmonchan and Ghost-Types. They enjoy teasing its inability to hit them, and it appreciates the shadowboxing practice. Hitmonchan are only employed for demolition jobs, since their gloves prevent them from handling objects.

tyrogue.name: Hitmontop
tyrogue.blurb: The tail unique to this branch of the Hitmon family is crucial for keeping its balance — a typical vestibular system would become very dizzy from its constant spinning.

lickitung.name: Lickitung
lickitung.blurb: Lickitung avoid freezing climates for obvious reasons. In their native jungle habitats, they hunt by unrolling their tongues into the underbrush, then waiting for passerby to stick to it.

lickitung.name: Lickilicky
lickitung.blurb: Lickilicky are great chef assistants, able to keep track of temperature from the heat in the air and delicately handle pots and pans from any distance. Regions used to ban Lickilicky from being in kitchens until recently, citing their tendency to taste teste everything as unsanitary.

koffing.name: Koffing
koffing.blurb: The international symbol for hazardous material. Constant nuisances in industrial areas, but thankfully their easygoing temperament means you can swat them out of your house with a broom. The odd marking on the front is thought to be some sort of heat-sensing organ.

koffing.name: Weezing
koffing.blurb: The heads take turns as the larger one, swapping each night. It’s attracted to any poisonous gas and doesn’t clean the air outside of Galar, so factories try to shoo them away when health inspectors show up. The tusks anchor them to surfaces while they sleep.

koffing.name: Galarian Weezing
koffing.blurb: Weezing is popular as the Pokémon who cleaned up Galar back when skies were blind with smog. It’s considered customary to tip your hat if you see one flying by. They still love eating poison though, so you should probably leave after.

rhyhorn.name: Rhyhorn
rhyhorn.blurb: Rhyhorn fights can be heard for miles. They are so tough and so stubborn that their fights only end when the loser is flipped onto their back. To groom a Rhyhorn’s plates to a contest-ready finish, contact your local sandblaster.

rhyhorn.name: Rhydon
rhyhorn.blurb: Rhydon spreads its arms wide to appear larger and more intimidating — they’re too clumsy and rigid to be good for manipulation. Despite their Typing, Rhydon are good swimmers, able to travel over both water and magma.

rhyhorn.name: Rhyperior
rhyhorn.blurb: Rhyperior is not a natural evolution, only happening when it interacts with the Protector item. Its aggression raises through the roof and its power grows immensely, so researchers think this may be Rhydon’s attempt at Mega Evolution.

happiny.name: Happiny
happiny.blurb: Happiny loves to pick up eggs it finds and put them in its pouch, to the annoyance of Pokémon who laid those eggs. Happiny usually gives the egg back, but if the offending parent is too rude, it will just run off.

happiny.name: Chansey
happiny.blurb:
Travelers who spy a shadow darting from hiding place to hiding place are relieved when it’s revealed to be a Chansey.
SURGEON CHAMPION’S WARNING: Contact your Pokémon Center if you or a loved one are suffering from Chansey egg addiction.

happiny.name: Blissey
happiny.blurb: Many Blissey choose hospitality work over battling. Only Blissey with a very strong bond with their Trainer will follow them into battle.

tangela.name: Tangela
tangela.blurb: The vines that Tangela shed taste great when sliced, fried, and salted into chips. Tangela that learn of this custom will leave vines on doorsteps and then knock on the door a day later. “Tangela’s share” is a phrase in some areas, meaning a portion set aside for good luck.

tangela.name: Tangrowth

evolves.by: Know Ancient Power and level up

tangela.blurb: Children commonly scare each other by pretending a shrub is Tangrowth, then daring each other to count the vines. Every once in a while, this becomes a dangerous game.

kangaskhan.name: Kangaskhan
kangaskhan.blurb: If a Kangaskhan battles while facing you, that means it’s teaching its child how to defend itself. It will turn around and attack viciously with its tail if it’s concerned about its ability to defeat its opponent safely.

horsea.name: Horsea
horsea.blurb: Horsea ink is still used today for calligraphy. It’s collected by surprising them in the wild, then wiping off the surpriser after the Horsea jettisons ink to escape.

horsea.name: Seadra
horsea.blurb: Horsea in decorative ponds or fishtanks cause a lot of trouble when they evolve into Seadra. Relocation facilities are a necessity, or they will be released to terrorize local waterways.

horsea.name: Kingdra
horsea.blurb: The fins on either side of Kingdra’s face are so sensitive, oceanographers use Kingdra to monitor changes in ocean temperature and composition.

goldeen.name: Goldeen
goldeen.blurb: Goldeens are proud of their horns, and assume anything they attack is dead unless it bites back. Aquariums keep them behind eight inches of shatterproof glass.

goldeen.name: Seaking
goldeen.blurb: If Seaking does not like the aquarium it is kept in, there is nothing to keep it from shattering out. Their standards are high, so most Seaking Trainers just raise them outside.

staryu.name: Staryu
staryu.blurb: Staryu prefers to keep the arm ringed by a golden strap in the same orientation. Research suggests it helps Staryu distinguish left from right and up from down, as it’s strangely unable to sense the tug of gravity.

staryu.name: Starmie
staryu.blurb: Starmie improves on Staryu’s prioperception with its spinning, gyroscopic back half. Sometimes, Starmie with missing arms flop onto beaches to rest and regenerate in peace. Do not approach them; you should see what happened to the other combatant.

mime jr..name: Mime Jr.
mime jr..blurb: Mime Jr. are popular acting alongside puppets in plays. A performer gestures backstage, and Mime Jr. mimics them. A particularly attentive Mime Jr. may even have dialog! Beware hecklers: Mime Jr. will mimic gestures right back at the audience if confronted.

mime jr..name: Mr. Mime
mime jr..blurb: Beware Mr. Mime in cities. Their outlandish appearance, ability to deflect impact, and pursuit-blocking walls make them perfect distractions and partners in petty theft. In natural Mr. Mime territory, hold a stick in front of you so you don’t collide with leftover walls.

mime jr..name: Galarian Mr. Mime

evolves.by: Know Mimic and level up while British

mime jr..blurb: Mr. Mimes in Galar break into dance studios at night to practice their footwork. They leave icy trails all over the floor, constituting a serious hazard. To deal with this, most dance studios have their floors heated at night, but low-budget studios just play music that Mr. Mime dislike.

mime jr..name: Mr. Rime
mime jr..blurb: Mr. Rime’s belly pattern is a pro at mimicking facial expressions, but it’s just expertly manipulated folds and skin. They used to be an icon of film, but nowadays you’ll mostly see Mr. Rime as an acting coach.

scyther.name: Scyther
scyther.blurb: Experienced wild Scyther hone one blade on rocks in their habitat, but keep the other rough to saw through tough materials. Working Scyther may have their blades serrated in different positions and patterns to make their jobs easier.

scyther.name: Scizor
scyther.blurb: Scizor molts once a year, discarding a pile of thick red steel. Scizor’s old shells melt at a lower temperature than other metals and are highly malleable, making them a smith’s dream. Historians believe that legendary swords of the past were made from these shells.

smoochum.name: Smoochum
smoochum.blurb: A Smoochum with chapped lips is highly distracted. It will ignore commands in battle, refuse food, and constantly wander off in search of anything that can be used as lip balm. Smoochum Trainers should carry chapstick.

smoochum.name: Jynx
smoochum.blurb: Surfaces beneath Jynx’s feet are flash-frozen with a thin layer of ice. This lets it execute smooth sweeping dance moves, but leaves behind slippery footprints in cold weather.

elekid.name: Elekid
elekid.blurb: Wild Elekid gather at the sound of thunder. With enough present, they act as a lightning rod and draw strikes away from nearby structures, recharging themselves at the same time.

elekid.name: Electabuzz
elekid.blurb: Electabuzz is one of the hardest Pokémon to groom. Bathing must be done with rubber gloves, and their fur bristles on end in dry conditions. However, hair combed in one direction strengthens its electrical discharges, so it appreciates the effort.

elekid.name: Electivire
elekid.blurb: When Electabuzz drains too much power from a plant, it may become Electivire. Electivire is extremely aggressive and hunts down other Electric-Types to steal their electricity. They get really excited when something punches back.

magby.name: Magby
magby.blurb: Magby has such a high reputation for glassblowing that many shops will advertise with Magby even if they use other Fire-Type Pokémon to craft their wares. If an inspector finds out, the shop can be charged for fraud.

magby.name: Magmar
magby.blurb: You can feel the rushing air when high-level Magmar intake oxygen to blow their hottest flames. Companies rent out Magmar as mobile space heaters, especially for outdoor winter events.

magby.name: Magmortar
magby.blurb: When a Magmar causes their volcano to erupt, they can evolve into Magmortar. Magmortar is endlessly confident and will burn down anything to make the area feel as hot as home. They respect anything that sticks around after getting shot.

pinsir.name: Pinsir
pinsir.blurb: Though capable of many martial arts techniques, its lack of honor prevents it from reaping the benefits of the Fighting-Type. Pinsir tracks are a beekeeper’s least favorite sight. Come to think of it, nobody really enjoys seeing Pinsir tracks.

tauros.name: Tauros
tauros.blurb: Pressing the largest gray stud on Tauros’s forehead will immobilize it… as long as you keep it pressed. Old cowpokes use this trick to stop a rampaging Tauros right in its tracks.

magikarp.name: Magikarp
magikarp.blurb: Magikarp was once the focus of arguments about the nature of intelligence and what Pokémon are acceptable to eat. The controversy died out and never settled; Magikarp taste terrible.

magikarp.name: Gyarados
magikarp.blurb: Both Magikarp and Gyarados will always bite a fishing line, even if it doesn’t have bait. Fishermen say that Magikarp is too dull to understand the problem, but Gyarados knows exactly what is on the other end.

lapras.name: Lapras
lapras.blurb: Lapras born during their resurgence are quicker to defend themselves and snap at strangers than before. Some aggressive specimens come onto land and attempt to engage vehicles in dominance contests by slamming their bodies against them.

ditto.name: Ditto
ditto.blurb: Ditto are extremely easy to train — they eat anything and benefit from any kind of exercise. The drawback is the amount of mischief they’re constantly getting into.

eevee.name: Eevee
eevee.blurb: Demand for pet Eevee is always high, but they can be surprisingly stressful to raise — they require constant supervision to keep them from evolving into something you don’t want.

eevee.name: Vaporeon
eevee.blurb: Piscine mutations let Vaporeon live both on land and in water. Tales of mermaids may have come from very drunk sailors spotting Vaporeon. Nowadays they’re often found lying in sinks.

eevee.name: Jolteon
eevee.blurb: Jolteon have been respected and noble pets throughout history, but the modern ubiquity of electricity leads to frequent complaints of licked sockets, chewed wires, and Jolteon running away with fresh laundry stuck to them.

eevee.name: Flareon
eevee.blurb: Not an indoor pet. Firemen worldwide use Flareon’s courage, strength, and fire resistance to help clear burning buildings of debris, and to drag people and Pokémon to safety. They are the stereotypical mascot of fire brigades.

eevee.name: Espeon
eevee.blurb: Espeon are rarely seen in the wild, but not unheard of. It is considered extremely poor taste to capture one alone, as Espeon only evolve when they have something to protect nearby.

eevee.name: Umbreon
eevee.blurb: Although moon rays should evolve most Eevee, wild Umbreon are rare, instead usually evolving under a beloved Trainer to protect them from attackers. Umbreon that evolve in the wild are especially antisocial, refusing to mingle even with other Eevee.

eevee.name: Leafeon
eevee.blurb: When Leafeon is groomed, the trimmings can be collected and turned into potpourri. This potpourri is extremely popular at parties, but also attracts wild Pokémon. You can tell the health of a Leafeon by the scent: wilting Leafeons smell like unripe fruit.

eevee.name: Glaceon
eevee.blurb: Glaceon is a great way to avoid paying for air conditioning. It never lets the atmosphere around it go above 65°F, so as long as it lives in your house it never gets too warm. Don’t forget to feed it though, unless you want a house colder than the worst winter.

eevee.name: Sylveon
eevee.blurb: Because Sylveon only evolves through a bond with a Trainer, they do not occur in the wild. It is legally debated if Sylveon is an artificial Pokémon, or simply domesticated. In theory, Sylveon could evolve from bonds with other species, but this has yet to be observed.

porygon.name: Porygon
porygon.blurb: By the time the patent on Porygon expired, it was revealed that its source code had been lost for a decade. Efforts to reverse-engineer it have met with great difficulty.

porygon.name: Porygon2
porygon.blurb: Once a Porygon2 gets into cyberspace, it disappears in the first direction that sparks interest. While most will reappear back within a week, some Porygon2 have been found wandering the far reaches of the internet years after their Trainers last saw them.

porygon.name: Porygon-Z
porygon.blurb: The Dubious Disc is illegal to copy, as it’s filled with glitches and possible malware. Silph Co has posted a 200,000₽ bounty to figure out who made the device. It still pops up here and there, especially in organizations that desire Porygon-Z’s “creative” accounting skills.

omanyte.name: Omanyte
omanyte.blurb: Omanyte’s beak is hidden among its tentacles, giving it a docile appearance. Its drab shell is theorized to once have a vibrant pattern, but such details don’t fossilize well.

omanyte.name: Omastar
omanyte.blurb: On land, Omastar seems to sway and shake to a beat only it can hear. This “dance” is it staggering under the weight of its shell outside of water, without buoyancy to help hold it up.

kabuto.name: Kabuto
kabuto.blurb: Kabuto leap from the water to scare would-be predators with their glowing red eyes, or to latch onto visitors they think make good prey. They are not popular choices for fossil resurrection.

kabuto.name: Kabutops
kabuto.blurb: Full Kabutops skeletons are an astoundingly popular museum exhibit, but rarely found in the wild. Black market dealers resurrect Kabutops fragments and sell the skeleton when it dies to fake history. This is why Kabuto guards are a mobster film staple.

aerodactyl.name: Aerodactyl
aerodactyl.blurb: Before resurrecting the infamously cranky and dangerous Aerodactyl, Trainers should think about whether they should. Scientists have many theories about how this omnivorous, effective predator could have gone extinct, but they all agree it was a mercy.

munchlax.name: Munchlax
munchlax.blurb: Munchlax’s long fur is apparently full of bacteria and yeasts that are great for fermentation. This helps explain why it sometimes hides food under its fur, when normally it eats everything immediately.

munchlax.name: Snorlax
munchlax.blurb: Snorlax’s cast-iron stomach can be put to work reviving polluted brownfields into fertile farmland. However, they are tremendous pests near humans: they overturn dumpsters, break into landfills, and terrorize picnics. Food trucks can’t be insured against Snorlax.

articuno.name: Articuno
articuno.blurb: Tracking Articuno flight patterns is an important responsibility of any weather prediction agency. Disaster weather relief squads will sometimes request help from an Articuno to weaken hurricanes before they demolish shorelines.

articuno.name: Galarian Articuno
articuno.blurb: This Articuno is a master of illusions and psychic power, but lacks creativity. Because of its ego, Articuno only thinks of itself and won’t make visions of anything else. A vision of this Articuno in your dreams was once considered a portent of disaster.

zapdos.name: Zapdos
zapdos.blurb: The lightning that strikes in the presence of Zapdos is rumored to reveal secrets: uncovering treasure, ruining facades, and illuminating dark activities. Flocks have been reported soaring through the ozone layer, repairing it with ionizing discharge.

zapdos.name: Galarian Zapdos
zapdos.blurb: Many Trainers set out to prove their power by challenging this Zapdos, but they come home in tears. Only some cry from defeat: if Zapdos considers a Trainer truly unworthy, it runs away and never battles them at all.

moltres.name: Moltres
moltres.blurb: Every few years, Moltres from around the world flock together to circumnavigate the globe. This causes strange weather where they pass, such as rain in deserts and droughts in wet areas. Some call this event “El Pájarito”.

moltres.name: Galarian Moltres
moltres.blurb: Many myths about Yveltal are actually about this Moltres. Its fire never burns wood, iron, or dust: it’s only the living that suffers from Moltres’ wrath.

dratini.name: Dratini
dratini.blurb: A Dratini living in a well is a sign of good luck and protection for the land the well irrigates. They only like certain coins that are tossed in for wishes, and will climb up and spit out the others.

dratini.name: Dragonair
dratini.blurb: Dragonair lairs hold piles of sea glass they hoard for unknown reasons. They aren’t possessive, freely giving them to peaceful visitors. Dragonair don’t tolerate other aquatic trash, either dumping it on beaches or leaving to find new homes if there’s too much for them.

dratini.name: Dragonite
dratini.blurb: Dragonite was thought to have lost Dragonair’s ability to control the weather, but instead they focus their powers to fly through the air more efficiently. When angered, they invert that focus to unleash typhoon winds and tsunami waves.

mewtwo.name: Mewtwo
mewtwo.blurb: Mewtwo aren’t considered roving disasters because they only battle those they deem worthy. “The Mewtwo Curse” describes their tendency to ambush Trainers who have become famous for their battle skills, especially newfound Champions.

mew.name: Mew
mew.blurb: Mew’s mysteriousness makes it an endless source of pseudoscientific theories. Some researchers try to predict new Pokémon species by analyzing Mew’s genome, while others claim that Mew is a living manifestion of genetic memory, recording new species as they develop.

chikorita.name: Chikorita
chikorita.blurb: Wild Chikorita live in tightly-knit packs. They seek out partially-shaded habitats and position themselves in a special way — as the sun moves across the sky, it falls on the Chikorita whose turn it is to keep watch. These dozing packs look like fairy rings at a glance.

chikorita.name: Bayleef
chikorita.blurb: The fighting spirit spurred by their buds’ scent means newly evolved Bayleef have trouble relating to their former Chikorita pack. Lone Bayleef often find other rough-playing Pokémon as friends, forming odd symbiotic relationships.

chikorita.name: Meganium
chikorita.blurb: Many have tried to use Meganium’s scent for perfume or medicine, but the fragrance quickly fades. Meganium are highly effective Safari Zone perimeter guards, soothing the protected Pokémon near the boundaries.

cyndaquil.name: Cyndaquil
cyndaquil.blurb: Cyndaquil fur is mostly silicon fibers, like asbestos. Clothing made from the shed hairs is durable and fire-resistant. New Trainers often worry about their Cyndaquil eating dirt, but it’s perfectly fine — that’s how they get more silicon for their coat.

cyndaquil.name: Quilava
cyndaquil.blurb: Quilava confuse their foes and prey alike by jumping and twisting in midair in a disorientating way. Particularly energetic displays have them use their backdraft abilities to gain lift and twist around even more ferociously.

cyndaquil.name: Typhlosion
cyndaquil.blurb: Unlike most Fire-Types, Typhlosion are excellent swimmers. Combined with their running and climbing talents, they thrive almost anywhere. A key warning sign for are trees or rocks with scorched surfaces and embedded sulfur quills, from Typhlosion scratching its back on them.

totodile.name: Totodile
totodile.blurb: If you find a cluster of eggs in swamp reeds, beware! Not only can newborn Totodile bite through a coconut, but their parents never stray far from the nest. Totodile often invade garden ponds and make nuisances of themselves.

totodile.name: Croconaw
totodile.blurb: Fishhooks made from discarded Croconaw teeth are of the highest quality. Stories claim such hooks can land even the orneriest Gyarados — if you would want that.

totodile.name: Feraligatr
totodile.blurb: When pressed, Feraligatr lower to all fours and slam their powerful tail against the ground. In a chase, these Pokémon reach speeds of 40mph — only briefly, but often long enough. When not aggravated, they can be peaceful and serene beyond their fierce appearance.

sentret.name: Sentret
sentret.blurb: Sentret use the conspicuous ring on their stomachs to signal other Sentret outside earshot. History is full of would-be inventors that tried to patent a Sentret semaphore system, but the Pokémon are just too distractable.

sentret.name: Furret
sentret.blurb: Furret prefer hunting in tall grass, dazzling prey with their stripes flashing between the blades. In urban environments, they run up water spouts and wriggle into any opening. Trained Furret used to be kept quite busy as chimney sweeps.

hoothoot.name: Hoothoot
hoothoot.blurb: Areas with Hoothoot were slow to invent mechanical timekeeping, because they used the Pokémon instead. The invention of clocks tends to follow the discovery that scattering coffee beans will throw off every Hoothoot around — a classic wartime tactic.

hoothoot.name: Noctowl
hoothoot.blurb: Noctowl historically nest in clock towers. Modern construction reveals they prefer anywhere with rhythmic sounds, so they also roost near generators, air-conditioners, and other industrial noise pollutants.

ledyba.name: Ledyba
ledyba.blurb: Ledyba’s wing coverings — or “elytra” — buckle and crumple under crush force, but their perfect roundness and smooth surface deflects projectiles without a scratch. An ancient military tactic is the wall of overlapping shields, inspired by Ledyba clusters.

ledyba.name: Ledian
ledyba.blurb: Ecologists pay close attention to Ledian migrations. They move when faced with weather changes, pollution, or invasive species — Ledian’s lack of battle prowess means any other species counts as invasive, alerting ecologists to the movement of harder-to-detect Pokémon.

spinarak.name: Spinarak
spinarak.blurb: Spinarak that live around humans learn that their face-patterns can be scrunched to get reactions out of people. Some make angry faces to discourage intruders, while others figure out how to wink for treats. Trained Spinarak can become almost as expressive as real faces.

spinarak.name: Ariados
spinarak.blurb: The horn on Ariados and Spinarak’s heads is venomless and rarely used to attack. Instead, it may have developed to look similar to their spinnerets, making it easier to confuse their heads with their abdomens.

chinchou.name: Chinchou
chinchou.blurb: Chinchou schools produce enough electromagnetic disturbance to disrupt undersea communications cables, but are also breathtaking sights that draw tourists. Their feet developed to walk on the ocean floor and are too stubby to use on land.

chinchou.name: Lanturn
chinchou.blurb: Trained Lanturn escort deepsea divers to provide light and advance warning. They sense movement through their electric fields further than their light can reach. Other Water Pokémon know Lanturn’s friendly appearance hides a super-effective viciousness.

togepi.name: Togepi
togepi.blurb: It is unknown how Togepi survive in the wild long enough to evolve. Theories span from secret poison secretions, to joining egg clutches of other Pokémon. Togepi’s rarity means whatever the method is, it must not work very well.

togepi.name: Togetic
togepi.blurb: Togetic are hard to train. They dislike shouted commands and respond poorly to the heightened emotions of battle. But with a positive attitude and patience, they can grow to adore the feelings of triumph, pride, and respect from well-fought battles.

togepi.name: Togekiss
togepi.blurb: Togekiss’ home region is unknown, as they drop eggs wherever they visit. They consider these eggs to be gifts to the surrounding residents, perhaps not even realizing the eggs will hatch.

natu.name: Natu
natu.blurb: Unlike most small birds, Natu rarely flock. But when they do, they swarm entire routes. It is thought this is because when only a few congregate, it’s too easy for all of them to become locked into staring contests with each other.

natu.name: Xatu
natu.blurb: Xatu’s constant staring and inaction makes it an irresistible target for humans to project meaning onto. Is it seized by existential dread, calm with foreknowledge, serene with its fate, biding its time, saving its energy, or distracted by its visions? Maybe it’s just lazy.

mareep.name: Mareep
mareep.blurb: As thunderstorms brew, Mareep wool expands enough to lift their hooves off the ground. Mareep shepards carry them to safety before storm winds send them bouncing across the countryside.

mareep.name: Flaaffy
mareep.blurb: The tail bulb is made of conductive layers suffused with oil, forming a natural capacitor that concentrates its charge into an electric blast. Wool always builds up the same charge polarity, so members of this family will violently repel each other when unloaded from transport.

mareep.name: Ampharos
mareep.blurb: Without wool, Ampharos instead stores its electricity as a charge differential between the “gems” on its head and tail. It brings them together for its trademark brightness, forming a powerful arc lamp.

azurill.name: Azurill
azurill.blurb: Azurill love to play in water, but can’t swim yet. If swept up in a current, Azurill can only wait to wash ashore somewhere else.

azurill.name: Marill
azurill.blurb: Marill’s buoyant ball lets it swim without drowning, but can be a vulnerability if left alone. Tyrogues that see the ball are known to snatch it and use Marill as exercise equipment.

azurill.name: Azumarill
azurill.blurb: Azumarill’s constant diving sometimes leads to a power that dwarfs other Pokémon in the area. It is said that nature photographers would rather swim through a river filled with Feraligatrs than Azumarill.

bonsly.name: Bonsly
bonsly.blurb: Bonsly aren’t very good at mimicking yet, but they try anyway. Unlike Sudowoodo, who stands perfectly still, Bonsly begins to shake after just a couple seconds. They like to hide in rock gardens and bonsai “orchards” where their potted appearance blends in.

bonsly.name: Sudowoodo
bonsly.blurb: Lesser known than their weakness to water is Sudowoodo’s weakness to flattery. If you think a tree may be fake, compliment it, then see if it blushes.

hoppip.name: Hoppip
hoppip.blurb: If you hold a Hoppip by the leaves, its body will spin around. They love this for some reason. Their airborne lifestyle precludes a root system, so they eat dirt whenever they get the chance.

hoppip.name: Skiploom
hoppip.blurb: Skiploom rise and fall in waves on partially cloudy days. They float high in sun, but sink as clouds pass overhead. Their flattened ears provide greater air control, but as they raise an ear in the direction of sudden noises, they aileron roll away from them.

hoppip.name: Jumpluff
hoppip.blurb: Jumpluff’s pre-evolutions had long tails to create drag and stop them from floating too quickly, but Jumpluff’s shorter tail serves as a rudder. They careen into anything when spoiling for a fight, but still make good pets as they’re too light to injure children with the collision.

aipom.name: Aipom
aipom.blurb: While the tail excels at manipulation, it’s not very sensitive. If an Aipom wants to closely feel something, it smushes its face into it. They greatly appreciate gloves as tail warmers in cold weather. Aipom gangs chain their tails together to lower themselves down and steal things.

aipom.name: Ambipom

evolves.by: Know Double Hit and level up

aipom.blurb: Ambipom are a real menace if a pack evolves near a city. They work together to steal food off vendors’ stands, eating them casually where the store owners can’t reach. They’ll also steal anything that looks interesting, which is everything to a curious monkey.

sunkern.name: Sunkern
sunkern.blurb: Sunkern is not blessed with natural strengths, but is endlessly competitive. If watered with enough Aprijuice, they can keep up with even the stiffest competition. Otherwise, they perform a vital role at the bottom of the food web.

sunkern.name: Sunflora
sunkern.blurb: Folktales say Sunflora always faces the sun, but studies show they point wherever they like. This may have to do with how they always keep their eyes shut to avoid damage from sun exposure, and the poor awareness that results from this decision.

yanma.name: Yanma
yanma.blurb: On hot days, open-air restaurants put out plants that attract Yanma, so the wind from their hovering cools off patrons. Their flight control is so stable, they can stay still in gusts up to 30mph!

yanma.name: Yanmega

evolves.by: Know Ancient Power and level up

yanma.blurb: The only real threat to wild Yanmega is other Yanmega. They are rare due to battling each other to the finish, leaving only one in any jungle. If a Yanmega is captured by a Trainer, nearby Yanma often evolve as if they’d been waiting for an opportunity.

wooper.name: Wooper
wooper.blurb: Wooper wander everywhere during heavy rain. They’re omnipresent during monsoon season and inadverdantly migrate en masse during flash floods and mudslides. They’re a crucial inhabitant in swamps, stirring up bottom layers to avoid dangerous gas buildup.

wooper.name: Quagsire
wooper.blurb: Quagsire’s eyes are no better than Wooper’s, as they spend most of their time in murky, muddy water. Wooper’s feathery gills sense vibrations instead, but Quagsire doesn’t even have that much. It’s possible that Quagsire are totally blind, but don’t care.

murkrow.name: Murkrow
murkrow.blurb: Murkrow bring bad luck — if you see one, you will be visited by a smelly bird with kleptomaniac tendencies. Trainers who can overlook that find a smart and curious companion. Reward them with sequins for effective training.

murkrow.name: Honchkrow
murkrow.blurb: If pest control wants to disperse a Murkrow gang, all they need to do is beat the boss. When Honchkrow faints, Murkrow suddenly lose their nerve and fly away. The absolute fear that Honchkrow causes in its gang transfers to whoever beats it.

misdreavus.name: Misdreavus
misdreavus.blurb: After dark, amusement parks let Trainers catch the Misdreavus that infest roller coasters and other thrill rides. Haunted houses have strict rules against catching them on premise.

misdreavus.name: Mismagius
misdreavus.blurb: Mismagius still loves to cause fear, but now prefers the kind caused by actual danger. They tend to settle in old houses, where ‘accidents’ become more and more frequent.

unown.name: Unown
unown.blurb: Unown rotate their bodies to always be right-side-up to onlookers — even if the Unown’s eye is pointing away from them. When together, they also instinctively align themselves according to their viewer’s writing system, but they’re powerfully confused by multilingual observers.

wynaut.name: Wynaut
wynaut.blurb: Wynaut toys were once intensely popular, always getting back up no matter how many times you pushed them over. After children tried this on real Wynauts, the toy was banned.

wynaut.name: Wobbuffet
wynaut.blurb: Wobuffet that wander into urban areas squeeze themselves into unlikely places such as vents, elevator shafts, and crawl spaces. They then plague inhabitants with incidental cries of assent in response to overheard sentences.

girafarig.name: Girafarig
girafarig.blurb: If the back end catches a glimpse of the front, it usually wastes several minutes trying to catch and bite it. It’s best not to approach Girafarig that you see slowly rotating backwards, as they’re usually pretty annoyed.

pineco.name: Pineco
pineco.blurb: Pineco infestations require full evacuations and specially-trained relocators. Forests with dense populations have little old growth, and sound like enormous popcorn kettles during inclement weather.

pineco.name: Forretress
pineco.blurb: When Forretress think they are alone, they roll merrily through the dirt, using magnetism to pick up iron in the soil. Foundries and workshops keep them on staff to clean the floor at night.

dunsparce.name: Dunsparce
dunsparce.blurb: Dunsparce don’t seem to have predators — the usual suspects react to it with bafflement. Enterprising art dealers pour molten metal into abandoned Dunsparce nests, then excavate the results and sell them as highly abstract sculpture.

gligar.name: Gligar
gligar.blurb: Gligar uses its tongue to sense air currents, then glides on them to extend its airtime. Its sensitivity heightens when fed spicy food — Gligar that figure this out break into buildings to burgle their hot sauce or spicy seasonings.

gligar.name: Gliscor
gligar.blurb: Gliscor’s teeth chatter when it wants to use echolocation to find prey in the night. To untrained ears, this just sounds like the rustling of trees in the wind. It picks off prey so quietly that nearby Pokémon don’t even realize it happened half the time.

snubbull.name: Snubbull
snubbull.blurb: Official Safety Advisory for what to do in case of Snubbull attack: ignore it until it goes away.

snubbull.name: Granbull
snubbull.blurb: When its mouth is closed, its lower fangs obscure its vision. Granbull that are inspecting their surroundings have their mouths hang open, appearing flabbergasted by new locations.

qwilfish.name: Qwilfish
qwilfish.blurb: The best way to discourage swimming, fishing, boating, and other human activity in a body of water is to introduce Qwilfish to it.

evolves.by: Know Barb Barrage and level up

shuckle.name: Shuckle
shuckle.blurb: Shuckle shells are so sturdy that material engineers have their own version of “lead into gold” — how to mold cast-off Shuckle shells into useful shapes? Unfortunately, so far they’ve only managed ugly vases and lawn ornaments.

heracross.name: Heracross
heracross.blurb: If a Heracross thinks a challenge is beneath it, it refuses to fight. Instead, it uses its giant horn to launch the offending Pokémon away like a catapult.

sneasel.name: Sneasel
sneasel.blurb: Sneasel are incredibly loyal, often stealing items to give to friends and loved ones. For this reason, they are a favorite Pokémon for thieves.

sneasel.name: Weavile
sneasel.blurb: The Combee Scouts Guidebook showcases over twenty different carvings left by Weavile. These carvings can lead Hikers to safe havens and food stashes — or ambushes if they don’t read carefully.

teddiursa.name: Teddiursa
teddiursa.blurb: Teddiursa often wander into dangerous situations while exploring or playing. Travelers beware: wild Teddiursa are rarely unsupervised.

teddiursa.name: Ursaring
teddiursa.blurb: Ursaring take it upon themselves to mind any unsupervised children, sometimes going as far as taking the child back to its den. Domestic Ursaring make very good babysitters for this reason, but sometimes get confused about who the child’s actual parents are.

slugma.name: Slugma
slugma.blurb: Slugma migrate en masse along the lava flows of active volcanoes, sometimes to such an extent that the lava appears to flow backward. Every volcanic settlement has a superstition for this phenomenon, but whether that superstition is good or bad varies.

slugma.name: Magcargo
slugma.blurb: The hotter their surroundings, the quicker and more fluid Magcargo become. While it’s hard to conduct intelligence tests near active volcanos, ancecdotal evidence suggests that they even become smarter at high temperatures.

swinub.name: Swinub
swinub.blurb: Groups of hungry Swinub are known to swarm camps in the early morning, consuming every scrap of food nearby before leaving. Hikers call this event a “Swinub Avalanche.”

swinub.name: Piloswine
swinub.blurb: Piloswine’s tusks evolved to dig in dirt and snow. These tusks and their excellent sense of smell make them valued members of avalanche rescue teams.

swinub.name: Mamoswine

evolves.by: Know Ancient Power and level up

swinub.blurb: Early humans started their children with Grass, Water, or Fire Pokémon as partners to make sure they always had an advantage on Mamoswine. In Sinnoh, Mamoswine is respected as a spirit of the mountain, and never battled if it can be avoided.

corsola.name: Corsola
corsola.blurb: In calm, secluded seas, Corsola grow to tremendous sizes. A classic sailor’s tale is a Corsola the size of a reef, moving across the seafloor to foul ships and ruin maps.

corsola.name: Galarian Corsola
corsola.blurb: Although the seas around Galar support other life, efforts to reintroduce Corsola to their beaches end in failure. Occultists believe reintroduction will fail until the ghostly Corsola hear an apology, but Pokéologists reject the theory.

corsola.name: Cursola
corsola.blurb: Although Cursola’s ectoplasm protects its body, there’s even more danger if you touch the real core. When a Pokémon touches Cursola’s real body, their fates are said to twist together. Cursola will ruin its own day afterward just to spite the one that hurt it.

remoraid.name: Remoraid
remoraid.blurb: Remoraid are weak swimmers, instead attaching to Mantine to hitchhike across the open ocean. In return, Remoraid use their powerful water gun to snipe anything it deems a threat to its chosen Mantine.

remoraid.name: Octillery
remoraid.blurb: Areas with high Mantine populations statistically also have aggressive Octillery waiting to ambush trainers. Recent studies have shown these aggressive Octillery are newly evolved, attacking Trainers to find a new partner after leaving Mantine behind.

delibird.name: Delibird
delibird.blurb: Delibird share bird Pokémon’s typical fascination with collecting interesting objects, but give them away instead of hoarding them. Delibird that move into gardens or pebble beaches become beloved neighbors, but those living near garbage dumps are popular only with Trubbish.

mantyke.name: Mantyke
mantyke.blurb: Mantine only raise Mantyke for a short time, foisting it off to a school of Remoraid after about a week. If Mantyke doesn’t care for the Remoraid, it simply swims off on its own in search of another. It gets along best with Trainers whose faces resemble its back.

mantyke.name: Mantine
mantyke.blurb: Squadrons of Mantine can get so massive that they can be seen from space. Boat trips promise to find these squadrons for tourists’ entertainment, but they’re usually staged.

skarmory.name: Skarmory
skarmory.blurb: If a Skarmory gets too hot, it produces a magnetic field strong enough to disrupt compasses, magnetize nearby metals, and attract nearby Steel-Types.

houndour.name: Houndour
houndour.blurb: Young Houndour may mistake any skull in low visibility for a pack member. This results in the Houndour calling out to it until another Pokémon (or its Trainer) comes to console it.

houndour.name: Houndoom
houndour.blurb: Houndoom are quick-tempered and extremely territorial. Firefights between packs are so massive that they have been spotted as far as 5 miles away.

phanpy.name: Phanpy
phanpy.blurb: When Phanpy headbutt, they cover their eyes with their ears and run face-first into their target. This often causes them to miss, as they can no longer see where they’re going.

phanpy.name: Donphan
phanpy.blurb: Donphan herds travel between watering holes by all rolling together at once. If you find yourself on a path where wild Pokémon refuse to tread, and there are trenches surrounding you, you have found yourself in great danger.

stantler.name: Stantler
stantler.blurb: Stantler uses its horns to generate psychic energy from background radiation. The higher the radiation, the stronger its attacks.

evolves.by: Know Psyshield Bash and level up

smeargle.name: Smeargle
smeargle.blurb: The hat-like shape of a Smeargle’s head will sometimes reflect the home regions of its parents. Smeargle sporting baseball caps have recently been spotted in the Unova region.

miltank.name: Miltank
miltank.blurb: Some ranches claim to naturally imbue their Miltank milk with specific vitamins and minerals. These ranches charge outrageous prices, with the justification that their milk can substitute for Ability Enhancers.

raikou.name: Raikou
raikou.blurb: Legends say the first Raikou appeared when lightning struck a Jolteon wandering the great plains with its master. Upon realizing it had died and left its master stranded, the Jolteon’s spirit revolted with such force that it returned to its body and was reborn into Raikou.

entei.name: Entei
entei.blurb: Any volcanic town free of corruption is rumored to have the protection of a Great Entei. These Entei are said to protect the town from eruptions and promise a fiery end to all outsiders the Entei deems unworthy.

suicune.name: Suicune
suicune.blurb: It is thought that the first Suicune was born from an iceberg that broke from one of the great glaciers of the north. Part of that glacier is said to still be present inside the giant crystal that rests on Suicune’s head.

larvitar.name: Larvitar
larvitar.blurb: Larvitar are so good at navigating in low visibility that cave towns will send them out to rescue lost travelers and lead them to safety.

larvitar.name: Pupitar
larvitar.blurb: The dirt and rock a Pupitar consumed as a Larvitar determine the thickness, color, and shape of its outer shell. It is rumored that if a Larvitar eats a mountain’s worth of gems, it will evolve into a Pupitar with a crystalline shell.

larvitar.name: Tyranitar
larvitar.blurb: Tyranitar draws its massive power from the Pupitar husk visible in its belly. This husk creates so much energy that a Tyranitar’s internal temperature is over 800 degrees. The husk also allows Tyranitar to eat radioactive minerals, its favorite food.

lugia.name: Lugia
lugia.blurb: Sailors tell tales of a giant bird with hand-like wings and glowing eyes. Those who saw blue eyes say the bird saved them from the worst storms of their lives, while those who saw red claim to be lucky to have escaped at all.

ho-oh.name: Ho-Oh
ho-oh.blurb: A single feather from Ho-Oh’s tail is said to bring great fortune to anyone lucky enough to possess it. A feather acquired unjustly, though, will bring nothing but bad luck until it is returned.

celebi.name: Celebi
