celebi.blurb: Monks tell of a lush forest with crystal-clear water and every fruit imaginable, untouched by wind and time. They say this is the first forest created by Celebi, and if you’re lucky, you may catch a glimpse of the legendary Pokémon playing among its trees.

treecko.name: Treecko
treecko.blurb: A wild Treecko is a warrior only concerned with protecting its territory and the Pokémon inside it. If you enter a Treecko’s territory uninvited, prepare for battle.

treecko.name: Grovyle
treecko.blurb: Grovyle are valued for their ability to navigate the forest. A Grovyle’s memory is so accurate, it can see a tree once and remember its exact location.

treecko.name: Sceptile
treecko.blurb: Wild Sceptile grow very attached to their territory, often refusing to flee in the face of imminent destruction. If a disaster does occur, a Sceptile works overtime until its forest is completely restored.

torchic.name: Torchic
torchic.blurb: Torchic’s incredible power combined with its enthusiasm make it a great Pokémon for trainers who are willing to get their hands dirty — or burned. Torchic have very poor aim, but with the right training they are unstoppable.

torchic.name: Combusken
torchic.blurb: Combusken can run for an extraordinarily long time without tiring, and it does so every day it can. A Combusken that does not get enough exercise will become restless, irritable, and loud until it can continue its self-imposed training.

torchic.name: Blaziken
torchic.blurb: Blaziken are only interested in worthy opponents, and will go to great lengths to find them. If a wild Blaziken is on the prowl, every territorial Pokémon in the region is in danger.

mudkip.name: Mudkip
mudkip.blurb: Mudkip eggs can wash up on riversides or beaches. River Mudkip spend more time on land than their beach counterparts, tracking mud all over the place. This makes the soil especially fertile, so Grass-Types rarely battle them.

mudkip.name: Marshtomp
mudkip.blurb: Beach Marshtomp stake their territory on the shore where the tide goes back and forth. They love to feed on Water-Types that get stranded when the tide gets low.

mudkip.name: Swampert
mudkip.blurb: Swampert live wherever they please, digging up underground streams if there isn’t already a water source nearby. If a river or beach isn’t muddy enough for them, they’ll change the current by hurling boulders around.

poochyena.name: Poochyena
poochyena.blurb: Poochyena are a popular starter for children who aren’t ready for Pokémon battling. Poochyena’s cowardice means it won’t provoke fights even if it finds something else in the yard, instead running around with the child until both are too exhausted to cause trouble.

poochyena.name: Mightyena
poochyena.blurb: Collectors gasp at the mention of a gold-furred Mightyena. Its slick hair and bold colors make it a favorite to win any Contest — to the point where it has been banned in minor leagues. This rare color is why Mightyena is on the Poached Species list, despite being quite common.

zigzagoon.name: Zigzagoon
zigzagoon.blurb: Zigzagoon show no fear of humans and will wander into towns. If you wish to remove Zigzagoon from your yard without a battle, grab a stone and pour strongly-scented tea on it. Throw the stone out of your yard, and Zigzagoon will run right after it. Unscented rocks work too.

zigzagoon.name: Linoone
zigzagoon.blurb: When city planners want to build a new road or install telephone poles, they will often release a Linoone and track how it runs over the area. Linoone will find the routes with the least amount of obstacles and turns, making for more efficient designs.

zigzagoon.name: Galarian Zigzagoon
zigzagoon.blurb: Zigzagoon break into Galarian concerts so frequently that some venues now advertise themselves as “Zigzagoon-friendly”. Teenagers looking for their first Pokémon will buy a ticket just to try and capture a friend with attitude.

zigzagoon.name: Galarian Linoone
zigzagoon.blurb: It’s not unusual to see squads of Linoone roaming Galarian streets after dark. These Pokémon take pleasure in destroying public property and are thought of as a menace, but they run away if they see even a small child nearby.

zigzagoon.name: Obstagoon
zigzagoon.blurb: Wild Linoone can’t evolve until they learn to control their destructive impulses. Obstagoon love to crash spotlit venues and scream at a moment’s notice, but never attack first. Wild Obstagoon are even known to protect people from their own herds if things get too rowdy.

wurmple.name: Wurmple
wurmple.blurb: They say you can tell if your Wurmple will evolve into a Silcoon or Cascoon based on its behavior: if it stares blankly at most objects, eats any food without reservation, or sits on the side of a tree without moving for hours, it will definitely evolve into one of the two.

wurmple.name: Silcoon
wurmple.blurb: The protective covering around Silcoon is, in fact, silk! Every spring, gardeners harvest the discarded Silcoon husks left behind by evolution. The husks are dropped into boiling water, and can then be unraveled into long continuous threads.

wurmple.name: Beautifly
wurmple.blurb: It is theorized that Florge’s lack of a Grass-Typing was an evolutionary defense against Beautifly’s attacks. The two are bitter rivals, and fight day and night for control of a flower field.

wurmple.name: Cascoon
wurmple.blurb: Cascoon’s protective shell is more brittle than Silcoon’s, dissolving in boiling water. If somebody wants to sell you “Silcoon” husks, check the color. It is still possible to make fabric from a Cascoon husk, but much more difficult.

wurmple.name: Dustox
wurmple.blurb: Dustox are skittish, using their natural camouflage to hide in trees as autumn leaves. This would be an effective strategy if they were not also known for eating all the foliage around them, making large bare areas over their hiding spots.

lotad.name: Lotad
lotad.blurb: Water gardens employ Lotad as paths between islands to not break up pleasant nature with unsightly bridges. Small Pokémon that get on it are startled when it suddenly moves.

lotad.name: Lombre
lotad.blurb: Children tell nasty rumors about Lombre, from stealing Mudbray and ruining soba noodles to drowning anybody who gets too close. Nobody knows the source of these rumors, but they make the rounds in nearly every school.

lotad.name: Ludicolo
lotad.blurb: Ludicolo love birdsong. Wild Ludicolo may ‘capture’ birds they especially like as personal music boxes, feeding the bird in exchange for on-demand songs.

seedot.name: Seedot
seedot.blurb: Seedot love to laugh at lost Trainers, shaking in the trees. This rattling was feared as angry spirits of the forest who wanted the Trainer to leave. Now Trainers still fear the noise, but it is because Seedots will Explode out of shock if they fall from laughing too hard.

seedot.name: Nuzleaf
seedot.blurb: Nuzleaf make their homes in the hollows of old trees, stuffing the trunks with leaves. It is considered polite to leave an offering of clothing here to guarantee safe passage. Trainers who disrupt these homes find themselves hopelessly lost.

seedot.name: Shiftry
seedot.blurb: If a wandering Shiftry makes its home in a city park, the area comes under special designation. Landscaping is halted, battling is banned, and littering is enforced as a misdemeanor. These new rules are harsh, but necessary for the safety of the community.

taillow.name: Taillow
taillow.blurb: Although Taillow nest in small families, when the young leave the nest they join flocks that can number in the hundreds. These flocks are dangerous, as Taillow has no fear of guard Pokémon and will not hesitate to wipe out entire outdoor markets.

taillow.name: Swellow
taillow.blurb: The Complete Thief’s Handbook has a chapter dedicated to Swellow falconry. Swellow are trained to swipe small objects from unsuspecting victims in a dive, then fly away before they can be battled. If the Swellow picks up a Klefki, the thief is encouraged to leave it behind.

wingull.name: Wingull
wingull.blurb: Wingull is seen in nearly every region, its signature wingspan shape considered a global symbol. It is said that even if you cannot speak the same language as another, you can still bond over Wingull.

wingull.name: Pelipper
wingull.blurb: Although Wingull is a good luck charm for fishermen, Pelipper is a dangerous sight due to the storms that follow. There is a saying amongst sailors: “Wingull above, seas of love. Pelipper up top, time to stop.”

ralts.name: Ralts
ralts.blurb: Ralts cannot filter emotional input from other creatures yet, and prefer to stay alone to avoid being overwhelmed by other Pokémon’s desire to battle. Despite this, they are the only member of their evolutionary line to approach Trainers in the wild.

ralts.name: Kirlia
ralts.blurb: Kirlia dancing competitions have been a tradition in Hoenn for centuries, and have set the bar for global standards. Trainers travel from all over the world to participate, bringing in styles and regional variants that don’t interact anywhere else.

ralts.name: Gardevoir
ralts.blurb: A Kirlia evolves when it discards its own self preservation to protect something else. Gardevoir’s responsibility can grow attached to nearly anything: Gardevoir have been seen protecting their Trainers, their nests, and even a local Bob’s Your Uncle establishment.

ralts.name: Gallade
ralts.blurb: In old films, watch carefully when the action starts. Directors used Gallade as stunt doubles during swordfights, producing dazzling scenes that fooled absolutely nobody. When the character starts swinging their elbow at their opponent, you know the switch has been made.

surskit.name: Surskit
surskit.blurb: Surskit Syrup was a popular drink ingredient until the last decade, when new regulations deemed the process of repeatedly startling Surskits abusive. Raids on criminal organizations now commonly retrieve cans of Surskit Soda, but the source of this product has yet to be traced.

surskit.name: Masquerain
surskit.blurb: Masquerain feeds on prey hiding underwater in peaceful ponds. Its four lower wings can balance on the water’s surface without a single ripple, leaving smaller Bug-Types none the wiser until it is too late.

shroomish.name: Shroomish
shroomish.blurb: Shroomish love walking in the rain, sipping at puddles with their feet. Lines of Shroomish march along roadside streams, finding themselves stranded in urban areas when the sun finally shines.

shroomish.name: Breloom
shroomish.blurb: Breloom are one of the most sought-after personal trainers for Martial Artists. Their pride is dangerous, however, as Breloom will correct any flaws in copying their technique via demonstration.

slakoth.name: Slakoth
slakoth.blurb: Theoretically omnivorous, Slakoth rarely eat anything but plants and lice in the wild. They are happy with any food a Trainer gives them, but usually fall asleep with it half-eaten in their mouths. A single cracker is more than enough for their daily calorie needs.

slakoth.name: Vigoroth
slakoth.blurb: Vigoroth’s endless energy makes it a public menace, especially because they always appear in herds without warning. Studies have tried to do studies on what makes a lazy Pokémon like Slakoth evolve, but any promising research has been cut short by sudden violent tragedy.

slakoth.name: Slaking
slakoth.blurb: Slaking Curling is rapidly increasing in popularity throughout Hoenn, with simple rules and tense gameplay. Players slide food towards Slaking, hoping to stop as close as possible. If the food touches Slaking or is far enough to make Slaking move, the team loses.

nincada.name: Nincada
nincada.blurb: Because Nincada mostly hide underground from Flying-Types, they are hard to find and capture. But when summer starts, the air fills with emerging Nincada cries to either mate or evolve. If different groups of Nincada synchronize, this sound can become impossible to live with.

nincada.name: Ninjask
nincada.blurb: Ninjask’s association with ninjas is misinterpreted in modern media. Rather than keeping Ninjask by their side, most ninjas use its screaming as a loud distraction far away from their actual target. An adept Ninja can command a Ninjask from over half a mile away.

nincada.name: Shedinja
nincada.blurb:
More mysterious than Shedinja’s sudden appearance is the lack of any wild specimens. The most accepted scientific theory is that Shedinja is the trusted bond between a Nincada and its Trainer possessing its discarded husk.
Pokéfeature: Shedinja’s Max HP is always 1.

whismur.name: Whismur
whismur.blurb: Whismur were thought to imperceptibly murmur, but new research suggests they communicate in tones so high-pitched that people and most Pokémon cannot hear. They drop down to mere “earsplitting” frequencies to boost the distance of their distress signals.

whismur.name: Loudred
whismur.blurb: Loudred are remarkably terrible at hearing — this could be an adaptation to avoid overwhelming their own ears, or it could be that they all quickly deafen themselves.

whismur.name: Exploud
whismur.blurb: Exploud’s auditory system has been completely repurposed to make them even louder. They “hear” by sensing vibrations through their feet and detecting resonances in their windpipes. They do a wonderful baseball organ impression.

makuhita.name: Makuhita
makuhita.blurb: When Makuhita is not training, it loves to collect stones. A Makuhita can spend hours sifting through a rocky route, picking up stones and hurling them away. Martial Artists believe Makuhita is trying to find a stone that will give it enough energy to evolve.

makuhita.name: Hariyama
makuhita.blurb: Hariyama matches are one of the most beloved sports in any region, even recognized by the International Pokéathlon Committee. Hariyama that consistently win become celebrities, much to the lament of their oft-forgotten Trainers.

nosepass.name: Nosepass
nosepass.blurb: Tectonic plates move faster than undisturbed Nosepass. While still excellent companions for wilderness wayfinding, modern life has resulted in Nosepass pointing in unusual directions around power stations, long-haul lines, and other electromagnetic disturbances.

nosepass.name: Probopass
nosepass.blurb: Probopass’ Mini-Noses sense everything the main head does for up to a half mile. Past this, they feel confused and can only make simple actions. When they reunite with their Probopass, everything a Mini-Nose has seen is shown to Probopass.

skitty.name: Skitty
skitty.blurb: Skitty’s face adorns children’s products all over the world, from clothing to sugary treats and school supplies. It is said that a child’s first Pokémon partners are Pikachu and Skitty.

skitty.name: Delcatty
skitty.blurb: Pokéologists thought that Delcatty was solitary and drifted without purpose, but new observations show they form small colonies with communal hunting if enough evolve in an area. These colonies form where no others dwell, and scatter from intruders to rejoin elsewhere.

sableye.name: Sableye
sableye.blurb: Sableye are a favorite of burglars, as their hard claws can dig through a concrete wall in less than half an hour. The Complete Thief’s Handbook states that a Sableye should receive at least a 10% cut of any gems from the heist, or it might run off with the entire haul.

mawile.name: Mawile
mawile.blurb: Mawile’s battle style and life in caves rarely use its eyes, so its sight is rather poor. Mawile instead senses its surroundings using its ‘bangs’. These hollow horns detect vibrations in the air, alerting Mawile to movement within 30 feet.

aron.name: Aron
aron.blurb: Although Aron loves eating ore, it never touches the molted shells of its brethren. Abandoned junkyards and iron mines eventually become littered with shells, luring scavengers.

aron.name: Lairon
aron.blurb: Lairon’s armor is peppered with holes that act as acoustic tunnels when it makes intimidation displays. Opera houses trained Lairon to amplify the sounds of onstage instruments, producing music that can be heard clearly at the highest balconies.

aron.name: Aggron
aron.blurb: Aggron cannot stand Larvitar on their mountains, but give a wide berth to Tyranitar. This may be because Aggron refuses to risk its territory being destroyed in the crossfire.

meditite.name: Meditite
meditite.blurb: Meditite are useful in battle, but demand strong discipline from their Trainers. They are offended if they are given too much food, not supervised when meditating, or recalled from a battle before fainting. Sending Meditite on a Poké Job is also called taking a Medi Vacation.

meditite.name: Medicham
meditite.blurb: Medicham’s large legs store energy as an adaptation to its long fasting periods, but also enhance its kicking power. If Medicham were able to spend all that stored energy in one kick, it could split an island in half.

electrike.name: Electrike
electrike.blurb: Electrike was frequently used in wars, but not for battle. Instead, their lightning-fast movements let them send messages between generals without attracting attention. Every once in a while the messages would burn up from an errant spark, so they eventually got phased out.

electrike.name: Manectric
electrike.blurb: Manectric are collected by wealthy owners for security, but these people rarely train their own Pokémon. Security Manectric are raised to follow orders from whoever gives them treats, but wealthy owners rarely do this personally either.

plusle.name: Plusle
plusle.blurb: Plusle and Minun are a popular choice for parents to give twins as first Pokémon, in the hope that the children learn to work together. Despite initial cries of how the children really wanted a Pikachu, the gambit usually works.

minun.name: Minun
minun.blurb: Plusle and Minun love bothering Charjabug. They interpret its electric attacks as cheering sparks, and follow it everywhere. The magnetic charge Plusle and Minun create between them even sometimes form the conditions for a Charjabug to evolve!

volbeat.name: Volbeat
volbeat.blurb: Volbeat fly around vehicles at night, trying to communicate with the “creature’s” headlights. If a driver does not flash their headlights back in a pattern the Volbeat enjoys, it gets offended and may even attack.

illumise.name: Illumise
illumise.blurb: Illumise’s 200 geometric patterns were recorded in a book now famous in fashion design. These patterns inspired outfits popular with the disaffected youth of the time, but are a bit outdated today.

budew.name: Budew
budew.blurb: Rival gardeners can sabotage each other by planting dormant Budew in the winter. When Budew wakes up in a strange new location, it spreads its toxic pollen everywhere and kills off other plants. Doing this to another gardener risks a lifetime ban from botany contests.

budew.name: Roselia
budew.blurb: Roselia’s body is influenced by its diet, with its flower colors changing daily to reflect its mineral intake. It used to be quite rare to see a purple-petaled Roselia, but domesticated ones have popped up all over after the spread of social media.

budew.name: Roserade
budew.blurb: Filled with dazzling confidence, Roserade travels the land to find the best sunny spots. It chases away other Grass-Types with its poison whips if it finds them annoying, making Roserade a monarch nearly anywhere they go. Except Kanto, for some reason.

gulpin.name: Gulpin
gulpin.blurb: Although wild Gulpin can and will eat anything, domesticated specimens are often picky eaters. Most Gulpin grow to have the same food preferences as their Trainers, to the point that food critics will sometimes send their Gulpin instead of personally attending a restaurant.

gulpin.name: Swalot
gulpin.blurb: Before Muk’s Alolan variant was discovered, Swalot were the number one Pokémon for cleaning up hazardous waste. Murmurs say the harsh Alolan laws on exporting Muk is partially to keep Swalot garbage disposal industries in business.

carvanha.name: Carvanha
carvanha.blurb: Carvanha don’t even get along with Sharpedo. When a Carvanha evolves, it is exiled from its school and forced to move to new territory. Despite this, many exotic fish traders find them to be wonderful pets.

carvanha.name: Sharpedo
carvanha.blurb: Sharpedo are one of the few Pokémon unafraid of Gyarados, hunting the atrocious Pokémon when food is scarce. Because of this, they are considered an important part of ocean ecosystems.

wailmer.name: Wailmer
wailmer.blurb: Wailmer pods have some of the longest migration routes in the world. Merchants looking to sell their wares in distant countries can follow these routes from Galar all the way to Kanto without ever having to travel over land.

wailmer.name: Wailord
wailmer.blurb: Wailord has large floatation sacs on its underside that it fills with water to sink to the lowest depths of the sea, or with hot air to become light enough to leap off the surface of the water. These sacs helped Wailord’s body remain light enough to move when it lived on land.

numel.name: Numel
numel.blurb: Numel is a great partner for campers, sitting still as it heats anything on top its back. Just don’t cook anything the Numel might want to eat, or you’ll find your meal gobbled up when you look away.

numel.name: Camerupt
numel.blurb: Areas Camerupt visit gain rich crops and fertile soil, a veritable paradise for Grass-Types and all the different species that follow. Areas where Camerupt live are barren and unbearable even for some Fire-Types.

torkoal.name: Torkoal
torkoal.blurb: Hoenn brick ovens imitate Torkoal’s shell, soaking up heat and evenly releasing it over hours. This significantly improves the flavor and texture, but the ovens take time to build. Many find it easier to catch a Torkoal and use it instead.

spoink.name: Spoink
spoink.blurb: Spoink lives far from the shore, and is a poor swimmer. How Spoink obtain pearls from Clamperl is a mystery yet to be solved, but recent theory is that Spoink grows the pearl itself. This would explain why Spoink loves to eat sand.

spoink.name: Grumpig
spoink.blurb: Grumpig still loves to bounce on its tail, but only when it thinks nobody is watching. If Grumpig falls asleep, it can start bouncing out of habit. Grumpig owners love to record video of this.

spinda.name: Spinda
spinda.blurb: Spinda who spend time with each other synchronize their steps. Not all Spinda are immune to each other’s movements, so they end up tripping over their own steps. Trainers who mimic Spinda’s teetering report it to be a rewarding bonding experience, until they throw up.

trapinch.name: Trapinch
trapinch.blurb: Trapinch eats small Pokémon that fall into its trap, but awkwardly waits in hiding when anything big blunders in. They are easy prey for Palossand, who absorb Trapinch nests into their body.

trapinch.name: Vibrava
trapinch.blurb: Trapinch’s evolution into Vibrava is so distinct that old textbooks thought them different species. When Pokéologists discovered the two were related, the fact was disputed for another five years.

trapinch.name: Flygon
trapinch.blurb: Flygon’s popularity with Trainers has made their eggs one of the most expensive items on the black market. Many bidders are disappointed when the “Vibrava” that hatch from a purchased Egg evolve into a screaming Yanmega.

cacnea.name: Cacnea
cacnea.blurb: Cacnea’s stubby legs and long arms produce a distinctive jaunty walk. Landscapers use them to aerate lawns with their pointy feet. They’re especially effective at aerating slopes that machines struggle with, since their spines poke holes as they roll down.

cacnea.name: Cacturne
cacnea.blurb: Cacturne stand completely still in the daytime, photosynthesizing energy to outlast prey during their nighttime stakeouts. They are effective as scarecrows, but for a different, more straightforward reason.

swablu.name: Swablu
swablu.blurb: Most love Swablu’s friendliness towards humans, but bakers find them a nuisance. Swablu will casually sit on a baker’s bench and eat all the bread it can, not even moving when threatened by a broom or spraybottle. What it doesn’t eat, it carries off to hoard in the wilderness.

swablu.name: Altaria
swablu.blurb: Altaria flock together for fall and spring migrations. These flocks can reach amazing sizes, but citizens rarely notice, reporting pleasant blue skies with scattered clouds. If the sky stays cloudy for three days with no rain, superstition says you’ve been visited by Altaria’s blessing.

zangoose.name: Zangoose
zangoose.blurb: It is hard to motivate Zangoose against foes other than Seviper, but other snakes provoke a similar response. In fact, if Zangoose catches wind of a snake Pokémon, it is hard to keep it inside its Poké Ball.

seviper.name: Seviper
seviper.blurb: Seviper’s hissy laughter and joyous wriggling seem silly, but are insidious ploys. The constant movement makes it hard to read its next attack, and the distraction gives it time to find a victim’s weak points. When a Seviper decides to attack, the battle is already decided.

lunatone.name: Lunatone
lunatone.blurb: Wild Lunatone spend large amounts of time dormant, waking under the light of the moon. Archaeologists who unearth suspicious statues place them outside on full moon nights, to test whether they’re actually Pokémon.

solrock.name: Solrock
solrock.blurb: At the end of autumn, Solrocks end their aimless wandering and travel to the nearest desert. When they arrive, they bury themselves halfway into the sand and hibernate for the winter. When the Solrock wake at the beginning of spring, the light is visible for miles.

barboach.name: Barboach
barboach.blurb: Barboach’s whiskers are so sensitive they can feel differences in barometric pressure, making them a reliable way for sailors to predict the weather. If Barboach hides deep in its mud, the sun is going to shine strong. If they come up for air, expect a lot of precipitation.

barboach.name: Whiscash
barboach.blurb: Whiscash’s whiskers look soft and fluffy, but they’re very strong. If a Whiscash untwirls its whiskers, it can cause severe injury to a foe. The whiskers are full of nerves, so Whiscash prefers to use its earthquakes as a defense instead.

corphish.name: Corphish
corphish.blurb: Wild Corphish are terrible for the environment, but their hardy nature make cheap farming. They used to be a meal for only poor fishermen and prisoners, but these days sell for absurd prices.

corphish.name: Crawdaunt
corphish.blurb: When people see a Crawdaunt shell in the wild, there’s an immediate search to find the molted creature and drive it out of the area. If the Crawdaunt is captured instead of defeated, the new owner is usually treated as a noble martyr.

baltoy.name: Baltoy
baltoy.blurb: Attempts to recreate the process that brought Claydol to life have failed, and Baltoy destroy toys made in their image. Despite these unanswered questions, Baltoy was voted #1 in Ruin Maniacs Monthly for the last twenty years.

baltoy.name: Claydol
baltoy.blurb: Keep Claydol away from Regirock, Regice, and Registeel. Claydol can communicate with the forbidden workers, and the monsters seem to listen to Claydol’s commands.

lileep.name: Lileep
lileep.blurb: Lileep sway hypnotically to draw prey close. Their eyesight is so poor that they try to devour anything within reach.

lileep.name: Cradily
lileep.blurb: Although Cradily was believed extinct, there have been confirmed sightings off Unovan coasts. Scientific expeditions to the deep sea are funded to discover if Cradily is actually still alive in areas yet explored.

anorith.name: Anorith
anorith.blurb: Anorith’s delicate constitution makes it an expensive pet. Aquariums need a specific temperature and daily minerals, and must be big enough for it to swim around. Most specimens are kept in labs, but some extremely wealthy patrons show off their Anorith “artificial coasts.”

anorith.name: Armaldo
anorith.blurb: Armaldo’s tough armor and powerful pincers should make it an apex predator in wild environments. However, its slow walking speed and loud scales allow most prey to flee before it even gets close. Pokéologists think this is why Armaldo went extinct.

feebas.name: Feebas
feebas.blurb: For some reason, Feebas refuse to live in the same area as Magikarp. Because Magikarp live almost everywhere, this makes Feebas an actually rare catch for fishers. It’s even rarer to see someone brag when they finally show up.

feebas.name: Milotic
feebas.blurb: When Gyarados threatens a town, people pray for Milotic. Milotic uses its hard scales to withstand rampaging Hyper Beams, and swings its serpentine tail to beat Gyarados back to the sea.

castform.name: Castform
castform.blurb: The Hoenn Weather Institute patented the creation process for Castform, keeping it a secret for another twenty years. This caused controversy until it was discovered that Castform can live in the wild and breed without issue.

kecleon.name: Kecleon
kecleon.blurb: Directors are always trying to hire Kecleon for Pokémon Musicals, and audiences adore their color-changing mood swings. Musical Trainers find Kecleon difficult to work with, as it is naturally inclined to vanish away in stage fright.

shuppet.name: Shuppet
shuppet.blurb: Although they feed on negative emotions, Shuppet are especially friendly and love playing with children. With its abilities and disposition, Shuppet is the only licensed therapy Ghost-Type.

shuppet.name: Banette
shuppet.blurb: The book “If You Give a Shuppet a Plush” is a perennial bestseller. Banette’s increasing mischief throughout the book initially sparked a debate on what behavior was alright to depict in children’s literature, but that only made it more popular.

duskull.name: Duskull
duskull.blurb: Duskull is frightening to behold, but ultimately a harmless pest. The worst it does is phasing through fridge doors and eating all the food. When a Duskull does make its way into a fridge, it likes to sit there for a while.

duskull.name: Dusclops
duskull.blurb: Dusclops’ bandages are its cocoon, evolving into Dusknoir naturally after 108 years. The first Pokéologist to witness this phenomenon won an award, but then was mysteriously unable to attend the ceremony.

duskull.name: Dusknoir
duskull.blurb: Dusknoir’s antenna rings when it hears church bells, and it feels compelled to follow the sound. Other Ghost-Types fear Dusknoir’s appearance, but none more than Drifloon. The Balloon Pokémon mysteriously go missing whenever a Dusknoir is in the same area.

tropius.name: Tropius
tropius.blurb: Without a tail, Tropius beat their wings to keep balance while raising and lowering their necks. This makes them look very unstable in the air, and only experienced Trainers can hope to ride one without throwing up.

chingling.name: Chingling
chingling.blurb: Chingling are an important part of many sacred rituals. This gives them a special status in religious circles, and traditionalist towns may even ban battling Chingling. To hear a Chingling walking in the forest is an omen of good luck: follow the sound, and you should find fortune.

chingling.name: Chimecho
chingling.blurb: Chimecho attach to any high underside and chatter if their perch moves. They draw children at fairgrounds and are good omens at construction sites. They’re pests at airfields and wherever they feud with Shuppet over territory.

absol.name: Absol
absol.blurb: Now that Absol’s role is becoming more appreciated, some put up shelters in the wilderness to try and attract them. If you see a doghouse with a long horn on top, leave an offering of beans.

snorunt.name: Snorunt
snorunt.blurb: Snorunt loves to play with humans, taking no offense at having snow thrown at them in snowball fights. If a child happens to throw an ice ball, it sees that as a new game. Children sometimes come home with bruises after playing too hard.

snorunt.name: Glalie
snorunt.blurb: If a Snorunt is mistreated enough, it evolves into Glalie. Glalie flash-freezes anything that looks like a bully, then ignores it. People frozen by Glalie should be thawed as soon as possible, then brought in for questioning.

snorunt.name: Froslass
snorunt.blurb: If you hear singing not of any language in a snowstorm, do not seek it out! It’s Froslass, shrieking over the winds to announce its presence. People who want to cross Froslass mountains wear masks that make them look too ugly for its collection .

spheal.name: Spheal
spheal.blurb: Spheal are the most popular attraction at any aquarium. Natural performers, they roll and bounce endlessly the second an audience is watching. Wary Trainers note: Spheal does the same thing when it sees something it wants to fight.

spheal.name: Sealeo
spheal.blurb: Sealeo mothers hatch eggs on land, and will spend approximately a year nursing her new Spheal pups. A Sealeo mother will leave her pups on the ice to forage alone at least once a month, or whenever an entire pack of Spheal gets to be too much to deal with.

spheal.name: Walrein
spheal.blurb: Only two species challenge Walrein in the wild: Sharpedo and Beartic. Sharpedo will disrupt a Walrein pod without fear, Beartic generally only makes that mistake once.

clamperl.name: Clamperl
clamperl.blurb: Pearl divers tell of sea trenches where hundreds of Clamperl sleep, with just as many pearls to be plucked from the sides of the snoozing pink roe. An area with so many Clamperl would be too deep for humans, so most pay the rumor no attention.

clamperl.name: Huntail
clamperl.blurb: Huntail’s body acts differently on deep sea than on land. A weak swimmer in its own environment, its wriggling becomes effective slithering on dry land or in shallow waters. It is no longer an ambush predator, instead choosing to chase prey down.

clamperl.name: Gorebyss
clamperl.blurb: Wild Gorebyss are cruel hunters, even eating Clamperl if there’s no other food available. Gorebyss’ thin mouth slips between Clamperl’s shell seams, leaving them defenseless.

relicanth.name: Relicanth
relicanth.blurb: Although Relicanth never changes, there are variants. Some Relicanth have different patterns to their tan and brown markings, always centered around the red dot. Treasure hunters think these patterns could be treasure maps.

luvdisc.name: Luvdisc
luvdisc.blurb: DNA sequencing reveals Luvdisc could evolve into Alomomola, but we have yet to discover how. Most Luvdisc owners don’t want them to evolve, so funding is hard to find.

luvdisc.name: Alomomola
luvdisc.blurb: Wild Alomomola are followed at all times by grateful Pokémon, who wish to give thanks for healing them. Not all species Alomomola takes care of get along, so some of these Pokémon just increase its workload.

bagon.name: Bagon
bagon.blurb: Drayden’s Dragon Manual states a Bagon should be hefted above the shoulders and carried about twice daily to simulate the feeling of flying. Bagon weighs nearly a hundred pounds, so Trainers tend to skip this advice.

bagon.name: Shelgon
bagon.blurb: Shelgon barely moves while transforming, but it is still conscious. Trainers who read or talk to their Shelgon report a much faster evolution into Salamence. Whether this is because Shelgon appreciates the company or wants to fly away from the conversation is up to debate.

bagon.name: Salamence
bagon.blurb: Along with its new wings, Salamence’s fire sac becomes capable of taking in vast quantities of oxygen. Pokéologists believe this was a previous attempt to fly that never reached fruition.

beldum.name: Beldum
beldum.blurb: Beldum migrate every season, navigating by the earth’s magnetic field. When Magnetic North drifts, Beldum end up in entirely different regions after a slight change in angle.

beldum.name: Metang
beldum.blurb: Metang generally don’t get along with other Steel-Types, but are most aggressive with members of the Klinklang line. Metang collide with these gears over and over, possibly trying to join the party.

beldum.name: Metagross
beldum.blurb: Metagross is an apex predator, not even fearing urban landscapes. If a Metagross enters a city, officials activate the same permissions to Trainers as a Gigantomax Raid.

regirock.name: Regirock
regirock.blurb: Constantly rebuilding themselves, Regirock never leave their post and never tire. The temples they guard may hide any amount of important knowledge, but the danger to get there is too high to risk.

regice.name: Regice
regice.blurb: Regice that awaken in non-arctic areas are considered an environmental crisis. They freeze their surroundings, drifting over the land to unseal their siblings. They can even freeze the sea, leaving entire fleets frozen in place for days.

registeel.name: Registeel
registeel.blurb: Registeel is docile compared to its brethren, obeying humans even without capture. Wealthy organizations may even employ Registeel. If given contradictory orders, it chooses what to do for itself. This is to be avoided, as Registeel like to solve problems by destroying them.

regieleki.name: Regieleki
regieleki.blurb: The power Regieleki outputs in a day could keep Galar going for a years, but no machine has ever come close to handling its voltage. Even the mightiest Klingklang has fallen when hit with Regieleki’s unbridled electric strength for just a couple seconds.

regidrago.name: Regidrago
regidrago.blurb: Historians found “dragon crystals” for years before Regidrago’s discovery put them into context. These dragon energy materials now sell for horrible amounts on the black market, where rogue archaeologists try to make a “complete” Regidrago.

regigigas.name: Regigigas
regigigas.blurb:
Regigigas’ history is unknown, but its body is scarred. It dwells only in temples hidden deep underground, defeated and broken. Historians cannot figure out if Regigigas fought for or against humanity.
CLASSIFIED UPDATE: This information is not to be shared with the public: new Kalos dig site reports there is more than one Regigigas.

latias.name: Latias
latias.blurb: The home region of Latios and Latias has yet to be discovered, nor the reason they fly all over the world. Scholars of the Eon Pair call it the “last great mystery” of Pokémon. This is patently untrue, but its romanticism has captured many imaginations anyway.

latios.name: Latios
latios.blurb: It is unclear whether Latias and Latios are the same species. Recent scientific theory posits that Latias and Latios are regional variants of each other that only meet when flying, and that other variants may have yet to be discovered.

kyogre.name: Kyogre
kyogre.blurb: Kyogre swims through the deepest parts of the ocean, the red glow from its rings visible for miles through the darkness. It appears on the surface in storms so mighty that no boat escapes unscathed, sailors reportedly quitting their jobs after a mere glimpse.

kyogre.name: Primal Kyogre
kyogre.blurb: Before Hoopa stole the power of the sea, Kyogre’s primal power could erase settlements without even noticing. Trainers took the League Challenge quest to become Champion and try to defeat Kyogre, if only for a while. Even when they succeeded, they rarely came back.

groudon.name: Groudon
groudon.blurb: Groudon swims through magma as if it were water, and digs through solid rock as if it was dust. Volcanoes erupt in its presence, announcing the arrival of a king. Towns where people have supposedly seen Groudon no longer stand.

groudon.name: Primal Groudon
groudon.blurb: Before Hoopa stole the power of the land, Groudon’s presence dried up the earth. Ancient kings and queens tried to control Groudon’s power, but it always ended with the destruction of their kingdom. Time after time, this story repeated until the Sky Pillar appeared.

rayquaza.name: Rayquaza
rayquaza.blurb: Rayquaza flies so high that the sky is no longer blue, appearing as a green comet to people below. It will battle anything that enters its kingdom, and has never lost. When it has prey in its sights, it will chase that prey to the ends of the world.

jirachi.name: Jirachi
jirachi.blurb: Jirachi once granted a king’s wish to end a war, sending him visions of a great weapon in a dream. The weapon was built, and the war ended after but a single use. Jirachi’s eye closed and it slept, satisfied.

deoxys.name: Deoxys
deoxys.blurb:
Inscrutable and nearly unstudiable, Deoxy’s DNA mutates on the fly as dramatically as Ditto’s. Nobody knows why they crash on Earth, or why they seek out other meteors when they land.
Pokéfeature: Deoxys can change forme when it comes into contact with meteorites.

deoxys.name: Deoxys (Attack)
deoxys.blurb: When Deoxys wants to attack, the mass at the end of its tentacles becomes one hundred times denser than near its core. With this power, it could pierce a battleship’s hull.

deoxys.name: Deoxys (Defense)
deoxys.blurb: When Deoxys wants to defend, it pours its body over its core again and again. The resulting form is so hard that you could drive a dump truck into it without a scratch.

deoxys.name: Deoxys (Speed)
deoxys.blurb: When Deoxys wants to move, it sheds all of its matter into ‘propulsion points’ along its body. In this lightweight form, Deoxys could fly around the globe in 12 hours.

turtwig.name: Turtwig
turtwig.blurb: The leaves on Turtwig’s head should be trimmed regularly to be in proper battling form if they’re taken to environments outside their home. In particularly damp biomes, this can take hours. The trimmings make good tea, so it’s not all bad.

turtwig.name: Grotle
turtwig.blurb: Grotle like to dig underground to sleep, only a pair of shrubs protruding from the surface. When these shrubs shake, Grotle knows something interesting is up above. Grotle can even track the branches that fall off for miles without error.

turtwig.name: Torterra
turtwig.blurb: Trainers who fall asleep in quiet forests might wake up in a strange new area with pure water springs. If they look at the tree they slept under, they’ll find it to be a part of Torterra’s back. When Trainers leave these grottos, they never seem to find them again.

chimchar.name: Chimchar
chimchar.blurb: Chimchar swing through the branches of swamp cypress, where the trees are too wet to burn. Chimchar can live their entire lives without needing to spend time on the ground, only hopping down to annoy Pokémon who can’t climb back up after them.

chimchar.name: Monferno
chimchar.blurb: Monferno are a circus staple. They’re taught how to juggle, take tickets, and even cook popcorn over their fiery tails. Some shady circuses also teach Monferno to pickpocket, but most ringmasters condemn the practice.

chimchar.name: Infernape
chimchar.blurb: Infernape love to pull pranks, stealing from powerful Pokémon and humans. This behavior can put Infernape in a lot of trouble, but it never tries causing problems for Pokémon smaller than itself.

piplup.name: Piplup
piplup.blurb: Piplup is much better at swimming than walking. They love racing against each themselves or other species in the water. Piplup winner circles are notoriously hard to deal with for local swimmers.

piplup.name: Prinplup
piplup.blurb: Prinplup only flock when an Empoleon evolves to keep them in line. Even then, they proudly refuse help from each other when a predator arrives. This pride washes away when a Gyarados appears.

piplup.name: Empoleon
piplup.blurb: Empoleon is one of the strongest swimmers in the world, despite the steel that should weigh it down. Boatyards design their ships based on Empoleon’s shape to handle the roughest waters.

starly.name: Starly
starly.blurb: Starly adapt to nearly any environment, becoming commonplace in many regions. This is partially due to their versatile diet; Starly can eat a wide variety of berries and fruit just as well as Bug-Types.

starly.name: Staravia
starly.blurb: Staravia will do nearly anything to protect their nests. If Staravia detects a snake in the grass, they will take one wing and trail it along the ground as if it were broken. This leads the predators away from their eggs and right into an ambush.

starly.name: Staraptor
starly.blurb: Although powerful, Staraptor don’t protect others of their own kind or attempt to breed. Instead their role within the species seems to be defending Starly territory when the flock has migrated away.

bidoof.name: Bidoof
bidoof.blurb: Bidoof are a national icon, to the ire of Sinnoh’s snootier citizens. Everybody loves its can-do attitude and ability to traverse nearly any terrain. Hiker gear usually has a Bidoof etched somewhere for good luck.

bidoof.name: Bibarel
bidoof.blurb: Training Bibarel can be difficult. They chew everything they get their teeth on, and try to dam any water sources the Trainer comes near. A special license is needed to own Bibarel if you live in a river town.

kricketot.name: Kricketot
kricketot.blurb: Kricketot are easy prey for the Starly line, with clumsy movements and little in the way of defenses. Kricketot try to keep Starly away by mimicking their calls, sounding like a rival flock. Starly tend to be fooled by this, but human ears can easily tell the difference.

kricketot.name: Kricketune
kricketot.blurb: Even after evolution, Kricketune don’t like to battle. Instead they spend their time composing new music to play for the wild Pokémon around them. Pokémon who enjoy this music protect Kricketune down to the last hit point.

shinx.name: Shinx
shinx.blurb: Shinx’s X-Ray vision hasn’t fully developed, giving them an adorable tendency to bump into walls they didn’t realize were there. Their tendency to emit blinding light in surprise when it happens is considerably less adorable.

shinx.name: Luxio
shinx.blurb: Luxio are a traditional partner for fairytale heroes. While Litleo represents bravery, Luxio represents knowledge. A Luxio tale would often be a battle of wits dependent on hidden knowledge only the Luxio was aware of.

shinx.name: Luxray
shinx.blurb: Luxray consider anything they live with as their pups, making them the only fully evolved Pokémon Parents’ Digest recommends giving to schoolchildren. Wild Luxray try to get their pups to join up with Trainers they consider worthy, but the standards are high.

cranidos.name: Cranidos
cranidos.blurb: Cranidos’s charges rip out trees and sever their roots, making an enemy of Shieldon. It’s believed they locked into an arms race long ago. Cranidos mistakes its own reflection as a challenger: mirrors, hubcaps, water — even realistic paintings are in danger.

cranidos.name: Rampardos
cranidos.blurb: It is nearly impossible to run from an angry Rampardos. It doesn’t matter if you are faster: Rampardos will barrel through any obstacle in its way, and won’t stop until it hits you.

shieldon.name: Shieldon
shieldon.blurb: Shieldon was expected to make a strong comeback due to its immense defenses, but modern wild Pokémon have more elaborate tactics. Shieldon still don’t fear predators, but competition with other herbivorous Pokémon keeps it rare.

shieldon.name: Bastiodon
shieldon.blurb: Bastiodon are used to protect archaeological digs from thieves. While the dig is unattended, they release Bastiodon walls around the site. Unless thieves have Flying-Types, the chances of getting in are slim.

burmy.name: Burmy
burmy.blurb:
Burmy constantly reknit their cloak and aren’t picky about the materials they find. This can be dangerous if Burmy picks up hazardous objects or even small Pokémon.
Pokéfeature: Burmy can change between Plant (Germinate), Sandy (Excavate) and Trash (Metallize) Cloaks outside of battle if it is in a proper environment.

burmy.name: Wormadam (Plant)
burmy.blurb: Wormadam’s cloak photosynthesizes only part of its calorie needs. It also eats lichen, moss, and fungi off trees before nesting on them. Navigating by the direction moss grows is especially unreliable in Wormadam territory.

burmy.name: Wormadam (Sand)
burmy.blurb: Most of Wormadam’s sand fused around its body, but the rocks are embedded for decoration. Sinnohans like to arrange the stones into patterns, but this practice is rare outside the region.

burmy.name: Wormadam (Trash)
burmy.blurb: New variants of Wormadam may arise in different urban environments. Wormadam collectors travel seeking new cloaks, but since the best locations are illegal to enter, rarely report their findings.

burmy.name: Mothim
burmy.blurb: Twice yearly, shops along Mothim migration routes hang bowls of honey. The idea was to distract Mothim from invading nearby businesses, but it was such a tourist attraction that it became a festival.

combee.name: Combee
combee.blurb: When two hives of Combee meet, their natural inclination is to join as friends. Only one Vespiquen is able to lead the new cluster though. If Combee is captured, they demand to be kept busy all day.

combee.name: Vespiquen
combee.blurb: Vespiquen pheromones can control Beedrill and Ribombee almost as well as Combee. If enough congregate, Vespiquen can become an environmental nuisance — at least surrounding plants thrive!

pachirisu.name: Pachirisu
pachirisu.blurb: It stores furballs crackling with static electricity along with its favorite berries in tree hollows. These berry traps are such a nuisance for Hikers that rubber gloves are common for foraging. Pachirisu resent the gloves.

buizel.name: Buizel
buizel.blurb: Buizel are popular with children, with many stories written about them. Their superstitions run the gamut: Buizel can be good luck, bad omens, witch familiars, transformed humans, or symbols of dignity or villainy.

buizel.name: Floatzel
buizel.blurb: Floatzel compete with Bibarel for control over rivers, breaking up their dams to strengthen currents. Bidoof and Bibarel are too slow to chase, so these conflicts are one-sided.

cherubi.name: Cherubi
cherubi.blurb: If the small ball is plucked it can eventually grow back, but only in the spring. Otherwise, Cherubi is stuck without evolving until the next year.

cherubi.name: Cherrim
cherubi.blurb: Cherrim still produces cherries on the sides of its head. These cherries store energy for overcast days, so Cherrim can go without sunlight for up to an entire week. It doesn’t like to put this to the test.

shellos.name: Shellos
shellos.blurb: Shellos has different appearances based on location and diet, but these changes aren’t yet enough to designate them regional variants. Blue Shellos prefer algae, while Pink Shellos are more carnivorous.

shellos.name: Gastrodon
shellos.blurb:
Gastrodon’s purple ooze can be made into powerful Repels, but are a terrible skin irritant.
Pokéfeature: Blue Gastrodon can choose Ice Body as their Level 5 Ability. Pink Gastrodon can choose Sun Blanket.

drifloon.name: Drifloon
drifloon.blurb: Drifloon are helpless against strong winds, getting blown around uncontrollably. They grab onto anything to keep put, even other Pokémon. If not heavy enough, they’re carried along too.

drifloon.name: Drifblim
drifloon.blurb: Drifblim love to drift through clouds, hidden from the rest of the world. People report fleets of Drifblim in stormy skies, only visible when lightning strikes.

buneary.name: Buneary
buneary.blurb: Wild Buneary are friends to all other Pokémon, but hate humans. They attack Trainers on sight, sometimes even before the Trainer brings out their partner for protection.

buneary.name: Lopunny
buneary.blurb: Lopunny hates having its fur touched, and terribly kicks anything that tries. They groom their fur for hours if it’s been even slightly ruffled, even if there’s other dangers nearby.

glameow.name: Glameow
glameow.blurb: Glameow is a popular pet for teenagers, who appreciate its fickle attitude. It’s a large responsibility though, and only gets more restless if it isn’t allowed to battle.

glameow.name: Purugly
glameow.blurb: If Purugly unfurls its tails, prepare for a rough battle. This means Purugly respects its foe, but also that it’s about to go all out. Purugly does not allow a foe to retreat when things get to this point.

stunky.name: Stunky
stunky.blurb: Young Stunky don’t know what deserves a spray, so they use it on anyone. They go after a house’s trash at night. The best way to stop an infestation is Cherrim; for some reason, Stunky hate its smell.

stunky.name: Skuntank
stunky.blurb: Skuntank’s noxious fumes are feared even by strong Pokémon, but Steel-Types have no problem with the smell. To deal with this, Skuntank uses its claws as flint to ignite their spray and thus their foes.

bronzor.name: Bronzor
bronzor.blurb: Ancient alloys imitated Bronzor’s body to resist earthquakes and withstand high temperatures. The formula has been lost for ages, but the archaeologists rumor of scrolls describing the process.

bronzor.name: Bronzong
bronzor.blurb: Bronzong gains no benefit from the rain it brings — it seeks cover in rainfall. Ruin Maniacs Monthly theorizes it summons rain to bargain for tribute from other species. If Bronzong cannot find food, it buries itself and sleeps until needed.

chatot.name: Chatot
chatot.blurb: Chatot is the star of the Jubilife Late Night Comedy Hour. It introduces and interviews guests, and even tells its own jokes. Most don’t know this is actually a whole flock of Chatot, who are prepped for weeks before every episode.

spiritomb.name: Spiritomb
spiritomb.blurb: In folklore, each spirit within Spiritomb has its own name and story. Occult researchers challenge each other to name these spirits as a game, but nobody knows where the tales originate from.

gible.name: Gible
gible.blurb: Gible is fascinated by what it can’t chomp to pieces, biting for hours before accepting that whatever it found is too tough. Gible with homes near roads can be seen hanging on the back of passing bicycles.

gible.name: Gabite
gible.blurb: Druddigon and Gabite regularly feud. Druddigon usually drives Gabite from nests to sleep on the hoarded jewels, enjoying their smoothness on its rough skin. If Gabite evolves, the ensuing retaliation shakes mountains.

gible.name: Garchomp
gible.blurb: Garchomp only fly at high speeds, so it’s not useful in battle. Riding Garchomp without special gear almost always gets you thrown off within seconds. It’s said to be extremely exciting, so people try anyway.

riolu.name: Riolu
riolu.blurb: Riolu are natural-born masters of combat, but can’t control the aura flaring inside them. It visibly bursts when they feel strong emotions, making them vulnerable to predators looking from above.

riolu.name: Lucario
riolu.blurb: Wild Lucario seek mentors after learning all they can alone. In high-level areas, Lucario may fight alongside strong Pokémon. If the Lucario thinks this unfair, you may convince it to leave.

hippopotas.name: Hippopotas
hippopotas.blurb: Hippopotas camouflages perfectly in deserts and swamps. It sinks down to soak up sun, but resents others walking on its protruding nose. This is nigh-impossible to avoid in Hippopotas colonies, and they communicate to the others via subtle tremors.

hippopotas.name: Hippowdon
hippopotas.blurb: If Hippowdon cannot find sand to steep in, it creates some. Wild Hippowdon wandering into urban areas have covered entire streets in sand, making temporary deserts. They’re in the Top 10 Most Dangerous Pokémon list every week in Rangers’ Digest.

skorupi.name: Skorupi
skorupi.blurb: Few Pokémon bother with Skorupi’s aggression, toxins, and pincers, so they have few predators. Skarmory, a noted exception, carries off Skorupi by its tail. Skorupi hide when Skarmory fly overhead.

skorupi.name: Drapion
skorupi.blurb: Skarmory do not hunt Drapion. Drapion never hide, and smash anything in their way with powerful claws. Many a fairy tale has an Ogre Scorp villian who wishes to eat innocent heroes.

croagunk.name: Croagunk
croagunk.blurb: Croagunk have trouble forming groups for long, as their penchant for mischief gets on each other’s nerves. But if they find a common prank to pull, they work together like a well-oiled machine.

croagunk.name: Toxicroak
croagunk.blurb: Toxicroak aren’t naturally battle-hungry, spending time croaking on rocks and lazily swimming in marshes. But when threatened, they become cruel and paranoid. What threatens a wild Pokémon is unpredictable, so be careful.

carnivine.name: Carnivine
carnivine.blurb: Carnivine and Weepinbel fight over branches to hang from and attract prey. Because both hunt by waiting, this mostly involves staring at each other for days. It is very dangerous to interrupt this battle.

finneon.name: Finneon
finneon.blurb: Finneon love jumping, despite the danger of Wingull. Their pink stripes soak up surface sunlight to shine even more vividly. If Finneon jumps into a boat by accident, toss it back to avoid bad luck.

finneon.name: Lumineon
finneon.blurb: Every year, hundreds of Lumineon gather off a certain beach for reasons unknown. It’s said their glowing fins are so numerous you can’t tell the stars from the sea. A Star Ocean festival is held nearby, said to be a perfect night for romance.

snover.name: Snover
snover.blurb: Snoverberries are a great seasonal snack. Cool and refreshing, they make a good contrast with the new warm spring air. Mountain Hikers like to crush them into jam or bake them into crisps.

snover.name: Abomasnow
snover.blurb: Abomasnow breathes galeforce winds with its massive lungs, freezing the air around it into small but intense blizzards to escape threats.

rotom.name: Rotom
rotom.blurb:
Rotom’s electronic possession is harnessed as a CPU for many modern inventions. They don’t mind helping out in exchange for the new form, but Rotom can get bored of the device and leave it empty.
Pokéfeature: Rotom can change forms by possessing machines. Rotom’s forms have separate Types, Level-up Moves, and Level 5 Abilities.

uxie.name: Uxie
uxie.blurb: In Ye Xian (collected and localized in The Yellow Fairy Book) Uxie gives a Feebas the ability to talk so that it can help a destitute girl with her evil stepmother. This tale has different iterations in many countries, but Uxie appears in all of them.

mesprit.name: Mesprit
mesprit.blurb: In The Pearl (collected and localized in The Purple Fairy Book) Mesprit grants a princess humility when she loses her birthright. This tale is a subversion from Mesprit’s usual role, where it hardens a villain’s heart.

azelf.name: Azelf
azelf.blurb: In The Adventures of Phanocchio (collected and localized in The Blue Fairy Book) Azelf changes a Phantump into a wooden boy, promising to teach him the value of hard work. This tale has been told many ways, but most adaptations wisely omit a lot of the story.

dialga.name: Dialga
dialga.blurb: Dialga’s timeline is inconsistent, appearing out of sync with history. In its loneliness, it lashes out at anyone it sees. If you touch the diamond on Dialga’s chest, you can see the rest of their life all at once.

palkia.name: Palkia
palkia.blurb: Palkia moves in multiple directions at once before making a decision, and it resents being forced into a spatial dimension where this is abnormal. It is said that the pearls on Palkia’s shoulders are mirrors to other worlds.

giratina.name: Giratina
giratina.blurb: Superstition says that if you stand at a crossroads during a stormy night, Giratina appears. The only way to escape being taken away to the Distortion World is to count Giratina’s legs, forcing them to grow.

giratina.name: Giratina (Origin)
giratina.blurb: If you get lost at night and cannot see where the road leads, you may find yourself walking into the Distortion World. Here, nothing makes sense and only shadows of a devil will be your company. Instead of retracing your steps, you must walk bravely forward to find your way out.

heatran.name: Heatran
heatran.blurb: Heatran do not live in volcanoes, but under them. What they eat is unknown, as no other species can stand Heatran’s natural environment. High volcanic pressure pushes them up to the crater surface.

cresselia.name: Cresselia
cresselia.blurb: When two moons appear in the sky, Cresselia is blessing the land. Even Hypno cannot steal the joyous dreams given by Cresselia, but some people refuse to ever wake up.

darkrai.name: Darkrai
darkrai.blurb: When Darkrai extends its legs to the ground, it covers the land in darkness. Nights supposedly last forever where Darkrai lays its head, and the moon is nowhere to be seen.

manaphy.name: Manaphy
manaphy.blurb: Manaphy loves to follow other Pokémon as they swim through the sea, helping out however it can. Even Sharpedo and Gyarados are friendly when it is around them, although they go right back to raging when it leaves.

manaphy.name: Phione
manaphy.blurb: Phione are only seen in great numbers in the middle of the ocean, where they were born. Ocean currents carry them away all over the world, where they are seen as ambassadors of companionship.

shaymin.name: Shaymin
shaymin.blurb:
Ruined battlegrounds pray to Shaymin to bring redemption. Some particularly desperate folks spend all day obsessively looking for Shaymin in fields.
Pokéfeature: Shaymin can transform into Sky Shaymin when exposed to flowers during the day and transforms back at night. Sky Shaymin has a separate Movepool.

shaymin.name: Shaymin (Sky)
shaymin.blurb: Flower artists always claim to see Shaymin, but their descriptions never match historical records. Their claim that Shaymin can fly is absolutely ridiculous, and should be taken as an automatic discredit.

arceus.name: Arceus
arceus.blurb: When the Azure Flute plays, Arceus must appear. Its thousand arms litter the Earth, shattered protecting us from those beyond. Those who approach Arceus without humility in their heart cannot stand in its presence.

victini.name: Victini
victini.blurb: Victini’s favor is fickle, and ancient armies on both sides of war clamored for its energy. Only those who give appreciation towards Victini’s power can hope to see it again.

snivy.name: Snivy
snivy.blurb: Snivy starts life in the trees. It uses its small arms and legs to hop between branches, not long enough yet to wrap its body around them. It hides amongst leafage, and many walk past without noticing. To tell if a Snivy is in your tree, bow to the branches.

snivy.name: Servine
snivy.blurb: Servine doesn’t need feeding in the summer, subsisting entirely on photosynthesis. It uses heat sensors on the tip of its nose to find the strongest sunlight, but this also lures Servine to Fire-Types.

snivy.name: Serperior
snivy.blurb: Ancient texts describe Serperior as the ruler of wild areas, never allowing warriors through. To travel through Serperior territory without conflict, bring a Pokémon that can perform Sunny Day as tribute.

tepig.name: Tepig
tepig.blurb: Chefs once cooked their food with Tepig’s help, but it has imperfect temperature control. Modern conventional ovens are better at restaurant-quality meals. Tepig cooks are still popular for festivals and holidays, with a more ‘natural’ taste.

tepig.name: Pignite
tepig.blurb: Pignite grazes in drought-stricken grasslands. Nobody’s sure how Pignite determines when an area will stop getting rain, but farmers grow nervous when it appears.

tepig.name: Emboar
tepig.blurb: Emboar is strong but lazy. If not fed properly, it refuses to battle with full strength — except against Infernape, where Emboar suddenly does everything with maximum firepower. The two don’t share habitats, so Pokéologists are unsure why.

oshawott.name: Oshawott
oshawott.blurb: If Oshawott loses its scalchop, it will not battle. It drifts despondently, refusing to defend itself. It takes about a month for Oshawott to grow a new scalchop.

oshawott.name: Dewott
oshawott.blurb: Dewott lives a life of strict discipline, sitting still two hours every day at the bottom of a strong river to strengthen its will. Its training with scalchops is often mistaken for an elaborate dance.

oshawott.name: Samurott
oshawott.blurb: Samurott needs a home to protect, and when it settles down will not retreat no matter what. Historians sometimes find Samurott guarding fortresses that have been abandoned for generations.

patrat.name: Patrat
patrat.blurb: Patrat are skittish and paranoid, but easy to capture regardless. Most Patrat confuse Poké Balls for berries and grab the ball of their own accord. Parents who haven’t taught their children how to throw often end up with a Patrat around the house.

patrat.name: Watchog
patrat.blurb: Watchog’s glowing body and eyes fluctuate wildly when it senses a threat. This confuses enemies so badly they nearly vomit, but Watchog Trainers often suffer the same fate.

lillipup.name: Lillipup
lillipup.blurb: Lillipup is even more popular than Growlithe in areas where both naturally occur. Lillipup handles strangers better and can’t put scorch marks on the couch, even if it isn’t as powerful and can’t scare away strong Pokémon in the yard.

lillipup.name: Herdier
lillipup.blurb: When Lillipup evolve, the money and effort needed for its care increase. Many households struggle to keep up, so Volunteer Pokémon Houses started a special assistance program. Give an Everstone to your Lillipup if you aren’t ready for the responsibility.

lillipup.name: Stoutland
lillipup.blurb: Stoutland fur makes great coats, so groomers keep the shed hairs whenever they brush it. A layered coat can keep you warm in a blizzard.

purrloin.name: Purrloin
purrloin.blurb: Purrloin is one of the best partners recommended in The Complete Thief’s Handbook, but with a warning. Purrloin even steal from their own Trainers, so keep incriminating evidence out of their reach.

purrloin.name: Liepard
purrloin.blurb: Battle Trainers don’t tend to like Liepard, but they’re extremely popular with Contest Participants. Their beautiful fur and ability to lie make them perfect performers. If that doesn’t do the job, they can always steal the Contest Ribbons afterwards.

pansage.name: Pansage
pansage.blurb: The Pan Trio are Unova’s most popular starters, easily trained and great helpers outside of battle. Pansage in particular loves to hang on its Trainer’s shoulders, keeping close watch over their partner.

pansage.name: Simisage
pansage.blurb: Simisage don’t make any audible noise, but their new fingers are great for sign language. This language is incompatible with human sign language, so it’s a mystery what they’re signing.

pansear.name: Pansear
pansear.blurb: Due to Pansear’s hard-to-access location, it’s the least commonly captured of the Pan Trio. Instead, Trainers breed Pansear and gift each other the eggs. It’s said that most Pansear partners descend from only a handful of specimens.

pansear.name: Simisear
pansear.blurb: Simisear’s nearly deaf to any sound but the flame within its body. It still makes a great assistant, as long as Chefs use timers that vibrate instead of ring.

panpour.name: Panpour
panpour.blurb: Panpour live in ponds without any currents, absorbing nutrients from mud at the bottom. This cleans the pond and helps the plants onshore grow to great heights.

panpour.name: Simipour
panpour.blurb: Simipour always knows where its opponent is in battle, but otherwise it can’t see outside of water. It can always follow the sound of its Trainer’s footsteps.

munna.name: Munna
munna.blurb: Munna’s dream mist is a popular incense, and seances can be full of it. Inhaling the Dream Mist gives a glimpse of someone’s dream, so occultists would use it to try and predict the future.

munna.name: Musharna
munna.blurb: Despite a clear battle advantage, Cofagrigus avoid Musharna. Experts believe Cofagrigus fears dreaming about its old life.

pidove.name: Pidove
pidove.blurb: Pidove adapt to cities better than their original habitats. They’re friendly, but too many are a problem: they knock over objects, challenge battlers on the street, and chase children carrying food. Avoid feeding city Pidove unless you intend capture.

pidove.name: Tranquill
pidove.blurb: Pidove leave cities after evolving into Tranquill. They compete to find suitable nesting places in forests, and they hide until evolving again. Magnemite and Probopass mess with their internal compass’s ability to return home.

pidove.name: Unfezant
pidove.blurb:
Unfezant’s mask once was a shorthand for nobility in stage costume, still seen in traditional plays. These days, it’s usually written as a signal of ostentatiousness.
Pokéfeature: Male Unfezant can choose Intimidate for their Level 5 Ability. Female Unfezant can choose Gale Wings.

blitzle.name: Blitzle
blitzle.blurb: Blitzle can’t outrun all predators and are unsure in battle, so they adopt a different defense mechanism: when frightened, their stripes flash in random patterns. Herded together, it’s disorienting to see where one Blitzle begins and the next ends.

blitzle.name: Zebstrika
blitzle.blurb: Zebstrika is a popular mount thanks to its high speed, and once was Unova’s answer to the Ponyta Express. Mail carriers of the time could be identified by their hair standing on end.

roggenrola.name: Roggenrola
roggenrola.blurb: The origin of the energy cores that animate Roggenrola is unsure. Analysis shows them as similar to Z-Crystals, but composed of no extraterrestial material. Unova televises Roggenrola bowling, where the chance of explosion is part of the show.

roggenrola.name: Boldore
roggenrola.blurb: When people get lost in caves, Boldore are sent in to find them. They always find the Trainer, but sometimes lead them to sources of water instead of the exit. This water is unfit for human consumption, but has very low salinity, so it’s a good idea to take some.

roggenrola.name: Gigalith
roggenrola.blurb: Gigalith’s energy core absorbs solar rays, forcing it out of caves and into bright sunlight. Poachers camp at cave mouths and wait for Boldore inside to evolve. The crystals sell for absurd prices on the black market.

woobat.name: Woobat
woobat.blurb: On romantic holidays, couples who own Woobat like to stick its nose all over to leave hearts for their partner to find. This leaves places like Nacrene City absolutely covered with the mark, which then has to be cleaned up by others.

woobat.name: Swoobat
woobat.blurb: Swoobat is too heavy for its nose to stick to walls, so it grows a long tail that can wrap around branches or stalactites. Its ultrasonic waves are too powerful to echolocate with, so it grew eyes as well.

drilbur.name: Drilbur
drilbur.blurb: Residents who get Drilbur in their gardens are encouraged to deal with it as soon as possible. While most household Pokémon can chase a Drilbur away, once it evolves all bets are off.

drilbur.name: Excadrill
drilbur.blurb: Trainers who get lost in Excadrill burrows could wander for a month and never see the same tunnel twice. Other Ground-Types take up residence in tunnels that Excadrill has forgotten about, hoping it won’t come back.

audino.name: Audino
audino.blurb: Wild Audino greet everything with a friendly face, even coming out of hiding to heal battle-weary Pokémon. This doesn’t always work out, but they never stop trying. Even when Trainers teach Audino the fun of battling, they prefer supporting their team to defeating enemies.

timburr.name: Timburr
timburr.blurb: Timburr who lose their log fell a tree in a single chop and whittle it down to make another. It doesn’t like cutting down trees when it has its log by its side.

timburr.name: Gurdurr
timburr.blurb: Gurdurr’s instincts make it so good at construction that historians think it was bred by ancient human workers. If it thinks the steel beam it carries is too small, it steals another from a work site.

timburr.name: Conkeldurr
timburr.blurb: Conkeldurr is confident in its strength, only picking up its concrete pillars when it’s time to work. At morning you can hear Conkeldurr barking orders to Timburr and Gurdurr, but it sounds proud of them.

tympole.name: Tympole
tympole.blurb: While humans can’t hear Tympole’s sound waves, the vibrations can be felt. Dancers report better rhythm if a Tympole is croaking in the room, and Tympole Trainers may feel an inexplicable urge to tap their feet.

tympole.name: Palpitoad
tympole.blurb: When Palpitoad shakes the ground, it can unearth Stunfisk hiding nearby. Stunfisk can’t do anything about it, so some Palpitoad turn it into a game. If a route is covered in angry Stunfisk, thank Palpitoad.

tympole.name: Seismitoad
tympole.blurb: Seismitoad can swim but prefers land with high rainfall. They use vibrations to force prey fish Pokémon out shallow water. Their forehead venom curiously only paralyzes humans, making Pokéologists wonder about its purpose.

throh.name: Throh
throh.blurb: Throh mostly practices judo, but its weaving is even more impeccable. Traditional towns leave out dyed vines for Throh to weave into comfortable clothing that takes forever to tear. Supposedly Throh even weaves the belts that Sawk wears.

sawk.name: Sawk
sawk.blurb: Sawk constantly spars against Throh, karate-chopping it when they meet. The two don’t have any actual animosity, and relax together after bouts. Sawk practically trains itself, which is great for beginning Trainers but difficult for advanced Trainers to influence.

sewaddle.name: Sewaddle
sewaddle.blurb: Leavanny cares for Sewaddle until it learns to make its own clothes. Sewaddle’s leaves are fashionable, but never last long. It constantly hunts for more foliage to wear.

sewaddle.name: Swadloon
sewaddle.blurb: Swadloon mostly keep to themselves, anxious of predators and criticism. They spend a lot of time making outfits that nobody wears, hiding them inside its cloak.

sewaddle.name: Leavanny
sewaddle.blurb: Leavanny’s an amazing tailor, but prefers working with leaves and silk. Fashion companies let Leavanny prototype outfits to copy its designs with other materials, but dedicated auteurs convince Leavanny to work with fabric. It refuses to make outfits for Fire-Types.

venipede.name: Venipede
venipede.blurb: Venipede eat nearly anything, but won’t battle Sewaddle unless provoked. It hates the taste of Sewaddle’s leaf outfit, and won’t eat it unless it’s starving.

venipede.name: Whirlipede
venipede.blurb: Underground Whirlipede racing is all the rage, where the referee places a Pansage on the track for Whirlipede to chase toward a finish line. This is banned in sanctioned sports leagues for obvious reasons.

venipede.name: Scolipede
venipede.blurb: Trainers who want to ride Scolipede are encouraged to buy covers for its toxin-filled spikes. If an enemy tries to get onto Scolipede’s back, it still knows how to roll up and fling them off.

cottonee.name: Cottonee
cottonee.blurb: Cottonee bunch together for warmth in cold wind, but also to offer each other better control over where they drift. It is one of the 10 species that aren’t penalized for ring outs caused by natural breezes.

cottonee.name: Whimsicott
cottonee.blurb: Trainers who put Whimsicott through many battles can spend hours cleaning up the debris stuck in its cotton. If Whimsicott gets too burdened by the mess, it will take off its cotton entirely and wait to regrow. This leaves it defenseless, so it would prefer to just be groomed.

petilil.name: Petilil
petilil.blurb: Petilil is one of the best judges a botany contest can ask for. Just place one in the soil, and see how it reacts. Petilil’s standards are high, so it only happily stays in the best kept gardens.

petilil.name: Lilligant
petilil.blurb: During the summer, it’s popular for county fairs to hold dance contests. If a Lilligant manages to find its way in, the winner is practically decided already. If a human manages to dance better than Lilligant, its flower blooms even brighter to try and compensate.

basculin.name: Basculin
basculin.blurb:
Where you find one color of Basculin, you’ll eventually find the other. The stripe is a matter of timing: hatchlings in warm seasons are red and hatchlings in cold seasons are blue. Newborn Basculin don’t recognize their parents, so they join schools of the same color.
Pokéfeature: Blue Basculin can choose Reckless or Zealous as their Level 5 Ability. Red Basculin can choose Rock Head or Lifedrinker.

sandile.name: Sandile
sandile.blurb: Sandile like to swim in the sand around Cacturne, using it to find collapsed prey. If a target is taking too long to stop moving, they’ll run up and bite on its leg. This partnership will be broken when Sandile evolves, but for now they enjoy each other.

sandile.name: Krokorok
sandile.blurb: Krokorok can’t stand desert nights, and won’t pop up from the sands even if there’s easy prey above. They still track the target using their heat vision from underground.

sandile.name: Krookodile
sandile.blurb: When Krookodile catches something it can’t eat, it buries the object for later. Entire cars have been found half buried in the desert after being dragged off the road and chomped on.

darumaka.name: Darumaka
darumaka.blurb: In winter, Daruma temples start a large fire. Sleeping Darumaka are taken to the temple and thrown into the flames, waking them up for the first time in months. A party is held around the resulting explosion of energy, which burns for three days.

darumaka.name: Darmanitan
darumaka.blurb: Darmanitan who pack together are always getting into trouble, and tend to migrate after wrecking their nest. When they meet up with a pack of Primeape, the level of violence is unprecedented. Their bellies don’t burn with rage: Darmanitan just love life too much to be careful.

darumaka.name: Darmanitan (Zen)
darumaka.blurb: Superstition says if you fill in a Darmanitan Zen statue’s eyes, you will have good luck on any goal. You fill in one when you meet it, then the other when you’ve achieved your goal. If Darmanitan wakes before you fill the other eye, it punishes your procrastination with violence.

darumaka.name: Galarian Darumaka
darumaka.blurb: Darumaka appear around Galar’s inert volcanoes where the temperature used to be much higher. Trainers lost in blizzards sometimes see dancing troupes on the mountain peaks. Galarian Daruma temples offer refuge from the weather if you can find them.

darumaka.name: Galarian Darmanitan
darumaka.blurb: The Darmanitan in Galar don’t have fire in their bellies to fuel so much violence. Much more peaceful and methodical, once they decide on a battle plan, they don’t deviate from it at all. A common prank is to surprise visiting Unovans with a Galarian Darmanitan while they’re eating.

darumaka.name: Galarian Darmanitan (Zen)
darumaka.blurb: In Galar, Darmanitan reaches Zen through violence. The face on a fainted Galarian Darmanitan is of ultimate satisfaction, even if it injured itself in its rampage.

maractus.name: Maractus
maractus.blurb: Maractus sometimes get together in the desert, jumping and dancing as a group. In small numbers this is quite enjoyable, but when dozens appear it’s just a racket.

dwebble.name: Dwebble
dwebble.blurb: Dwebble fight over the best shell rocks. Their natural habitats don’t usually have gemstones, but Dwebble go crazy when there is one around. Career contest judges say a Gem Dwebble is even more prestigious than a shiny one.

dwebble.name: Crustle
dwebble.blurb: There aren’t enough boulders in deserts to sustain large Crustle populations, so they migrate to mountains after evolution. There’s plenty of rock in this new environment, but a new risk comes from Fighting-Types wanting to shatter Crustle’s shell as training.

scraggy.name: Scraggy
scraggy.blurb: Scraggy love to steal anything as elastic as their pants. Springs, rubber bands, and accordions litter their alleyway nests. They don’t seem to notice whenever people steal these objects right back.

scraggy.name: Scrafty
scraggy.blurb: Scrafty’s acid spit also has non-battle applications; the liquid can be converted into a variety of paints for cheap, making it popular with starving artists. Scrafty doesn’t take criticism of its artist partner well, and is known to headbutt a rude audience.

sigilyph.name: Sigilyph
sigilyph.blurb: Trainers biking at night near old ruins report large flying creatures chasing them down the road, only to disappear once the trainers reach town. Many wonder if they’re hiding something or simply afraid of the light.
