yamask.name: Yamask
yamask.blurb: The funeral rites used by ancient people to become Yamask after death have never been found in detail. What little archaeologists know implies that the world was better off having forgotten.

yamask.name: Cofagrigus
yamask.blurb: Cofagrigus has completely abandoned its old life to revel as king of whatever tomb it inhabits. Trainers exploring old ruins should bring a small amount of gold they can tribute to Cofagrigus. It won’t decide to let you leave, but you can run away while it eats the gold.

yamask.name: Galarian Yamask
yamask.blurb: Yamask in Galar do not remember their past lives, as evidenced by Dream World research. The worlds that Yamask dream of are twisted fragments of epic tales, with no context to make sense of it all.

yamask.name: Runerigus
yamask.blurb: Archaeologists consider Runerigus a double-edged sword. While it is a living piece of history, it consumes historical artifacts to evolve. Unscrupulous archaeologists feed Yamask relics that would otherwise fetch low prices, selling off the resulting Runerigus for massive profit.

tirtouga.name: Tirtouga
tirtouga.blurb: When Tirtouga’s first fossils were found on land, it was believed to be the result of continental drift. It only became apparent that Tirtouga hunted on land when one was found with Cranidos-shaped dents in its shell.

tirtouga.name: Carracosta
tirtouga.blurb: Carracosta’s shell is extremely tough, using air pockets within its indents to keep buoyancy. Carracosta would hunt in the deep sea by grabbing prey and pulling it up to the surface before it could adjust.

archen.name: Archen
archen.blurb: Archen doesn’t eat the kibble sold in most stores. It must be fed special berries grown from ferns that existed during its time, or sausage curry. Ecologists don’t think it can be reintroduced to the wild, but it’s popular enough with Trainers to not be a problem.

archen.name: Archeops
archen.blurb: Archeops only clumsily flies for short periods. It could probably fly better if it tried harder, but it never makes the attempt. Archeops gives up on problems immediately if it faces obstacles, making it hard to train. That said, it learns quickly, so it isn’t impossible.

trubbish.name: Trubbish
trubbish.blurb: Trubbish are all over junkyards, eating everything in sight. This is a big help in cleanup, but the place still smells awful. Trubbish that learn to eat things other than trash smell a bit better, but aren’t as strong at battling.

trubbish.name: Garbodor
trubbish.blurb: Garbodor’s poison gases are greatly affected by what they ingest. Parents should be careful with children and Garbodor, as kids find it great fun to throw objects in Garbodor’s mouth and smell the changes. The gases are still poison, so the game always ends with tears.

zorua.name: Zorua
zorua.blurb: Zorua’s original region is a mystery, as it only pops up invading other Pokémon’s territory. Zorua can’t imitate the moves of other Pokémon, so when it disguises itself it tries not to provoke battles. This can get awkward when two Zorua meet up and don’t recognize each other.

zorua.name: Zoroark
zorua.blurb: Zoroark who meet like to form their own pack, and their illusive powers only multiply. They team up with Sudowoodo to make forests that trespassers never emerge from.

minccino.name: Minccino
minccino.blurb: It’s common for house owners to capture a Minccino to keep the house clean. This has a chance of backfiring when a child enters the scene, as Minccino will kick something that’s too dirty out of its home.

minccino.name: Cinccino
minccino.blurb: Cinccino only secretes oil when it feels stressed or wants to clean itself. Most owners don’t want to deal with how many battles it takes to keep up a constant supply, but Cinccino seems happy to take foes to the cleaners.

gothita.name: Gothita
gothita.blurb: Gothita love to watch the stars, and try to climb up trees just to get a better look. They dislike being in brightly lit areas at night, but they live near cities, so it’s hard for them to find a place they like.

gothita.name: Gothorita
gothita.blurb: Gothorita likes to play games with the children it controls, but doesn’t know how they work. Children may play by its improper rules when they wake up. If you see a child playing hopskotch by stepping or drawing triangles on a grid, they were likely possessed by Gothorita.

gothita.name: Gothitelle
gothita.blurb: Newly-evolved Gothitelle have problems walking with their long dress and short legs. They instead trap Pokémon from fleeing with their Psychic powers, showing them the cosmos. Gothitelle’s shadow reflects the stars even at noon.

solosis.name: Solosis
solosis.blurb: The shape of its jelly is held together by its psychic powers. When asleep or unconscious, it collapses into a puddle to form a soft bed.

solosis.name: Duosion
solosis.blurb: Duosion can’t pay attention to anything for long, so it seeks to solve problems quickly and easily. If it can’t just blast an obstacle apart, it wanders off and lets somebody else handle it. It mostly grazes at this stage, soaking up easily-found plant matter and dissolving it.

solosis.name: Reuniclus
solosis.blurb: When Reuniclus gets angry, the liquid in its arms begins to boil. It’s not particularly hot, but Reuniclus is losing its structure in favor of exploding power. When this happens, Reuniclus will fight with no regard for its safety. If it calms down, the liquid reforms quickly.

ducklett.name: Ducklett
ducklett.blurb: Peat moss is an important part of pond ecology, so if there’s too many Duckletts they need to be relocated. Locals get together with special League Balls to capture as many Ducklett as they can, then release the Pokémon in larger ponds that can handle the birds.

ducklett.name: Swanna
ducklett.blurb: Swanna are beautiful but mischievous. They love taking the bag off a Trainer’s side and running off with it for no obvious reason, then pretending nothing happened if they get caught.

vanillite.name: Vanillite
vanillite.blurb: Vanillite covers itself with snow to protect its vulnerable head. Lots of trainers like to add flavors to change Vanillite’s colors, but they always wash out by the next day.

vanillite.name: Vanillish
vanillite.blurb: In particularly cold regions, Vanillish never want to stay inside. They’ll turn a house into a snowy wonderland until somebody opens the door for them, so most Trainers just don’t take them inside to begin with.

vanillite.name: Vanilluxe
vanillite.blurb: Vanilluxe’s new pipe is the only piece of its body not made from ice, with special metal coils throughout its structure. This pipe acts as a cooler for Vanilluxe, keeping it cold even in warmer environments.

deerling.name: Deerling
deerling.blurb:
If a Deerling is taken from one hemisphere to another, its colors change to match the new environment. Its scent doesn’t change its timing though, so Deerling can recognize when one is from a different region.
Pokéfeature: Deerling’s third Level 5 Ability changes with the season: Pixilate in Spring, Normalize in Summer, Germinate in Fall, and Refrigerate in Winter.

deerling.name: Sawsbuck
deerling.blurb:
Sawsbuck hate having their leaves pruned, but need it in domestic life. Wild Sawsbuck naturally get rid of excess leaves by ramming each other’s antlers when they compete.
Pokéfeature: Sawsbuck’s third Level 5 Ability changes with the season: Pixilate in Spring, Normalize in Summer, Germinate in Fall, and Refrigerate in Winter.

emolga.name: Emolga
emolga.blurb: Emolga are so popular in Unova they almost eclipse Pikachu. For a short while, people even wore Emolga-modeled cloaks after a runway appearance by Elesa. This trend was originally worn by teenagers, but now it’s seen as a fashion for children.

karrablast.name: Karrablast
karrablast.blurb: Karrablast’s aggression towards other Bug-Types make it a favorite on large farms. It’s a bad idea to use one in a personal garden, since if a Karrablast isn’t supplied enough other bugs to fight, it will wander off to find them.

karrablast.name: Escavalier
karrablast.blurb: Although Escavalier are considered strong and noble, they gained their armor through illicit means. Trainers believe Escavalier’s tendency to let other Pokémon attack first despite their great speed is a form of atonement.

shelmet.name: Shelmet
shelmet.blurb: Shelmet can hop around a bit, but its armor is too heavy for any sustained movement. It likes to find a hidden spot up above and wait for prey to pass underneath. When prey walk by, it drops down and snaps its shell over the target to trap it.

shelmet.name: Accelgor
shelmet.blurb: Wild Accelgor have an instinctual urge to steal back their armor from Escavalier, even if they never succeed. Their skills should make them a perfect partner for criminals, but Accelgor tend to also have an aggravated sense of justice.

foongus.name: Foongus
foongus.blurb: DNA sequencing suggests that Foongus might be a Unovan variant of Morelull. The Pokémon adapted to live in urban environments, luring Trainers rather than Pokémon. Trainers who fall for this ruse and get knocked unconscious find themselves missing their Poké Puffs.

foongus.name: Amoonguss
foongus.blurb: Amoonguss generally do not realize their disguise no longer works after evolution. Trainers who refuse to fall for Amoonguss’ obvious ruse find themselves being chased down by the Pokémon and its poisonous spores, offended by the insult.

frillish.name: Frillish
frillish.blurb: Frillish who want an easy meal like to drift along the side of fishing boats. They can squeeze through the tightest nets and eat fish Pokémon that can’t run away. They’ll also scare schools into the nets though, so fishers don’t always find it a hindrance.

frillish.name: Jellicent
frillish.blurb:
It’s dangerous to treasure hunt in Jellicent’s hunting grounds, but lots of divers do so anyway. The treasures in a Jellicent palace can date back hundreds of years, built up by generations of Jellicent.
Pokéfeature: Male Jellicent can choose Regal Challenge as their Level 5 Ability. Female Jellicent can choose Queenly Majesty.

joltik.name: Joltik
joltik.blurb: If your electric bill is suspiciously high, check for Joltik infestation. To get rid of a Joltik infestation, borrow an Electric-Type and walk it around the house. The Joltik will all attach themselves to your Pokémon, which can then be taken outside and shaken free.

joltik.name: Galvantula
joltik.blurb: Galvantula’s web is nearly invisible in tall grass, but less so in caves and other biomes. Trainers in Unova often wear rubber-soled shoes just in case. If a wandering Krookodile sees the web, it bites the electric trap intentionally and waits for Galvantula to show up.

ferroseed.name: Ferroseed
ferroseed.blurb: Ferroseed get the water they need to grow as it drips down stalactites, and apparently don’t need sunlight at all. This makes them extremely hardy plants, recommended for people who somehow always kill their garden.

ferroseed.name: Ferrothorn
ferroseed.blurb: Ferrothorn are a bigger threat above than Galvantula is below. The two species will compete for prey and the attention of Trainers who pass by, both of them spinning out elemental attacks as hard as they can.

klink.name: Klink
klink.blurb: An industrial accident flooded machinery with delta energy, and the gears started to move on their own. This was the birth of Klink, according to historians, who can’t find any appearance of the Pokémon beforehand.

klink.name: Klang
klink.blurb: If an engineer designs their machinery for it, Klang can attach to power the device. If the Klang starts to feel threatened, it will speed up and start to overclock whatever it’s attached to.

klink.name: Klinklang
klink.blurb: Ace Trainers and Engineers are both on the lookout for Klinklangite. Its Mega Evolution is rumored to be a technological marvel beyond mankind, although its designs may not be benevolent. As it is now, Klinklang can power a small town if fed properly.

tynamo.name: Tynamo
tynamo.blurb: When a school of Tynamo is nearby, the hair on your arm stands on end. During these times, Trainers are encouraged for their safety to wait. Tynamo split up to eat or sleep, so it will be safe to pass eventually.

tynamo.name: Eelektrik
tynamo.blurb: When tired, Eelektrik attach to cave ceilings and pretend to be stalactites. This doesn’t actually fool anybody, but nothing wants to attack Eelektrik in its environment, so it works out.

tynamo.name: Eelektross
tynamo.blurb: Eelektross only leave their caves when prey is scarce, so they’re especially aggressive. They like to chase Flying-Types through the air, toying with them like a Glameow with a Ratatta.

elgyem.name: Elgyem
elgyem.blurb: Conspiracy theorists always search for the UFO that supposedly crashed in Elgyem’s desert, but after fifty years it’s never been found. Most attempts are said to not have seen anything memorable at all.

elgyem.name: Beheeyem
elgyem.blurb: Some pop scientists theorize that Beheeyem is behind nearly every human achievement in history. Considering Beheeyem only first appeared fifty years ago, this claim is not highly regarded.

litwick.name: Litwick
litwick.blurb: The fire on Litwick’s head cannot be trusted, as it only illuminates what Litwick wants. It puts a spotlight on the path it wants humans to walk, but hides all the dangers that are lurking just to the sides.

litwick.name: Lampent
litwick.blurb: Lampent’s glass shell lets it wander in even the worst storms. Repentant Lampent will glow over a shrine like lighthouse beacons, offering shelter under dark skies.

litwick.name: Chandelure
litwick.blurb: Chandelure controls the vision of those it burns. It plunges people into a total darkness, never letting them escape until it is defeated. If a victim no longer fears Chandelure, the burn disappears mysteriously as well.

axew.name: Axew
axew.blurb: Axew love to gash anything taller than themselves, from phone lines to fences. Because of this, Axew are forbidden to walk outside Poké Balls in populated areas, unless the Trainer has badges to prove they can handle it.

axew.name: Fraxure
axew.blurb: The only way for a Fraxure’s tusk to grow back is evolution. This makes a Fraxure with a broken tusk incredibly dangerous, as they will attack anything on sight in a bid to grow stronger.

axew.name: Haxorus
axew.blurb: Before discovering Haxorus as Fraxure’s evolution, medieval scholars believed it to be Bug-Type. This mistake only reinforced Haxorus’s reputation, as it easily endured even the hottest Flamethrowers.

cubchoo.name: Cubchoo
cubchoo.blurb: Trainers have to avoid the urge to clean up its snot. Cubchoo will just make more to replace it, eventually dehydrating itself. It only stops making mucus when swimming.

cubchoo.name: Beartic
cubchoo.blurb: In snowy regions, art fairs sell beautiful “found” ice sculptures. These sculptures are actually made by Beartic’s breath. Beartic makes these sculptures when it thinks nobody is looking, but smashes them if it thinks it’s been found out.

cryogonal.name: Cryogonal
cryogonal.blurb: Every surface of Cryogonal is reflective when polished. The back reflects perfectly, but its front distorts and warps images. This can confuse enemies every once in a while, but most use it for funny faces.

stunfisk.name: Stunfisk
stunfisk.blurb: Local fairs pit Stunfisk against each other, but not for their electricity. Instead, contestants raise the flattest Stunfisk. One infamous year a person submitted a paper cutout of Stunfisk, but it didn’t win.

stunfisk.name: Galarian Stunfisk
stunfisk.blurb: Local fairs forbid Galarian Stunfisk. This variant adapted to live in nearly any terrain, but especially loves muddy caves with low visibility. Routes with both Foongus and Stunfisk are completely off-limits for badgeless Trainers.

mienfoo.name: Mienfoo
mienfoo.blurb: If Mienfoo see somebody attacked by Sneasel, they almost always interfere. The two packs will battle each other, forgetting about the person entirely.

mienfoo.name: Mienshao
mienfoo.blurb: There’s a school of dancing based on copying Mienshao’s movements. Using long sleeves, dancers combine flowing movements and sweeping arcs. Even the best dancers can’t keep up with Mienshao when it’s excited about battle.

druddigon.name: Druddigon
druddigon.blurb: Druddigon uses the naturally stable temperature of caves to hide from the cold of winter, which make it unable to move. If you find a collection of statues in a snow-ridden area, be careful not to build a fire too close.

golett.name: Golett
golett.blurb: When not actively guarding anything, Golett curl up into inert rocks to conserve energy. Archaeologists who want to protect ancient ruins sometimes make fake Golett boulders to scare away intruders.

golett.name: Golurk
golett.blurb: Golurk will follow the orders of anybody who speaks the language of the ancient people who created it. Ruin Maniacs Monthly prints some key phrases every issue just in case an archaeologist should run into one, but the pronunciation is hard to imitate.

pawniard.name: Pawniard
pawniard.blurb: Pawniard are dangerous pests when they enter urban areas. They’ll threaten shopkeepers, gang up on guard Pokémon, and even attack Trainers in public plazas. Pawniard packs only show up once a week no matter how bold they get, so towns at least get time to prepare.

pawniard.name: Bisharp
pawniard.blurb: Bisharp don’t participate in battles it thinks are unworthy of its attention, only hitting the final blow. If it sees a Pokémon as strong as itself though, it challenges the target one on one and won’t let its Pawniards interfere.

bouffalant.name: Bouffalant
bouffalant.blurb: Bouffalant aren’t hurt when they headbutt each other, so they do it out of affection. Trainers who don’t handle this behavior find themselves in a hospital bed. The afro fur from Bouffalant is used to make Assault Vests.

rufflet.name: Rufflet
rufflet.blurb: Popular culture pits Rufflet and Vullaby as enemies, but in the wild they get along splendidly. Rufflet will show skulls it finds to Vullaby, and Vullaby points out strong enemies for Rufflet to throw itself against. Some people consider it an uneven relationship.

rufflet.name: Braviary
rufflet.blurb: Braviary picks up any car that parks too close to its nest and drops it into the ocean. Pokéologists believe it mistakes the car for an evolution of Durant, and don’t blame it for overreacting.

vullaby.name: Vullaby
vullaby.blurb: Vullaby isn’t a good hunter, so it can’t stray from its nest for long. It doesn’t recognize danger, so it will wander off if it sees anything interesting. When it inevitably becomes lost, it makes a cry similar to Cubone’s to attract its mother.

vullaby.name: Mandibuzz
vullaby.blurb: Mandibuzz only uses the finest bones to make its nest. If the bones get dirty or cracked, they toss the whole nest out and rebuild from scratch. Some towns leave out trays of polished bones after their meal is finished to keep Mandibuzz satisfied.

heatmor.name: Heatmor
heatmor.blurb: Heatmor are so successful at keeping Durants in check that pest control agencies have begun breeding them to handle other infestations. This has led to mixed success; especially in terms of collateral damage.

durant.name: Durant
durant.blurb: Although Durant prefer mountain tunnels, heavy rain can drive them out to find new homes. If they cross a farm during this migration, it is considered already destroyed.

deino.name: Deino
deino.blurb: Deino has a powerful sense of smell, and it rushes to bonk its head into anything that smells new. If you’re just learning to cook curry, Deino is a great partner as it loves even a poorly made dish.

deino.name: Zweilous
deino.blurb: Brainscans show that Zweilous only has one mind between both heads. Although the heads don’t get along, they almost always make the same decision. Their bickering is closer to an internal dialog than a fight between two different Pokémon.

deino.name: Hydreigon
deino.blurb: When Hydreigon evolves, both its original heads become arms that can fire off Moves of their own and its brain matter reforms in the middle. Sometimes it argues with its arms out of habit, but they don’t talk back anymore.

larvesta.name: Larvesta
larvesta.blurb: Every autumn, people burn piles of dead leaves to try and attract Larvesta. Towns with a shrine gather together for one giant pile, making a fire that can be seen a mile away. Any Larvesta that stick around afterward are considered guests of the shrine and not to be captured.

larvesta.name: Volcarona
larvesta.blurb: Volcarona’s ember scales make for a powerful incense that temples use in ancient rituals. The scales are dangerous to handle, as they will burn to ash with the slightest spark. They’re also easy to wash off, so Stylists should be especially careful when grooming Volcarona.

cobalion.name: Cobalion
cobalion.blurb: Cobalion considers itself the leader of the Swords of Justice, and demands respect wherever it roams. Wherever Cobalion goes, it tutors Pokémon to be their strongest form.

terrakion.name: Terrakion
terrakion.blurb: Terrakion is easily the strongest Sword of Justice, but it always loses to the others when they spar. When Terrakion entered the battlefields of human war, it would defeat both armies.

virizion.name: Virizion
virizion.blurb: Virizion’s slice is so fast and elegant that many foes don’t recognize it as an attack until they’ve already been cut. Musical Pokémon change their songs when Cobalion appears in the forest.

keldeo.name: Keldeo
keldeo.blurb: Keldeo left the Swords of Justice to prove itself worthy and earn its own legends. Some occultists think Keldeo taught Unovans how to partner with Pokémon instead of fighting them. Even if the timeline doesn’t quite match up, the tale gets retold anyway.

keldeo.name: Keldeo (Resolute)
keldeo.blurb: Keldeo’s sacred sword is so powerful that it has sliced castles clean in half. It appeared once to save humans, when a ship in the middle of an ocean was attacked by a Gyarados swarm.

tornadus.name: Tornadus
tornadus.blurb: Despite being so similar, Tornadus and Thundurus can’t stand each other. They battle whenever they meet, only stopping if forced by a higher power. The storms caused by this can destroy small towns entirely.

tornadus.name: Tornadus (Therian)
tornadus.blurb: Every time Therian Tornadus flaps its wings, a mighty gale rips through an entire Route. Pokémon like Jumpluff and Cottonee never appear where it visits.

thundurus.name: Thundurus
thundurus.blurb: There used to be shrines to try and appease Thundurus, but they were all struck down by its lightning anyway. Their ruins scatter Unova, hidden and untouched.

thundurus.name: Thundurus (Therian)
thundurus.blurb: The beads on Therian Thundurus discharge randomly, even while it sleeps. Herds of Pikachu would follow its route in the hundreds, until they were found in every region in the world.

landorus.name: Landorus
landorus.blurb: Landorus interferes with any wild Pokémon who fight for reasons it doesn’t approve of. If feuding Trainers pray at the Abundant Shrine, supposedly it will give a sign to end the argument.

landorus.name: Landorus (Therian)
landorus.blurb: Trainers are constantly on the lookout for Therian Landorus after The Analysis Scene Zine proclaimed it to be the perfect battle partner. Agriculture school students take an oath to protect Landorus from poachers if they ever become farmers.

reshiram.name: Reshiram
reshiram.blurb: The real names of the Heroes of Truth and Ideals are lost to time. Reshiram can always tell the truth from lies, and is never fooled. Historians think if a Trainer appeases Reshiram enough, it would reveal the brothers’ names.

zekrom.name: Zekrom
zekrom.blurb: The Dragon Stones are inevitable, as Zekrom and Reshiram could not stay awake for long after splitting. Zekrom always works towards the ideals of its Trainer, even if the Trainer commands otherwise. Zekrom will run out its energy entirely before it allows itself to rest.

kyurem.name: Kyurem
kyurem.blurb: Kyurem’s origins have contradictory accounts, but none of the origins (a meteorite, a Dragon Stone, or the remains of a split) have been debunked. Pokéologists wonder if there are multiple Kyurem in the world each with a different origin, but eh…

meloetta.name: Meloetta
meloetta.blurb: Recordings of Meloetta’s music are absurdly popular — some people listen to nothing else. Meloetta has the highest bounty on the Criminal Trade System, and programmers strive to make computers imitate its voice. There’s rumors of a composer that wrote for only Meloetta.

meloetta.name: Meloetta (Pirouette)
meloetta.blurb: Meloetta lost its Pirouette Form when its Relic Song was used to inspire an army to war long ago. It still refuses to sing when Reshiram or Zekrom can hear its voice.

genesect.name: Genesect
genesect.blurb: The only known Genesect fossil was stolen by Team Plasma before scientists could restore it to its true species. Because of this, the Devon Corporation announced a 100,000,000₽ reward to find another. Paleontologists cite increased dig site thefts after the announcement.

chespin.name: Chespin
chespin.blurb: Chespin’s armor is practically unstoppable, but it hasn’t grown enough of a shell to protect its front yet. It grows the armor from the nuts in its diet, with different colors if Chespin eats something different.

chespin.name: Quilladin
chespin.blurb: Quilladin don’t battle much in the wild, as predators give up after a couple bounces. With their shell too heavy to climb, they ram trees to make berries fall. The lack of competition makes them strong in their home environment, but weak to Trainers who can strategize around the shell.

chespin.name: Chesnaught
chespin.blurb: Only other Pokémon can hurt Chesnaught enough to faint, with no other force coming anywhere close. It has to eat an entire garbage can of chestnuts every day to keep its armor in shape.

fennekin.name: Fennekin
fennekin.blurb: Fennekin’s paws aren’t strong at digging, so they work together to make burrows in the desert. Fennekin make colonies near baobab trees, for a steady supply of dry twigs to chew on.

fennekin.name: Braixen
fennekin.blurb: Braixen’s tail fur is rough and grainy like a matchbox. Stylists use a special brush to groom it, and sweeping it across a surface catches a fire. Witches in film used brooms of Braixen hair, so they would spark flames when sweeping.

fennekin.name: Delphox
fennekin.blurb: Delphox loves staring at fire, especially if it caused it. Wild Delphox sometimes burn down the baobab tree their colony depends on, and are sent into exile across the desert.

froakie.name: Froakie
froakie.blurb: Froakie can use their bubbles to make a variety of new sounds, croaking into bubbles of different sizes. It blows these bubbles away from its lakeside home to lure away predators. Trained properly, even a Trainer can pitch their voice with Froakie’s help.

froakie.name: Frogadier
froakie.blurb: When Frogadier blows a bubble around an object, it can stick that bubble to a wall and come back for it later. These bubbles can last for up to an hour, but pop quicker in the summer.

froakie.name: Greninja
froakie.blurb: Rumors of hidden dojos in the woods that specialize in Greninja. They rent Greninja out as mercenaries and spies to whoever has the Pokédollars and knowledge of their existence.

bunnelby.name: Bunnelby
bunnelby.blurb: Bunnelby’s ears can sense underground Pokémon, so it knows to stay away from Onix tunnels or pesky Nincada. These vibrations can pinpoint the location of tree roots, which Bunnelby chews to keep its incisors from growing.

bunnelby.name: Diggersby
bunnelby.blurb: Diggersby uses the wool covering its stomach as a counterbalance when lifting hefty boulders or too much soil above its head. When Diggersby’s wool is sheared, it tends to fall over while burrowing.

fletchling.name: Fletchling
fletchling.blurb: Fletchling’s beautiful songs are not for friendship, but rivalry. If two Fletchlings are in the same room, they will construct more and more elaborate tunes until one breaks down and attacks the other.

fletchling.name: Fletchinder
fletchling.blurb: Forests protected by Trevenant don’t allow Fletchinder to make its nest inside, as its hunting methods wreak havoc on the local plant life. Route planners use them to burn away tall grass for safe passage.

fletchling.name: Talonflame
fletchling.blurb: Talonflame is one of the bravest predators, chasing prey that can retaliate with super-effective Moves. It succeeds by crashing into Wingull or Pelipper so fast that they can’t react, injuring itself in the process. If this ambush doesn’t work, Talonflame is in a lot of trouble.

scatterbug.name: Scatterbug
scatterbug.blurb: Spewpa’s powder is great for keeping computers from overheating, but it’s toxic to the touch. A special process can turn the powder into a dry gel that applies between computer walls, so it doesn’t touch the user and paralyze them.

scatterbug.name: Spewpa
scatterbug.blurb: Spewpa hasn’t yet gathered enough energy to evolve, so it still moves after its cocoon forms. They roam the forest floor looking for dry leaves they can munch on. If they find a patch of soft dirt, they roll around in it to make their powder thicker.

scatterbug.name: Vivillon
scatterbug.blurb: Seeing every Vivillon pattern was much harder before PCs could trade between regions in seconds. Some merchants sold nothing but Vivillon as they traveled the world.

litleo.name: Litleo
litleo.blurb: The last thing Litleo learns before evolving is how to properly roar. Litleo can be heard trying all day long, only letting out loud meows until it’s strong enough to change. It’s only in their cub form that they can purr.

litleo.name: Pyroar
litleo.blurb:
Royal Kalos families captured entire Pyroar prides to keep them in gardens. When the monarchies would fall, Pyroar would take over the garden as their own.
Pokéfeature: Male Pyroar can choose Regal Challenge as their Level 5 Ability. Female Pyroar can choose Pride.

flabébé.name: Flabébé
flabébé.blurb: Flabébé will trade its flower for another with a more preferable shape or color. If two Flabébé want the same flower, they never fight over it. It is believed this common courtesy is because both refuse to risk hurting the flower.

flabébé.name: Floette
flabébé.blurb: Although plucked long ago, Floette’s flower never seems to wilt. Scientists would love to study this, but have yet to successfully separate a Floette from its flower long enough to do so. Floette is so protective, it won’t use the flower’s full power in battle, fearing it may be bruised.

flabébé.name: Florges
flabébé.blurb: Florges surrounds its entire body with flowers and uses its power to create more. Although beautiful, this behavior is harmful to wild ecosystems, as they refuse to let Grass-Types or herbivores in their flower fields.

skiddo.name: Skiddo
skiddo.blurb: Skiddo can’t afford to fall from mountains just yet, so they live on hills where they can climb without getting hurt. Skilled Skiddo can climb a wall at nearly 90 degrees, but they can’t carry passengers at the same time.

skiddo.name: Gogoat
skiddo.blurb: Gogoat Racing is an extreme sport for only the skilled. Rather than flat racetracks, Gogoat race on complex obstacle courses. People bet on who will finish the race, and on who fall off before the finish. Gogoat never misses its jumps, so it’s all on the rider to trust their partner.

pancham.name: Pancham
pancham.blurb: When Pancham get together, they don’t fight. Instead they try and stare each other down with their most intimidating glare. Pancham never want to admit they’re afraid, so this can take all day.

pancham.name: Pangoro
pancham.blurb: Pangoro is rough to adults, but practically passive around children. Pangoro owned by older siblings are often found into games of house, piano recitals, and are overwhelmingly nicknamed “Mrs. Nesbit”. They appreciate the attention.

furfrou.name: Furfrou
furfrou.blurb:
Furfrou is the icon of Kalos, especially after Lysandre soured Pyroar’s popularity. In the wild, they use their sharp claws to cut their own fur. The results aren’t very stylish, so they jump at the chance for a groomer to beautify them.
Pokéfeature: When Furfrou gets a haircut, its Level 5 Ability and the move False Surrender changes based on its haircut. Haircuts can be given during Long Rests (or by a Stylist any time outside of combat).

  • Untrimmed: False Surrender, Tangling Hair
  • Heart: Heart Swap, Soul-Heart
  • Star: Water Shuriken, Victory Star
  • Diamond: Power Gem, Prism Armor
  • Pharaoh: Hex, Cursed Body
  • Kabuki: Role Play, Dancer
  • Matron: Teatime, Friend Guard
  • Dandy: After You, Rivalry
  • La Reine: Trop Kick, Queenly Majesty
  • Debutante: Follow Me, Enthrall
    (The GM and players are encouraged to collaborate to create more.)

espurr.name: Espurr
espurr.blurb: There are toys made for Espurr to calm their psychic energies. Such toys are expensive, but most Trainers would rather buy them than deal with a destroyed living room. Espurr colonies in the wild will often have small cats flung through the air in every direction.

espurr.name: Meowstic (♂)
espurr.blurb: Male Meowstic stay with the colony and protect it from intruders by putting up psychic walls and giving off illusions that there’s nobody home. If left alone at home, they’re usually well-behaved, but panic when they hear the mailman.

espurr.name: Meowstic (♀)
espurr.blurb: Female Meowstic are the ones that hunt, using psychic energies to bring back prey thrice their size. They need a big space to run around in, or they get restless and claw up furniture before tossing it into walls.

honedge.name: Honedge
honedge.blurb: Battlefields slowly clean themselves with Honedge, with spirits inhabiting every weapon until it’s completely empty. There was once a king who attempted to use an army of Honedge, but their reign shortly ended.

honedge.name: Doublade
honedge.blurb: When Doublade loses a blade, it grows another. The discarded sword loses its ghastly powers, but is still made of the strongest materials. This leads poachers to try capturing only half of Doublade, selling the remaining sword to “historical researchers.”

honedge.name: Aegislash
honedge.blurb: Aegislash can control the weak-minded, and orders weak-willed hunters to attack each other without ever drawing its own blade. When an Aegislash takes control of a castle, it waits for a strong Trainer to defeat it and claim the estate as their own.

spritzee.name: Spritzee
spritzee.blurb: Spritzee nests have an extremely strong scent, discouraging predators with heightened senses of smell. If a Trainer walks through one of these nests by accident, they smell like perfume for a week no matter how much they bathe.

spritzee.name: Aromatisse
spritzee.blurb: Spritzee already has trouble flying, but Aromatisse is entirely grounded. It follows its nose to find new and interesting chemicals to fuel its scents, able to recreate any smell it finds after an hour of experimenting.

swirlix.name: Swirlix
swirlix.blurb: Every month, towns with Swirlix hold a food market for baked sweets. There’s vendors and stalls where people can buy food, but a special stand is built just to place gifts for Swirlix. Whoever’s sweets are devoured the quickest get a blue ribbon they can hang on their shop.

swirlix.name: Slurpuff
swirlix.blurb: Aristocrats kept Slurpuff around to protect themselves from poisoning. Slurpuff can smell a single drop of poison in an entire feast, so the nobles wouldn’t touch anything if Slurpuff refused to taste it. Nobles spent a lot of their time malnourished from not eating enough greens.

inkay.name: Inkay
inkay.blurb: Inkay is mischievous but mostly harmless. The worst it does is stealing objects from hypnotized targets and stashing them up a tree. Flipping Inkay over triggers something malicious in its thoughts.

inkay.name: Malamar
inkay.blurb: When Malamar hypnotize their prey, they don’t always eat right away; they use the prey to commit crimes for their own benefit. Even humans who try to take advantage of Malamar’s powers regret it by the end.

binacle.name: Binacle
binacle.blurb: Binacle eggs are laid and hatch simultaneously on rocks. After some time, they move away from their sibling by swapping with a nearby rock. If two Binacle pairs meet, they’re much friendlier when one is related to the other.

binacle.name: Barbaracle
binacle.blurb: Pokéologists found cavities in Barbaracle’s rock that allow its 7 specimens to communicate without alerting anybody else. Trainers should be careful to give affection to each Binacle within Barbaracle, not just the head. If a limb become jealous, it snaps off and leaves.

skrelp.name: Skrelp
skrelp.blurb: Skrelp brings attention to itself and lures predators into masses of seaweed secretly made of Dhelmise. The two then share the meat. Dhelmise never attacks Skrelp, so the Skrelp thinks it’s in charge.

skrelp.name: Dragalge
skrelp.blurb: The water that filters through Dragalge has its poisons filtered out into Dragalge’s body. This makes Dragalge even more toxic, but keeps the water around it clean. Until Dragalge attacks you for swimming nearby, of course.

clauncher.name: Clauncher
clauncher.blurb: Clauncher are terrible to keep in aquariums. They stun other inhabitants and punch through four inches of glass in a single shot. Those who breed Clauncher for meat rotate steel tanks.

clauncher.name: Clawitzer
clauncher.blurb: Clawitzer’s pincer is far bigger than necessary to catch prey or break up rocks in its den. Pokéologists think the claw kept growing to attract mates, leaving Clawitzer in an arms race against its fellows. If the pincer got any bigger, Clawitzer may find itself unable to move.

helioptile.name: Helioptile
helioptile.blurb: Helioptile can’t stand sandstorms, so they run whenever they see Ground- or Rock-Types. They get along well with Pokémon otherwise, and even lend their electricity if there’s enough sunlight to go around.

helioptile.name: Heliolisk
helioptile.blurb: Some Heliolisk absorb so much sunlight when extending their collar that it actually hurts. During these times, Heliolisk glow bright yellow and fires off Thunders so powerful they sear through rubber. Heliolisk won’t leave the sun on its own, so it’s up to its Trainer to find shade.

tyrunt.name: Tyrunt
tyrunt.blurb: After a certain film, Tyrunts gained immense popularity as a child’s Pokémon. This is a big problem as Tyrunts are powerful and temperamental, leading to injury and destroyed playrooms. Many parents wish to have Tyrunts put on the “badge-only” list.

tyrunt.name: Tyrantrum
tyrunt.blurb: Fossil records show Tyrantrum’s body was once covered in the plush feathers that create its mane. Fossil Restoration sites unofficially compete with each other to revive Tyrantrums with more of the feathers intact.

amaura.name: Amaura
amaura.blurb: Although Amaura’s fossils were first discovered in Kalos, restored specimens have flourished in Sinnoh’s cold climate. With its natural predators long extinct, Amaura herds are expected to become common in the next fifty years.

amaura.name: Aurorus
amaura.blurb: Professionals warn against riding Aurorus without proper protective gear. Trainers who ride a newly-evolved Aurorus into battle often come to Pokémon Centers with severe hypothermia.

hawlucha.name: Hawlucha
hawlucha.blurb: Hawlucha Man is the Masked Royal’s most popular opponent. They have clashed 200 times, but joined forces to beat Fezzie Gigantoman and his DynaMachamp. During Hawlucha Man’s betrayal by his Pokémon partner, it wore a different mask to showcase its evil intentions.

dedenne.name: Dedenne
dedenne.blurb: When a Dedenne is sick, its antennae pick up strange signals. They start chittering in seemingly random patterns and digging all over, looking for something that only they can identify. If they chew their way into a TV set, it starts playing mysterious music.

carbink.name: Carbink
carbink.blurb: Areas with high Carbink populations have formed a coalition of like-minded fans online. Each year, there is a contest to mine the most interesting form of Carbink out of the ground. The winner is gifted a year’s supply of rock polish.

goomy.name: Goomy
goomy.blurb: Goomy’s slime isn’t acidic enough to melt anything yet, so it can only eat soft foods. Anything harder than a berry will just sit in Goomy’s stomach for two days until Goomy finally spits it back up.

goomy.name: Sliggoo
goomy.blurb: Whatever Sliggoo absorbs becomes a part of its acid’s chemical structure. This can change its color and its danger level. Nearly everything makes Sliggoo more and more poisonous, but water seems to make it completely harmless.

goomy.name: Goodra
goomy.blurb: Goodra’s meek disposition makes it a poor hunter, so it seeks out human food more than any other Dragon-Type. If you wake up in the night to find that your camp has been covered in disgusting slime, you’ve probably been visited by Goodra.

klefki.name: Klefki
klefki.blurb: Wild Klefki wander city streets for keys to hoard. They won’t return the keys to anyone but the person who captures it, so thieves capture Klefki at first sight. If you return a Klefki’s key to somebody else, it tends to get mad and refuses to battle for an entire day.

phantump.name: Phantump
phantump.blurb: When Phantump sleeps during the day, it curls in and looks just like an ordinary stump. Some Trainers walk past entire orchards of sleeping Phantump without noticing. Phantump are incredibly hostile if they’re woken up too soon, so this is probably for the best.

phantump.name: Trevenant
phantump.blurb: There’s no sure way to tell how many Trevenant are in a forest; each tree that shifts when you’re not looking could be controlled or a Trevenant itself. Trevenant communicate with each other using underground roots, so they coordinate perfectly.

pumpkaboo.name: Pumpkaboo
pumpkaboo.blurb: Breeders in rural areas try and grow the biggest Pumpkaboo possible. Nearly every county holds a contest around the Halloween week, with the winner receiving a prestigious ribbon and a truckload of fertilizer.

pumpkaboo.name: Gourgeist
pumpkaboo.blurb: Bratty children like to carve up pumpkins to look like Gourgeist and throw them at neighbors. Real Gourgeist who wander the streets at night take great offense to this mimicry, and wait until the children are alone to take revenge.

bergmite.name: Bergmite
bergmite.blurb: Bergmite stay so high in the mountains that they mostly battle other Ice-Types. They spend their time making their ice armor thicker and thicker, but if one overdoes it it can’t move. If that happens, Bergmite has to wait and hope that something wants to battle.

bergmite.name: Avalugg
bergmite.blurb: Avalugg migrates from mountain to mountain, moving on whenever the roots in an area get too scarce. It can smash through any obstacle that could endanger a regular mountaineer, so it’s frequently used as a rescue operative.

noibat.name: Noibat
noibat.blurb: Noibat love nesting in any dark corner and are often found in chimneys. As the acoustics of the chimney make their ultrasonic waves ten times louder, if a whole flock of Noibat live together, a house can become unlivable.

noibat.name: Noivern
noibat.blurb: Noivern no longer only eats fruit, now coming after Bug-Types that fly in the night. They particularly enjoy Venomoth, and won’t attack Venonat until it evolves. Noivern still seems to prefer fruit over everything else when it’s available though.

xerneas.name: Xerneas
xerneas.blurb: The shards that break off of Xerneas can cure any illness. Consuming one of the shards fills a person with uncontrollable power, and make Pokémon evolve past their limits. If the Pokémon survives, it may become a mythical creature of its own right.

yveltal.name: Yveltal
yveltal.blurb: Where Yveltal’s feathers are buried, life cannot grow. Battlefields that prayed for its help sit desolate and empty hundreds of years after. Yveltal sleeps in a ruined palace where no creature lives as a mercy.

zygarde.name: Zygarde
zygarde.blurb: All of Zygarde’s cells can communicate with each other just a bit, syncing up to share data about the environment. It breaks apart to learn all about the region, but cannot reform again on its own.

zygarde.name: Zygarde (10%)
zygarde.blurb: Zygarde takes this form to begin the reformation process. It can sniff out cells like itself and runs across the region to find them. Multiple Zygarde can emerge in this form, unaware of the others.

zygarde.name: Zygarde (Complete)
zygarde.blurb: When Zygarde finally completes itself, it determines what to do about the region. If it decides to take action, nothing can change its mind. Its revenge on the civilization that ruined Orre was devastating

diancie.name: Diancie
diancie.blurb: Diancie began life as a Carbink beloved by a small town. When Carbink mysteriously evolved, nobody could recognize it in its new form. Diancie now stays with other Carbink and distrusts humans, fearing it could be forgotten again.

hoopa.name: Hoopa
hoopa.blurb: Hoopa is forever bound to its bottle, only allowed to keep its power for three days. Afterward, Hoopa’s power returns to the Prison Bottle and hides somewhere new in the world. Hoopa will do anything to find it again, granting the most ridiculous requests you can think of.

hoopa.name: Hoopa (Unbound)
hoopa.blurb: Hoopa’s rings could bind any Pokémon stuck inside them to its service. It would force even legendary beasts to steal and battle for its own whims. Humans tricked Hoopa into binding itself by stealing a bottle of its own essence.

volcanion.name: Volcanion
volcanion.blurb: Volcanion hides something in the mountains that has never been found. If somebody tries to climb its mountain, they are enveloped in a thick fog and lost for days before returning empty handed.

rowlet.name: Rowlet
rowlet.blurb: Rowlet’s popularity as a non-battling pet has led to special furniture to accommodate it for a typical home. Rowlet beds are nailed to many walls, and handbags with “Rowlet pockets” appear in every major Alolan city. #Rowletizing is a popular hastag on social media.

rowlet.name: Dartrix
rowlet.blurb: Wild Dartrix usually prefer grooming alone on high perches to battle, but attack Gumshoos and Meowth on sight. Their population was thought to be nearly extinct after these species’ introductions to Alola, only repopulating after the first recorded appearance of Decidueye.

rowlet.name: Decidueye
rowlet.blurb: Decidueye has the fastest archery shot in the world, but likes to slowly think its choices through before acting. This has made it an icon for scholars, but a frustration for battling Trainers.

litten.name: Litten
litten.blurb: Litten are solitary even in the wild, and wander to find their own territory before evolving. Litten in grasslands will burn hollows into trees to make homes. In urban areas, they may accidentally burn down empty buildings for the same purpose.

litten.name: Torracat
litten.blurb: Bird Pokémon learn to fly from the sound of a bell as Torracat spits its fire at them. However, Hawlucha takes the bell as a challenge, and meets Torracat head on.

litten.name: Incineroar
litten.blurb: It’s violent, temperamental, and egotistical, but not all bad. It gets along famously with children and lets them climb all over it. When wild Incineroar meet, they immediately battle for control of the territory. They fight even harder when other Pokémon are watching.

popplio.name: Popplio
popplio.blurb: There’s nothing that can keep Popplio from making its water balloons. Trainers who don’t let it outside at least twice a day report their furniture being drenched in water after Popplio bursts its bubbles all over the house. At least the bubbles use clean water.

popplio.name: Brionne
popplio.blurb: Brionne is an excellent dancer, but it doesn’t dance for battle. It just loves showing off as a performer. Sometimes Brionne will even forget it was battling at all if it gets too worked up.

popplio.name: Primarina
popplio.blurb: Primarina lagoons are always filled with the sound of music. With dancing Brionne and Popplio blowing bubbles, it’s a magical sight. The entire herd can jump in the water and disappear in only a second, so some sailors thought it was the work of legendary creatures.

pikipek.name: Pikipek
pikipek.blurb: After drilling a hole in trees, Pikipek vents the built-up sawdust through its beak as a stinging cloud. Sometimes Pikipek saves this sawdust to chase Emolga out of its nest.

pikipek.name: Trumbeak
pikipek.blurb: Trumbeak’s many calls have made it a popular partner for street performers on Alolan streets. Musicians prefer its ability to mix together sounds to Chatot’s stricter call and response mimicry.

pikipek.name: Toucannon
pikipek.blurb: Toucannon’s larger size compared to Trumbeak make it prefer sparser forests. They build their nests in open sight of other Pokémon and use their bill as a warning against battle, rather than hiding in the trees.

yungoos.name: Yungoos
yungoos.blurb: Yungoos have great noses for sniffing out food, able to find a single morsel of meat in a whole bag of garbage. They use their noses to find Pokémon loot stashes and eat anything that’s remotely edible. Some residents wonder whether they’re any better than Rattata.

yungoos.name: Gumshoos
yungoos.blurb: Police frequently team with Gumshoos to stake out criminal hideouts. Gumshoos watches for suspicious activity during the day, and the officer watches during the night. Rookie Gumshoos tend to run into danger without waking their partner first.

grubbin.name: Grubbin
grubbin.blurb: Grubbin who get together will suck nearly all the sap out of a tree, leaving just enough for the tree to survive. Every once in a while they bite down on a Sudowoodo and regret it.

grubbin.name: Charjabug
grubbin.blurb: Although found alone, Charjabug are social Pokémon. They use sound waves to communicate with each other when they need help or find a tree full of sap. If a Charjabug doesn’t inform the others when it finds a delicious tree, they don’t appear when it calls for help later.

grubbin.name: Vikavolt
grubbin.blurb: Vikavolt has amazing top speed and turns on a dime, but it takes a second to accelerate. When it really needs to power up, it’ll grab a Charjabug and use its Battery to become even more powerful. Despite the weight, this can even make Vikavolt faster!

crabrawler.name: Crabrawler
crabrawler.blurb: The hard materials Crabrawler eats go into its mighty pincers. This leaves the rest of its shell soft and vulnerable, so it’s weak to flanks. Crabrawler who get into boxing matches constantly strafe around each other, searching for an opening.

crabrawler.name: Crabominable
crabrawler.blurb: Crabominable trains in the mountains, punching the ground as it walks to make its pincers tougher. Even today, some think the prints left by these training sessions are from a gigantic monster walking through the snow.

oricorio.name: Oricorio (Baile)
oricorio.blurb: The nectars of Ori flowers are fermented into flavorful alcoholic drinks. These drinks are immensely popular in Alola, but growing the flowers on foreign soil only results in Baile petals. Since this is the most complex flavor, exports are rare.

oricorio.name: Oricorio (Pom-Pom)
oricorio.blurb: Although all Oricorio formes are popular with performers, Pom-Pom is the most commonly trained by commercial Trainers. They are hired to dance for sports games, league battles, and other public events.

oricorio.name: Oricorio (Pa'u)
oricorio.blurb: If an Alolan stage performance has the budget, it is customary to have Oricorio above the stage supplement the actors’ performances. Western screenwriters usually reserve Oricorio Pa’u for Intermission, but in the East it is an integral part of Kishōtenketsu narratives.

oricorio.name: Oricorio (Sensu)
oricorio.blurb: Unlike most Ghost-Types, Oricorio Sensu’s appearance is a good omen. Said to dance for the entertainment of the dead, they are often used before weddings to represent the blessing of ancestors.

cutiefly.name: Cutiefly
cutiefly.blurb: Riolu treat Cutiefly as a mentor, as Cutiefly is better at controlling aura. Cutiefly don’t pay Riolu any mind, going about their day finding flowers to feed on. They love to feed on Florge’s flower fields, easily dodging its wrath.

cutiefly.name: Ribombee
cutiefly.blurb: With its proboscis shortened, Ribombee uses its new arms to pick pollen out of flowers. It loves picking things up with its arms, but it tends to fly off carrying objects without thinking.

rockruff.name: Rockruff
rockruff.blurb: Rockruff rubs itself against boulders to mark territory and keep its fur from getting too soft. They hunt in packs until they’re close to evolving, at which point Rockruff strike out on their own.

rockruff.name: Lycanroc (Midday)
rockruff.blurb: Lycanroc is a popular pet all around the world, but their loyalty is hard to earn. If a Trainer is late to feed Lycanroc even once, it pouts for an entire week. They bathe by rolling in pebbles and sand, to avoid being submerged in water.

rockruff.name: Lycanroc (Midnight)
rockruff.blurb: This Lycanroc is incredibly difficult to train, but it has a natural instinct for battle. Teenagers often evolve Lycanroc during the night and simply let it do whatever it wants in battle, not even trying to control it.

rockruff.name: Lycanroc (Dusk)
rockruff.blurb: The Criminal Trade System pays out the nose for Dusk Lycanroc. Rich Trainers use it as a way to showcase their wealth, but rarely battle with it. This only makes Lycanroc more explosive when it does finally get to fight.

wishiwashi.name: Wishiwashi
wishiwashi.blurb: Blue on top and white on bottom, Wishiwashi’s countershaded colors makes it hard to see from above or below. It can even change its shades to better match the time of day. Fishermen say for every one Wishiwashi you see, there’s 50 you can’t.

wishiwashi.name: Wishiwashi (School)
wishiwashi.blurb: All the Wishiwashi that spawn from a batch of eggs count as a single Pokémon to the Poké Ball Capture Program. At first programmers treated this as a bug, but Trainers refused to let them fix the problem.

mareanie.name: Mareanie
mareanie.blurb: Mareanie hide themselves in the sand when they see predators or humans, disguised as a blue sea flower. If a swimmer accidentally steps on a Mareanie, Mareanie will grab hold of their leg and refuse to let go. It takes the force of a crowbar to loosen its grasp.

mareanie.name: Toxapex
mareanie.blurb: Gastrodon is the only known Pokémon that chooses to prey on Toxapex. The pink ooze that comes out of Gastrodon when it is injured dilutes the poisons in Toxapex’s tentacles, but it’s still a harsh gamble.

mudbray.name: Mudbray
mudbray.blurb: Mudbray’s legendary stubbornness makes training them difficult. Trainers’ suggestions should let them think it was their idea in the first place. Once they’ve got a goal into their heads, they won’t stop, even if it takes the whole day.

mudbray.name: Mudsdale
mudbray.blurb: Mudsdale coloration varies depending on where they spend time. Geologists work together with naturalists to help determine Mudsdale migration patterns by the layers of caked-on mud.

dewpider.name: Dewpider
dewpider.blurb: If Dewpider thinks it can’t win a battle, it inflates its water bubble to appear larger. Dewpider can’t keep its balance when it does this, so the gambit only lasts a couple seconds before collapsing.

dewpider.name: Araquanid
dewpider.blurb: Araquanid spend large portions of their life walking above the water, only coming back down to get fresh oxygen for their bubble. Masquerain like to pop their bubble for fun, so Araquanid keep to themselves at night.

fomantis.name: Fomantis
fomantis.blurb: Fomantis pretends to be a Bug so larva Pokémon like Caterpie and Grubbin will leave it alone. They can’t keep up the act when they sleep, so they actively seek out Trainers for protection when they hear footsteps.

fomantis.name: Lurantis
fomantis.blurb: Cutiefly work together with sleeping Lurantis, warning them about predators during the day in exchange for a bit of pollen. Every once in a while Cutiefly will give off false alarms for a reward, but if it tries this gambit too often Lurantis just stops responding.

morelull.name: Morelull
morelull.blurb: Morelull sabotage rival Paras by perching on its back and siphoning vitality from Paras’ mushrooms. Pokéologists aren’t sure whether this is parasitic or beneficial.

morelull.name: Shiinotic
morelull.blurb: To sleep, Shiinotic retract their arms and collapse their mushroom bell around their eyes to prevent daylight from disturbing their slumber.

salandit.name: Salandit
salandit.blurb: If Salandit can’t squeeze its way through a cranny, it scorches the wall until there’s enough space. They love to steal anything that glitters, and fill their den with treasures to impress Salazzle.

salandit.name: Salazzle
salandit.blurb: There are two ways to lure Salazzle out of its cave. The less reliable way to make it appear is to threaten a group of Salandits, letting one go to warn its boss. But if you want Salazzle to appear every time, there’s nothing better than a good dance.

stufful.name: Stufful
stufful.blurb: 10% of Stufful’s communication is verbal. The rest is a combination of exaggerated body language and scents emitted from its rear tag. Humans can’t smell most of these scents, so Stufful’s sudden mood swings come as a surprise.

stufful.name: Bewear
stufful.blurb: Bewear has a strong parental instinct and feeds small injured Pokémon it finds. It always finds these Pokémon when it walks back through a place it’s been before.

bounsweet.name: Bounsweet
bounsweet.blurb: Alolan children often keep a Bounsweet before graduating to more-involved Pokémon partners. Bounsweet only needs daily watering, so it’s a good introduction to pet ownership. If it does evolve into Steenee, parents end up doing most of the work again.

bounsweet.name: Steenee
bounsweet.blurb: Bird Pokémon can’t stand Steenee, as it plucks their tail feathers and bounces on their head without a worry. Steenee doesn’t play so rowdy with other Pokémon, just the ones that hunted it down in a previous form.

bounsweet.name: Tsareena
bounsweet.blurb: Tsareena’s hard sepals cover its entire back to thwart surprise attacks. It viciously kicks whatever dares to attack Bounsweet or Steenee in its presence, but expects absolute loyalty in return.

comfey.name: Comfey
comfey.blurb: Doctors are still researching Comfey’s ability to use flowers as medicine. There’s a common scam where people will bottle flowers allegedly treated with Comfey oil, but since Comfey’s flowers only heal Pokémon for an hour after being detached these are always fake.

oranguru.name: Oranguru
oranguru.blurb: Oranguru construct their signature fans by weaving local foliage with their own hair. These fans let them communicate with other Pokémon species from across the battlefield.

passimian.name: Passimian
passimian.blurb: Trained Passimian make excellent orchard harvesters. Give a team a basket, and they’ll pluck, pass, and fill it within a minute.

wimpod.name: Wimpod
wimpod.blurb: A new business uses Wimpod to clean areas after large parties. The Wimpod are released to eat every piece of trash in their path. They are then “herded” by frightening them into an efficient formation. The ethics of this business are still under debate.

wimpod.name: Golisopod
wimpod.blurb: Golisopod pride themselves on never fainting in battle, rather than on always winning. If they think they face defeat, they retreat of their own accord. But if two Golisopod battle each other, they will not give even a single inch.

sandygast.name: Sandygast
sandygast.blurb: Sandygast are frightening, but rarely last long. Most wash away when the tide comes in, dashed to pieces that take a long time to reform. Specimens that hold together during the tide are even more dangerous.

sandygast.name: Palossand
sandygast.blurb: When Palossand meet, they battle for dominance. The loser’s shovel is broken and their sand merged into the winner’s body. Palossand who survive multiple battles can get as big as a house.

pyukumuku.name: Pyukumuku
pyukumuku.blurb: Tourists think them cute, and natives honor them as an important part of Alola, but hotel owners and new citizens consider Pyukumuku a pest. Petitions to relocate Pyukumuku go nowhere, as they inevitably return in only a few days.

type: null.name: Type: Null
type: null.blurb: No Pokémon is more prized in criminal rings than Type: Null. A contest is held every three months to try decrypting the data sealing its heavy mask, but nobody has found the secret yet.

type: null.name: Silvally
type: null.blurb: Aether Foundation’s claim that they created only three Silvally has been investigated after multiple ten-year-olds registered the Pokémon under their ownership. Its memory drives are popular on the black market, driving further suspicion.

minior.name: Minior
minior.blurb: Minior are a major part of humanity’s endeavor to clean up the world’s orbital space. Minior love to eat small space debris, and bring the particulates back when they fall. Now the only obstacles to space vehicles is Minior themselves — and Rayquaza, of course.

minior.name: Minior (Core)
minior.blurb: Minior Cores are dangerous for collectors with addictive personalities. Some camp for weeks on a known Minior crash site to glimpse a new color, or spend their entire salary on rare Cores from the Criminal Trade System.

komala.name: Komala
komala.blurb: Komala’s constant sleep makes it perfect to Drowzee. The two form a symbiotic relationship, with Drowzee protecting Komala from other threats. If the Drowzee evolves, the relationship usually turns sour.

turtonator.name: Turtonator
turtonator.blurb: Turtonator crane their necks towards the sky, watching for meteors. As they are far too sluggish to beat other Pokémon to the impact site, nobody is sure why.

togedemaru.name: Togedemaru
togedemaru.blurb: Togedemaru sheds its spikes each new season, leaving metal thorns behind. Stepping on these spikes hurts worse than a Lego, so Trainers should use a magnet brush to clean Togedemaru regularly. In the wild, the spikes are gobbled up by Geodude.

mimikyu.name: Mimikyu
mimikyu.blurb: Although Pikachu is the most popular Pokémon, many areas have their own local favorites. If a Mimikyu finds itself in a place where another species is revered, it tries to create a different disguise.

bruxish.name: Bruxish
bruxish.blurb: Bruxish’s teeth are stronger than its skin, so they don’t tolerate each other’s company. Most reefs have a single Bruxish that calls the sands its territory.

drampa.name: Drampa
drampa.blurb: Drampa can walk on water or even fly after a running start, so it’s a classic Ride Pokémon on Alola. It’s not fast, but Drampa’s fur is soft and it always keeps riders safe. Even small children are allowed to ride Drampa unsupervised, something no other Pokémon can claim.

dhelmise.name: Dhelmise
dhelmise.blurb: Dhelmise infest Jellicent palaces to pilfer anchors from the ships Jellicent drags to the sea floor. Dhelmise is suspected to be more ship parts than the anchor, and litter boat decks after violent storms. There are tales of ghost ships with no crew, covered in blood-red seaweed.

jangmo-o.name: Jangmo-o
jangmo-o.blurb: Jangmo-o live in large packs but don’t hunt together. Instead, they spar at night and hunt alone during the day. If Jangmo-o find themselves after the same prey, they make competing clangs with their forehead scale. The louder noise wins, if the prey hasn’t already run off.

jangmo-o.name: Hakamo-o
jangmo-o.blurb: The Alolan Dance Step lists at least twenty seven unique dances Hakamo-o will perform to communicate with its pack. Fifteen of these are about combat, but the rest have a wide variety of meanings.

jangmo-o.name: Kommo-o
jangmo-o.blurb: Kommo-o sleeps in places that enhance its acoustics, but most of these are manmade, so Kommo-o leads packs of its pre-evolutions to seize them. Its tail’s jangling coordinates Jangmo-o and Hakamo-o’s movements, but the Kommo-o refuses to join except for worthy foes.

tapu koko.name: Tapu Koko
tapu koko.blurb: Shooting stars in the sky could be real, but they could also be Tapu Koko. Tapu Koko races Miniors through the sky, saps radios of their broadcasts, and blasts Trainers with its power just to test their mettle. It does not know fear or rest, and only deals in curiosities.

tapu lele.name: Tapu Lele
tapu lele.blurb: Tapu Lele heals and destroys without reason. As long as it is approached with a straightforward face, anything can happen. It despises tricks though, and punishes them with extreme prejudice.

tapu bulu.name: Tapu Bulu
tapu bulu.blurb: Tapu Bulu does not wish for violence, but demands respect. When it rings its bell, all around must kneel or prepare for battle. Tapu Bulu lives and dies by the old traditions, some of which only it can still remember.

tapu fini.name: Tapu Fini
tapu fini.blurb: Do not approach Tapu Fini or its fog. If it wishes to grant a human its boon, Tapu Fini appears of its own volition. Otherwise, simply approaching Tapu Fini can be a reason for punishment. Its mood is as volatile as the ocean waves.

cosmog.name: Cosmog
cosmog.blurb: Composed of little more than stardust and light, it’s incredibly frail. Cosmog accumulates matter seemingly from nowhere and instinctively seeks out a guardian as it grows. Specimens are vanishingly rare and likely not of this planet.

cosmog.name: Cosmoem
cosmog.blurb: After achieving critical mass, Cosmog metamorphosized into this cocoon-like form. Cosmoem’s shell is record-breakingly dense, and nigh-impenetrable as it waits in a catatonic state.

cosmog.name: Solgaleo
cosmog.blurb: This final metamorphosis of Cosmog is from sustained exposure to solar energy, which sparks a reaction that can turn night to day. Its third eye sees the path to other worlds, but it may stay to protect its former guardian that showed it kindness as an infant.

cosmog.name: Lunala
cosmog.blurb: The influence of lunar bodies prompts Cosmoem’s development into this form. It traps and absorbs light to turn day into night. Confirmed sightings are scarce, as they return to another world as soon as possible.

necrozma.name: Necrozma
necrozma.blurb:
Identification: Black
Discovered deep underground, it is unclear if subject is native to this world or Ultra Space. Its prism-like body alternates between totally absorbing or refracting light, and it expresses deep contempt for its surroundings through powerful laser beams.

necrozma.name: Necrozma (Dusk Mane)
necrozma.blurb:
Identification: Black Lion
Subject’s victim is forced to emit more light than even the subject is capable of absorbing. With no self control, subject’s parasitism’s energy consumption is completely unsustainable.

necrozma.name: Necrozma (Dawn Wings)
necrozma.blurb:
Identification: Black Bat
Subject’s parasitic connection with the victim forces constant emitting of moonlight and “dark light” energy. Dark light energy has physical properties not found in any Type of this world, but cannot be studied without violence.

necrozma.name: Necrozma (Ultra)
necrozma.blurb:
Identification: Radiance
Subject bathes in the devoured light of unseen suns. It strengthens itself to fight the hand from another world that shattered it in ages past, frightened despite all its power.

nihilego.name: Nihilego
nihilego.blurb:
Identification: Symbiont
Subject latches onto human hosts to grant immeasurable power and rage. Intelligence level unknown, but to be treated as extremely hostile. Crystalline structures found on subject’s homeworld to also be treated as extremely hostile.

buzzwole.name: Buzzwole
buzzwole.blurb:
Identification: Absorption
Subject drains bodily fluids from its foes to catalyze incredible growth in its muscles. The bodybuilding poses it instinctively strikes are the extent of its communication.

pheromosa.name: Pheromosa
pheromosa.blurb:
Identification: Beauty
Subject carries itself with an aloof stature, holding the world around it in contempt. The only recorded exception is Z-Stones, which the subject holds in fond regard. It is capable of breaking world records for agility and acceleration without fatigue.

xurkitree.name: Xurkitree
xurkitree.blurb:
Identification: Lighting
Subject alternates between dormancy and activity — after absorbing phenomenal amounts of electricity from its surroundings, it then discharges intense radiance and lightning. Motivation for these actions has yet to be found.

celesteela.name: Celesteela
celesteela.blurb:
Identification: Blaster
Subject’s body is formed from an alien alloy that is equally organic and metallic. Undiscovered chemical reactions within it produce enough power to soar through the atmosphere.

kartana.name: Kartana
kartana.blurb:
Identification: Blade
Subject is a living weapon made of grass fibers woven into sheets of impossible thinness. Weak to high temperatures but can cut through anything.

guzzlord.name: Guzzlord
guzzlord.blurb:
Identification: Glutton
Subject’s entire body evolved to devour. Leaves no traces of its passing, but puts the immense energy to no use other than to keep eating.

stakataka.name: Stakataka
stakataka.blurb:
Identification: Assembly
Subject is composed of 150 small stone-like lifeforms, each with an eye on one side. It often remains passive and completely still but will react with extreme aggression when an object or creature is placed atop it.

blacephalon.name: Blacephalon
blacephalon.blurb:
Identification: Burst
Subject is semi-corporeal and composed partially of thermal energy, most noticeably in its ‘head’. This structure is used primarily for pyrotechnic assault and can be regenerated afterward; it is unclear if it serves any anatomical purpose otherwise.

poipole.name: Poipole
poipole.blurb:
Identification: Adhesive
Subject originates from another world with humans and is a common starter for new trainers there. In the wild, it nests with its kin and uses an adhesive venom for self-defense; it seems to take amusement in foes’ struggles to break free.

poipole.name: Naganadel
poipole.blurb:
Identification: Stinger
Subject is the only known Ultra Beast to have undergone evolution. Its abdomen comprises most of its body, swollen with venom that it can eject with deadly accuracy. Its highly developed brain is inside its stinger.

magearna.name: Magearna
magearna.blurb: Magearna was built to entertain, but its heart felt the loneliness of the princess it danced for. When Magearna cried for the princess, its tears washed away its magnificent paint, leaving it drab and grey. Somewhere in the world, the blueprints for the original Magearna lay hidden.

marshadow.name: Marshadow
marshadow.blurb: On moonless nights, there have been rumors of entire hordes of Marshadow marching through the night. Nobody knows where they are going, or what they are training so hard to fight.

zeraora.name: Zeraora
zeraora.blurb: Zeraora has been spotted biting through power lines, smashing into generators and stealing entire plants’ worth of electricity. Its power grows each time, but this power cannot last for long. When all of its electricity is used up, Zeraora will come back looking for more.

meltan.name: Meltan
meltan.blurb: Tools and silverware should be locked away during Meltan infestations, as they can squeeze through the smallest holes. The hex nut can’t change shape, so it’s often left behind. If you find the nut, put it in a wooden bowl and Meltan will get stuck retrieving it. Make sure not to put too many Meltan in the same bowl.

meltan.name: Melmetal
meltan.blurb: Historians are unsure why Mysterious Boxes appeared recently, nor why Melmetal was sealed after being so revered 3,000 years ago. Maybe Melmetal was the prototype for the Legendary Titans, or it destroyed the Relic Castle, or maybe it helped build the ultimate weapon.

grookey.name: Grookey
grookey.blurb: Grookey’s sticks aren’t very durable, so they need a steady supply. Maple or hickory makes the best sound, so Grookey will tear twigs off whenever they find one. You can always tell a troop of Grookey has passed through by seeing which trees have been stripped bare.

grookey.name: Thwackey
grookey.blurb: Thwackey are ideal partners for musicians, as their timing is always perfect. They’ll keep playing music all day unless they’re distracted though, so Musicians who don’t want to spend time training are known to wear headphones wherever they go.

grookey.name: Rillaboom
grookey.blurb: The grass that makes up Rillaboom’s hair also acts as a perfect bed for maple and hickory seeds. If Rillaboom’s drum is destroyed, it will grow a new drum in its hair in a week.

scorbunny.name: Scorbunny
scorbunny.blurb: Scorbunny is always on the move, prone to kicking around while dreaming. It never lives in one place lfor ong, as it burns away the grass it needs to eat when it runs. Give your Scorbunny an outlet for its excess energy, or it’ll take it out on your belongings.

scorbunny.name: Raboot
scorbunny.blurb: Frequent training gives Raboot better self-control after evolution. Its warm fluffy fur has inspired fashion trends, and young children are especially fond of mimicking its style. Raboot have the best teamwork of their line, without Scorbunny’s distractions or Cinderace’s ego.

scorbunny.name: Cinderace
scorbunny.blurb: While best known for kicking burning pebbles as projectiles, Cinderace can adapt to and match any professional athlete. Trainers need to be ready to keep up with its headstrong and competitive attitude, though.

sobble.name: Sobble
sobble.blurb: Sobble’s limbs evolved to grasp onto seaweed stalks. It can hide underwater on a seaweed’s side for hours, only becoming visible when alone. Anything that disturbs the seaweed gets a nasty ambush.

sobble.name: Drizzile
sobble.blurb: Drizzile prefers freshwater lake habitats, so it moves inland. If it finds a lake that Frogadier already lives in, the two scheme endlessly to drive each other out. Other nearby Pokémon deal with the consequences.

sobble.name: Inteleon
sobble.blurb: Inteleon refuse to stay in the open for long, preferring to snipe from afar. It can hide in trees as comfortably as under water. For some reason, its skeleton glows under ultraviolet light. Pokéologists think this is so Inteleon can cooperate without giving away their position.

skwovet.name: Skwovet
skwovet.blurb: Children in Galar are forbidden to climb berry trees without a Pokémon companion because of Skwovet; it interprets anything as a threat to its stash. Skwovet can hoard berries from over a dozen different trees, and you may even find missing school lunches up there.

skwovet.name: Greedent
skwovet.blurb: At the local Bob’s Your Uncle restaurant, anyone who pays for a Greedent gets their own meal for free. Rookies see this as a great deal, but Greedent’s appetite will almost always make up the difference.

rookidee.name: Rookidee
rookidee.blurb: Rookidee don’t migrate like other birds, choosing to brave cold weather. Galarian children make nest boxes for Rookidee when snow arrives. When spring arrives, Rookidee leave the box and children pull them down to find a gift as thanks.

rookidee.name: Corvisquire
rookidee.blurb: Corvisquire is an incredibly social bird that can remember faces and teach them to others. Trainers who abuse Rookidee in one route can find themselves harassed by Corvisquire across the entire region if there’s enough witnesses.

rookidee.name: Corviknight
rookidee.blurb: Corviknight can only perch on strong branches that can support its weight. This leads it to urban areas with iron poles and stone archways. One flock of Corviknight has lived inside Wyndon’s tower for centuries; if they leave the tower, superstition says Galar will fall.

blipbug.name: Blipbug
blipbug.blurb: Blipbug is one of the few Pokémon who can learn to read. Gardeners who want to get rid of Blipbug can trap them by putting up a sign with long rambling text. The Blipbug will stop and refuse to move until they’ve gotten to the end.

blipbug.name: Dottler
blipbug.blurb: If Dottler thinks an opponent approaches, it puts up invisible barriers to guide the Pokémon elsewhere. If the Pokémon finds Dottler anyway and battles, it adds a week to Dottler’s evolution time. Trainers can overcome this delay by reading poetry to Dottler for two hours a day.

blipbug.name: Orbeetle
blipbug.blurb: Orbeetle’s wings are vestigial, left over from an age when its psychic powers were weak. The elytra have adapted into wells of psychic power. Galarian entymologists have an unofficial betting pool on whether Orbeetle’s wings will also repurpose themselves, or simply atrophy.

nickit.name: Nickit
nickit.blurb: Nickit doesn’t store food, relying entirely on theft. If too many Pokémon get offended and move away, it’s left alone and hungry. Nickit must strike a balance between theft and a charming reputation.

nickit.name: Thievul
nickit.blurb: A Thievul’s territory can cover miles of secret lairs and easy targets. Liepard can detect the secret scent that Thievul marks targets with, and poaches them. Liepard and Thievul are both cowards, so when they meet they steal from each other but try to avoid their rival.

gossifleur.name: Gossifleur
gossifleur.blurb: If you find a garden where mysterious music plays, you’ve probably stumbled into a Gossifleur field. Every Gossifleur’s song is different, but when two sing they harmonize into a single melody. In early spring, citizens report entire fields of Gossifleur making symphonic music.

gossifleur.name: Eldegoss
gossifleur.blurb: Yoshida Coffee uses Eldegoss seeds to make the strongest coffee on the market. By most standards it’s nutritious and healthy, but a health warning was posted after someone drank two cups and couldn’t sleep for three days.

wooloo.name: Wooloo
wooloo.blurb: Wooloo wool is a main export of Galar, as it makes very soft and durable cloth. Domestic Wooloo need frequent trims to keep from growing too thick. Wild Wooloo keep their wool under control by rolling down hills and tearing their wool on whatever it sticks to on the way down.

wooloo.name: Dubwool
wooloo.blurb: Despite their appearance, wild Dubwool don’t like to fight. Their springy, protective fur and daunting horns are enough to discourage predators. Disputes over territory or mates are resolved with threat displays that never get followed up.

chewtle.name: Chewtle
chewtle.blurb: Chewtle can’t help but chew on everything it finds. Because it’s teething, Trainers are recommended to find it something soft and cold to soothe the ache. Chewtle are surprisingly docile once this is dealt with.

chewtle.name: Drednaw
chewtle.blurb: Drednaw don’t appreciate complicated tactics or fancy techniques. If they can’t bite or smash a foe to bits, they try again over and over. Only dedicated Trainers can bring out Drednaw’s full potential, where it becomes practically unstoppable.

yamper.name: Yamper
yamper.blurb: Yamper’s prance-generated electricity massages its short leg muscles, letting it run further. This feedback loop sometimes keeps Yamper moving for hours, chasing Flying Taxis. Frustrated Trainers across the region end up calling the Lost & Found in Motostoke.

yamper.name: Boltund
yamper.blurb: When the Pokémon League is off-season, Galar citizens pour their energy into Boltund Races. Betting was banned over a decade ago, but gamblers can find willing bettors in every bar. There are many whispers about DENSOKU, the most prominent Boltund Race sponsor.

rolycoly.name: Rolycoly
